qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires producers of architectural paint to establish and implement a Paint Stewardship Program in Maryland for the collection, transportation, and processing of postconsumer paint. The program is funded by a paint stewardship assessment added to the purchase price of paint sold in the state, and producers or a representative organization must submit plans and annual reports to the Maryland Department of the Environment for approval and oversight.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment, Office of Recycling
qa_results.stakeholders: Architectural paint producers, retailers, distributors, consumers, local governments, and the Maryland Department of the Environment.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have no fiscal impact in FY 2025. Starting in FY 2026, State special fund expenditures and revenues increase by an estimated $70,212, and $64,307 in FY 2027. These expenditures cover the Maryland Department of the Environment's administrative and oversight costs, which are offset by plan and report review fees paid by paint producers. Local governments may see a decrease in waste management costs as paint is diverted from landfills, though both state and local agencies will face minimal increases in the cost of purchasing paint due to the stewardship assessment.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for enforcing environmental laws and oversight of the Office of Recycling, MDE is the lead regulator for the Paint Stewardship Program. The agency must review and approve stewardship plans, assessments, and annual reports, while also maintaining a public list of compliant producers.

MES is explicitly required by the bill to coordinate with the Office of Recycling to study and report on recycling centers, financing of systems, and the economics of waste disposal and recycling as part of the biennial report to the Governor.
The Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the State Recycling Trust Fund, which will now receive new revenue from paint stewardship plan review fees, annual report fees, and penalties.
The State Treasurer's Office is the custodian of the State Recycling Trust Fund and is responsible for holding and investing the funds collected through the program's fees and assessments.

DGS is responsible for the maintenance and renovation of state-owned facilities. As a consumer of architectural paint for these facilities, the agency will be subject to the paint stewardship assessments added to the purchase price of paint.
The Governor's Office receives mandatory reports from MDE and MES regarding recycling centers and the overall cost-benefit review of the Paint Stewardship Program due by 2028.
The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for MDE and would be involved in enforcing the civil and administrative penalties established for violations of the Paint Stewardship Program.

DBM oversees the state's personnel and budget system. The fiscal note indicates the need for additional contractual staff and special fund budget authority to handle the program's implementation and oversight.
The OAH provides a forum for residents and businesses to challenge agency decisions. This would apply to any contested enforcement actions or administrative penalties issued by MDE under the program.

The bill impacts producers, retailers, and distributors of architectural paint. As the state's primary economic development agency, Commerce has a secondary interest in how these regulations affect the business environment and retail sector.

OLA is responsible for auditing state agencies like MDE to ensure public funds and the State Recycling Trust Fund are handled according to state law and that financial controls for the new fees are in place.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of any Maryland county to establish a subclass of real property for vacant lots or improved properties cited as vacant and unfit for habitation on a housing or building violation notice. It further allows these local governments to set a special property tax rate for such properties and requires them to report annually to the Department of Housing and Community Development and the General Assembly on the rates set and the results thereof.
qa_results.responsible_party: Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county
qa_results.stakeholders: Owners of vacant and abandoned property, small businesses owning such property, Baltimore City, and Maryland county governments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State finances. Local property tax revenues for Baltimore City and county governments may be affected depending on the specific tax rates established for the new property subclass. Small businesses that own vacant or abandoned property may be meaningfully affected. Local jurisdictions that enact a special rate are responsible for reporting requirements, which can be managed with existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires Baltimore City and any county enacting a special tax rate for vacant property to report annual data to the Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD). This data includes property counts, revenue changes, and plans for adaptive reuse, aligning with DHCD's mission of neighborhood revitalization and affordable housing management.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the implementation of new laws and the operations of the DHCD, which is tasked with the bill's reporting requirements. The bill is a priority piece of legislation (HB 2) signed by the Governor to improve community economic opportunities.

The Department of Planning coordinates land use and sustainable growth. This bill addresses vacant and abandoned properties, which are central to the agency's mission of protecting community vitality and implementing smart growth strategies to balance development and environmental stewardship.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to state agencies, including the DHCD. They may be required to provide legal guidance on the interpretation of the new tax subclass authority or the enforcement of the reporting requirements established by the bill.

As the state's chief financial officer and fiscal watchdog, the Comptroller monitors changes to tax law and local revenue structures. While this bill affects local property tax rates, the Comptroller sits on the Board of Public Works and oversees the state's long-term fiscal health which is impacted by local property revitalization.

DBM serves as the state's central fiscal authority. While the bill has no direct state fiscal impact, DBM monitors local revenue trends and the fiscal accountability of state agencies like DHCD that manage the resulting reporting data.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits public and private institutions of higher education in Maryland that receive State funds from using legacy preference or donor preference as a criterion for admission. Legacy preference is defined as a preference based on an applicant's relationship to an alum, while donor preference is based on a relationship to a financial supporter. Institutions are still permitted to collect information about familial relationships to alumni for data collection purposes.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland institutions of higher education that receive State funds, including the University System of Maryland, Morgan State University, St. Mary's College of Maryland, and participating private institutions.
qa_results.stakeholders: Applicants to Maryland higher education institutions, alumni, financial donors, and the administrative bodies of public and private colleges and universities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have no material fiscal impact on State or local governments. Public four-year institutions and community colleges can adjust admissions processes using existing resources. While some private nonprofit institutions indicated that removing legacy incentives might affect tuition revenue or alumni giving, the Department of Legislative Services assumes any such impact would be minimal and cannot be reliably estimated.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's primary regulatory and coordinating board for public and private colleges and universities, MHEC is responsible for establishing statewide policies and overseeing institutional standards, making it the central agency for enforcing the bill's prohibition on legacy and donor preferences.
USM oversees 12 public universities that are directly subject to this bill. The bill explicitly changes the undergraduate admissions standards for all constituent institutions within the system.

As an independent public university that receives state funds, Morgan State is directly impacted by the bill's restrictions on admission criteria and will need to ensure its admissions processes comply with the prohibition on legacy and donor preferences.

As a state-funded public honors college, Saint Mary's is directly subject to the bill. While the fiscal note suggests it does not heavily rely on legacy status, the college must legally ensure its admissions standards do not consider donor or legacy preferences.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to state agencies and institutions of higher education. It will likely provide legal guidance on the implementation of these new standards and defend the state in potential challenges regarding the legality of admission criteria.

The Governor's Office oversees executive departments and signs legislation into law. This bill represents a significant shift in state educational policy that the Governor's administration will monitor and potentially coordinate through its educational initiatives.

The bill explicitly allows institutions to collect data on familial relationships to alumni for the purpose of data collection. As the agency responsible for tracking student and workforce outcomes, MLDS may eventually manage or analyze this data to study admissions trends and educational equity.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill codifies the common law crime of indecent exposure and establishes a more severe misdemeanor penalty for committing indecent exposure with prurient intent in the presence of a minor, specifically when the minor is at least 2 years old and more than 4 years younger than the offender.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary and the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Minors, individuals charged with indecent exposure offenses, and the Maryland criminal justice system.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State and local revenues and expenditures are expected to increase minimally due to the bill's penalty provisions. The new offense for indecent exposure in the presence of a minor carries a maximum penalty of 5 years imprisonment and a $10,000 fine, which is higher than the standard penalty of 3 years and a $1,000 fine.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates a new criminal offense and codifies existing common law, directly impacting court filings, case management, and sentencing. The fiscal note provides specific data on indecent exposure violations currently filed in District and Circuit courts.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill increases the maximum penalty for indecent exposure in the presence of a minor to 5 years. Individuals sentenced to more than 18 months are incarcerated in State facilities managed by this agency. The agency also oversees parole and probation intakes for these offenders.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency is responsible for representing indigent defendants in criminal cases where incarceration is possible. The fiscal note specifically notes that the Public Defender anticipates an increase in attorney caseloads due to the new statutory offense.

As a primary statewide law enforcement agency, the State Police are responsible for investigating criminal law violations and enforcing the new specific charges related to indecent exposure in the presence of a minor.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office serves as the central hub for public safety policy and advises the Governor on criminal justice strategies. The bill's focus on crime prevention and specific protections for minors falls within its policy mandate.
The Governor's Office is responsible for signing the bill into law and overseeing the general enforcement of state criminal statutes through its executive agencies.
The Comptroller acts as the state's tax collector and fiscal watchdog; the bill is expected to generate a minimal increase in general fund revenues through the collection of new criminal fines.
The OAG manages criminal appeals and provides legal advice to the state agencies tasked with enforcing this new provision of the Criminal Law Article.
DBM oversees the state budget and general fund; the bill will result in a minimal increase in expenditures related to incarceration costs and revenue from fines.
The GOC leads policy action to improve the well-being and safety of children. This bill specifically creates a new criminal offense to protect minors from indecent exposure.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Housing Innovation Pilot Program and the Housing Innovation Fund within the Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD). The program provides low- or no-interest loans to local housing authorities and county governments to develop mixed-income, cross-subsidized housing projects. These projects must prioritize public ownership, prevailing wage commitments, and long-term affordability set-asides.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD)
qa_results.stakeholders: Local housing authorities, county governments, private housing developers, and Maryland residents seeking affordable or mixed-income housing.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill increases State general obligation (GO) bond expenditures by $10,000,000 in FY 2025 due to a budget restriction for the pilot program. From FY 2026 through 2029, the Governor may reallocate $5,000,000 annually from existing rental housing programs to the new fund. General fund expenditures for DHCD administration increase by $170,535 in FY 2025, rising to $175,200 by FY 2029. Local jurisdictions will see increased revenues and expenditures via loan receipts and project costs.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Housing Innovation Pilot Program and the Housing Innovation Fund within this department, designating it as the primary agency for administration, project selection, and loan management.

As the head of the executive branch, the Governor oversees the program's implementation and is authorized by the bill to include specific appropriations for the Housing Innovation Fund in the annual state budget.
The bill statutorily requires the Comptroller to account for the newly created Housing Innovation Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund within the state's financial system.
The Treasurer is required to hold and invest the Housing Innovation Fund's assets and manages the general obligation bonds used to capitalize the program as identified in the fiscal note.
This agency manages the state's budget process and oversees the allocation of the $5 million annual appropriations and the $10 million in bond funding authorized for the pilot program.
The bill prioritizes housing projects that commit to prevailing wage requirements, a regulatory area managed and enforced by the Department of Labor.
The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Housing and Community Development and will assist in drafting program regulations and reviewing loan agreements.
The OLA will be responsible for conducting fiscal and compliance audits of the new program and the Housing Innovation Fund to ensure the proper use of state resources.
The Board approves significant state expenditures and the use of general obligation bonds, which are the primary funding source for the program's initial capitalization.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the establishment of a condominium regime on a leasehold estate where an affordable housing land trust owns the reversionary fee simple estate. This places affordable housing land trusts on the same footing as the State, counties, municipal corporations, and the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority regarding the authority to establish residential condominium regimes on leasehold property.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Secretary of State and affordable housing land trusts
qa_results.stakeholders: Affordable housing land trusts, low-income and moderate-income families, and residential property developers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect Maryland State or local government finances or operations. Revenues and expenditures are expected to remain unaffected, and the impact on small businesses is categorized as minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary state agency dedicated to expanding access to affordable housing and fostering neighborhood revitalization, the department is directly impacted by changes to the operational authority of affordable housing land trusts, which are key partners in their mission.

The Secretary of State is responsible for the oversight and registration of condominium regimes in Maryland; this bill expands the types of entities authorized to establish such regimes on leasehold estates.

The bill requires that condominium declarations, bylaws, and plats be recorded among the county land records, which are maintained by the clerks of the court under the guidance of the Administrative Office of the Courts.

The Department of Planning coordinates land use and sustainable growth policy; authorizing new residential condominium structures on land trust property aligns with their mission to support community development and smart growth.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel on the interpretation and enforcement of the Real Property Article, which this bill amends regarding the establishment of condominium regimes.
The Governor’s Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation and oversees the executive agencies, such as DHCD, that implement affordable housing initiatives enabled by this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill requires the State Department of Assessments and Taxation (SDAT) to maintain a website for voluntary electronic donations to the Homeowner Protection Program (HPP). It also mandates that local tax collectors include an insert with each property tax bill, designed by the State Tax Sale Ombudsman, which describes the HPP and encourages taxpayers to make a donation to the Homeowner Protection Fund.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Department of Assessments and Taxation
qa_results.stakeholders: Low-income, elderly, and disabled homeowners; Maryland taxpayers; local tax collectors
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Special fund revenues for the Homeowner Protection Fund will increase starting in FY 2025 due to voluntary donations, though the total amount cannot be reliably estimated. Local government expenditures will increase to cover the costs of including the required program inserts in property tax bills, with estimated annual costs ranging from $3,200 to $70,000 per jurisdiction.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill's primary purpose is to fund the Homeowner Protection Program (HPP), which prevents homeowners from losing their homes to tax sale foreclosure. This aligns directly with the agency's mission to expand access to affordable housing and manage homelessness prevention programs.

The Homeowner Protection Program specifically targets elderly homeowners to prevent them from losing their homes. The agency is responsible for advocating for older adults and ensuring they can age with dignity in their own communities.

The bill's mandated property tax bill insert must describe how the program assists disabled homeowners in preventing foreclosure. The agency serves as a policy leader to ensure Marylanders with disabilities have equal access to stable housing.

The bill impacts the Homeowner Protection Fund, which receives a mandated annual appropriation of $750,000 through fiscal year 2025. DBM is responsible for formulating the state's annual budget and overseeing such funds.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the implementation of state initiatives like the Homeowner Protection Program and manages the state's budget, which includes mandated appropriations for the HPP Fund.

Tax sale foreclosures are legal proceedings managed within the judiciary. The success of the Homeowner Protection Program in diverting homeowners from foreclosure directly affects the volume of such cases handled by the court system.
The Treasurer is the principal custodian of the state’s financial assets, including the Homeowner Protection Fund, and oversees the management and protection of these public funds.

The Comptroller serves as the state’s chief financial officer and tax collector. While property taxes are local, the bill establishes state-level mechanisms for collecting voluntary donations that must be credited to a state special fund.

The Tax Court adjudicates tax controversies in the state. Programs and funding mechanisms related to tax sales and property tax relief are within the broader scope of their administrative review work.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for state agencies and would provide legal counsel regarding the implementation of tax sale regulations and the administration of the Homeowner Protection Fund.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires Maryland's charter counties (including Baltimore City) and certain code counties to include an assessment of fair housing in the housing element of their comprehensive plans. It establishes a duty for these counties to affirmatively further fair housing through their housing and urban development programs by taking meaningful actions to overcome patterns of segregation and foster inclusive communities.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Planning and Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
qa_results.stakeholders: Charter counties, Baltimore City, code counties, and Maryland residents, particularly those in need of low-income or workforce housing.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have no material fiscal impact on State or local governments. The Maryland Department of Planning and the Department of Housing and Community Development can provide technical assistance using existing resources. Local governments are expected to implement the requirements within existing resources as part of their standard comprehensive plan updates.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires the Department of Planning to provide technical assistance to charter counties in developing the housing element of their comprehensive plans to ensure they affirmatively further fair housing.

The bill requires the Department of Planning to consult with DHCD to provide technical assistance to counties. Furthermore, the bill's core mandate of 'affirmatively furthering fair housing' is defined within the Housing and Community Development Article administered by this agency.

The bill's focus on affirmatively furthering fair housing includes overcoming patterns of segregation and fostering inclusive communities free from barriers based on protected characteristics, which aligns directly with the Commission's mission to enforce anti-discrimination laws in housing.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates the state's 'Smart Growth' efforts, which include sound land-use policies and community revitalization. Integrating fair housing assessments into local comprehensive plans is a key component of sustainable and equitable growth management.

As the primary legal advisor to state agencies, the OAG may be required to provide counsel to MDP and DHCD regarding the implementation of these new statutory requirements and the legal definitions of fair housing obligations.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the operations of MDP and DHCD and spearheads statewide initiatives aimed at economic opportunity and community well-being, which this bill supports.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill renames the northern snakehead fish as the "Chesapeake Channa" for official state purposes. It updates the name of the commercial northern snakehead license and requires the Department of Natural Resources to adopt regulations and update all applicable published materials to reflect the new common name by January 1, 2025.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Commercial fishers, the seafood industry, and small businesses involved in fish harvesting and marketing.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The State and local fiscal impact is expected to be minimal, as the bill can be implemented with existing resources. There is a potential meaningful positive impact on small businesses in the commercial fishing and seafood industry if the name change improves marketing and harvesting efforts for the species.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DNR is the primary agency responsible for implementing the bill; it is explicitly tasked with adopting naming regulations and updating all licensing and published materials to reflect 'Chesapeake Channa' as the common name for the northern snakehead.

The MDA markets Maryland seafood through the 'Maryland’s Best' initiative; rebranding an invasive species to increase its commercial appeal and consumer demand directly aligns with the agency's mission to support the local seafood market.

Commerce supports small businesses and economic development; the rebranding of the species facilitates new commercial opportunities and job growth within the state's seafood harvesting and processing sectors.
MOTD promotes Maryland's culinary identity; the name change supports the agency's efforts to market local, sustainable seafood as a destination-based tourism asset and culinary attraction.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Agricultural & Resource-Based Industry Development Corp.
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MARBIDCO provides financial support to seafood businesses; rebranding the northern snakehead into a commercial product helps create new market segments and investment opportunities for rural entrepreneurs in the industry.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies tasked with the implementation of the rebranding and regulatory updates, and the Governor signed the legislation into law.

The MFCA operates the state's wholesale seafood distribution hub in Jessup; a successful rebranding that increases commercial volume of the species would directly impact the operations of their distribution infrastructure.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland State Highway Administration to update its pollinator habitat plan to include specific policies for native plant use, habitat maintenance along highways, and public education. It mandates that the agency track and apply for federal funding for pollinator habitats and provide annual public updates regarding the location and size of these areas.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Highway Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland motorists, bicyclists, pedestrians, community associations, elected officials, and pollinator species.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State Transportation Trust Fund expenditures are expected to increase by less than $50,000 annually due to costs for signage and outreach. There is a potential increase in federal fund revenues if the State Highway Administration receives federal grants. Local government finances are not affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically mandates the State Highway Administration (SHA) to update its pollinator habitat plan, include new policies for native plants and public education, and track/apply for federal funding related to these initiatives.

As the parent department of the State Highway Administration, MDOT is responsible for the overall planning and maintenance of the state's transportation network, which the bill directly impacts through its requirements for SHA.

The bill amends the Agriculture Article and requires the pollinator habitat plans to be developed in consultation with the Department of Agriculture. Additionally, the bill preserves the authority of MDA over weed control programs.
The bill modifies the specific section of law (2-1801 of the Agriculture Article) that mandates DNR to maintain and implement its own pollinator habitat plan, alongside SHA and MES.
MES is one of the three agencies (with SHA and DNR) originally required to establish and implement a pollinator habitat plan under the statute being amended.
The bill grants the Secretary of Health specific authority to determine when certain pesticides otherwise prohibited in pollinator habitats may be used to respond to public health threats.
DBM is relevant due to the bill's fiscal impact on the Transportation Trust Fund (TTF), as the agency oversees the state's central fiscal authority and budget formulation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires all qualified health plans (QHPs) sold through the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange to include pediatric dental benefits as an essential health benefit. It repeals a previous provision that allowed QHPs to exclude these benefits if a separate stand-alone dental plan was available and removes the Exchange's authority to require children to enroll in separate dental plans, as the coverage will now be integrated into the primary health plan.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Health Benefit Exchange
qa_results.stakeholders: Health insurance carriers, children and families purchasing insurance through the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange, and small businesses utilizing the SHOP Marketplace.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not substantively change State or local activities, operations, revenues, or expenditures. The Maryland Insurance Administration and the Department of Legislative Services determined that the bill will have minimal to no impact on small businesses, as carriers already voluntarily include pediatric dental benefits in their plans.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly modifies the Insurance Article governing the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange (MHBE). It changes the requirements for MHBE's certification of Qualified Health Plans (QHPs) by mandating the inclusion of pediatric dental benefits and repealing the Exchange's authority to waive these requirements if stand-alone dental plans are available.

This is a departmental bill requested by the Maryland Insurance Administration (MIA). The MIA is responsible for regulating the insurance carriers affected by this bill and must approve the premium rates and contract language for the Qualified Health Plans that are now required to include pediatric dental coverage.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange and the Maryland Insurance Administration. They would be responsible for ensuring the new regulatory requirements for dental coverage comply with state and federal laws, including the Affordable Care Act.

The Maryland Department of Health coordinates with the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange on health policy and manages programs like the Maryland Children's Health Program (MCHP). The bill's focus on essential pediatric dental benefits aligns with the Department's mission to promote child health and safety.

As a departmental bill signed into law by the Governor, the Governor's Office oversaw the introduction and signing of this legislation. The bill impacts the operations of the executive agencies (MHBE and MIA) that fall under the Governor's oversight.
The bill mandates pediatric dental coverage in health plans, which directly impacts the well-being and healthcare access for children in Maryland, a primary focus of this office's policy advocacy.

DBM is responsible for the state's fiscal accountability and was consulted in the preparation of the fiscal note for this bill. While the fiscal impact is minimal, the agency monitors the budgetary health of the implementing departments.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the Small, Minority, and Women-Owned Businesses Account (SMWOBA) within the Maryland Department of Commerce to allow eligible fund managers to provide financial assistance in the form of grants, specifically authorizing grants of up to $10,000 when issued in conjunction with a loan. It also updates the terminology and scope of financial assistance for businesses in clean energy industries and those located in areas under declared states of emergency or federal disaster.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce
qa_results.stakeholders: Small, minority, and women-owned businesses; veteran-owned businesses in the clean energy industry; and eligible fund managers including local economic development corporations and private firms.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not affect State revenues or expenditures as it only alters the allowed form of financial assistance from an existing account (SMWOBA). Local fiscal impacts may occur starting in FY 2025 as local economic development entities acting as fund managers utilize the new flexibility. This may increase local expenditures for grants and administration, while potentially reducing future revenues from loan repayments if funds are issued as grants rather than loans.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Commerce has primary authority over the Small, Minority, and Women-Owned Businesses Account (SMWOBA) and is responsible for making grants to eligible fund managers to provide financial assistance.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office oversees the socioeconomic procurement programs and connects entrepreneurs in these groups to state-funded opportunities, directly aligning with the bill's focus on capital access for these businesses.
The bill explicitly mandates that fund managers receiving grants be subject to audit by the Office of Legislative Audits and requires the Legislative Auditor to audit the utilization of funds.
The agency manages the Strategic Energy Investment Fund (SEIF), which provides a portion of the money for SMWOBA specifically to benefit businesses in the clean energy industry.
The Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the SMWOBA and issuing warrants to pay out money from the account based on Department of Commerce transmittals.
The Treasurer is mandated by the bill to invest and reinvest money in the Small, Minority, and Women-Owned Businesses Account.
The bill specifies that financial assistance derived from the Strategic Energy Investment Fund may be used to benefit veteran-owned businesses in the clean energy industry.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: SMWOBA receives a portion of gross video lottery terminal (VLT) proceeds, which are regulated and overseen by this agency.
Official declarations of emergency by the Governor trigger specific provisions allowing fund managers to provide or convert financial assistance into grants for businesses in affected areas.
As the state’s central fiscal authority, DBM oversees the special fund structures and revenue estimations associated with accounts like the SMWOBA.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill aligns Maryland health insurance law with federal requirements, including the No Surprises Act and the Affordable Care Act. It updates the definitions of emergency services and emergency medical conditions to include mental health and substance use disorders, prohibits carriers from denying emergency coverage based solely on diagnosis codes, and updates the effective dates of federal regulations that state laws must follow. The bill also authorizes the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange to adopt expanded open enrollment periods and modifies the criteria for special enrollment periods related to material errors in the Small Business Health Options Program (SHOP).
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Administration and the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange
qa_results.stakeholders: Health insurance carriers, insured individuals in Maryland, behavioral health providers, and small business employees participating in the SHOP Exchange.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect state or local finances. Any changes in state activities are expected to be handled within existing resources. The Maryland Insurance Administration determined that the bill has minimal or no economic impact on small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's primary insurance regulator and the requester of this bill, the agency is responsible for adopting regulations to ensure Maryland health insurance law remains in conformity with updated federal standards, including the No Surprises Act.

The bill grants the Exchange specific new authority to adopt expanded open enrollment periods and modifies the triggering events and material error definitions for special enrollment periods within the SHOP Exchange.

The bill amends the Health-General Article to update definitions of emergency medical conditions and services, specifically incorporating mental health and substance use disorders, which fall under the department's regulatory and public health purview.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for the Maryland Insurance Administration and the Department of Health, providing counsel on the implementation of these complex federal-state conformity requirements and representing the state in related appeals.

The OAH conducts formal proceedings for insurance-related disputes; changes to statutory definitions of emergency services and enrollment triggers directly impact the legal standards used by Administrative Law Judges to resolve these contested cases.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the departments implementing these regulatory changes and the Governor signed the legislation into law to align state health policy with federal consumer protection standards.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires local permit offices to include an estimated cost of construction when submitting copies of building permits to the State Department of Assessments and Taxation. This additional information is intended to help the department more accurately value property improvements for tax assessment purposes.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Department of Assessments and Taxation and local permit offices
qa_results.stakeholders: Local government permit offices, property owners, and the State Department of Assessments and Taxation
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no significant impact on State finances or operations. Local fiscal impact is expected to be minimal because many jurisdictions already provide construction cost estimates during the permitting process. While some jurisdictions may see a slight change in workload, the overall effect on local expenditures and revenues is not expected to be material.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that local permit offices include estimated construction costs when submitting building permits to the supervisor of assessments. This data is used to establish more accurate property valuations, which are the subject of the appeals heard by this Board.

As the highest level of administrative review for tax controversies, including real property assessments, the Tax Court will use the valuations refined by the additional construction cost data required by this bill to adjudicate tax disputes.

The Department of Planning is responsible for land use coordination and demographic research. More accurate and standardized data regarding building improvements and construction costs at the county level supports their economic forecasting and community planning efforts.

The State Department of Assessments and Taxation (SDAT) is an executive agency, and the Governor's Office oversees the operations of all state departments, including the implementation of departmental legislation like this bill.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for state agencies and would be responsible for providing counsel to the Department of Assessments and Taxation regarding the legal requirements for local jurisdictions to provide this data.

As the state's central fiscal authority, DBM oversees the performance and budgeting of the Department of Assessments and Taxation, which is the primary state entity affected by this administrative change.

While property taxes are primarily a local revenue source, the Comptroller serves as the state’s chief financial officer and fiscal watchdog, monitoring state-level economic forecasting and the overall fiscal health influenced by accurate property valuations.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates 'Smart Growth' efforts and land-use policies. Improved accuracy in tracking building improvements and construction costs provides better data for their sustainable development goals.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes consumer protections related to property insurance claims by extending the rescission period for public adjuster contracts from 3 to 10 business days (7 days for seniors), prohibiting solicitation by adjusters within 24 hours of a loss or between 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., and requiring adjusters to notify the Insurance Commissioner of contracts signed within 72 hours of a loss. It also expands the definition of insurance fraud to include contractors who offer to pay or compensate for an insured's deductible for any type of property damage repair, removing the previous limitation to weather-related damages.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commissioner and the Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland property owners, public adjusters, and home repair or remodeling contractors.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Insurance Administration can implement the bill's requirements using existing budgeted resources. There is no effect on local government revenues or expenditures. The bill is estimated to have minimal or no economic impact on small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Insurance Administration is the primary agency responsible for enforcing the Maryland Insurance Article. The bill directly regulates public adjusters, alters contract requirements, expands the definition of fraudulent insurance acts, and requires adjusters to report certain contracts directly to the Insurance Commissioner.

The Office of the Attorney General is the chief legal office of the state and is responsible for investigating and prosecuting complex white-collar crimes and insurance fraud. The bill expands the definition of 'fraudulent insurance acts,' which falls under their enforcement and consumer protection purview.

The bill includes specific consumer protection provisions for individuals aged 65 and older, specifically establishing a unique contract rescission period for this demographic. This is relevant to the department's mandate to advocate for and protect older Marylanders from financial exploitation.

The bill expands the definition of fraudulent insurance acts related to contractors offering home repair or remodeling services. The Department of Labor regulates and licenses professional trades and contractors through various boards, such as the Maryland Home Improvement Commission.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City from requiring new motor vehicle off-street parking for developments that include residential use if the development is located within a 0.25-mile radius of a present or planned MARC, Baltimore MTA Light Rail, Red Line, or Metro station.
qa_results.responsible_party: Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City
qa_results.stakeholders: Residential developers in Baltimore City, residents of Baltimore City near mass transit stations, and small businesses involved in real estate development.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not directly affect State or local government finances. It may have a meaningful fiscal impact on small businesses that develop residential properties near transit stations in Baltimore City by reducing the costs associated with mandated off-street parking.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill stimulates private investment and economic development in Baltimore City by reducing the cost of residential and mixed-use development near transit hubs.

The bill directly impacts the cost and feasibility of residential development in urban areas. DHCD is responsible for expanding affordable housing and neighborhood revitalization, which is often hindered by high parking construction costs.
As the agency responsible for coordinating land use and sustainable growth, the bill aligns with 'smart growth' strategies by encouraging transit-oriented development and reducing urban sprawl.
The bill defines and centers its policy around state-managed transportation assets, including MARC, Light Rail, Metro, and the planned Red Line, which are managed by MDOT.

The Governor oversees all state departments and signs legislation. This bill specifically facilitates the implementation of the Red Line project, a major administration priority for economic opportunity and public safety.

MEDCO often issues revenue bonds for and develops real estate projects; the elimination of parking mandates affects the financial modeling and infrastructure planning for projects they may facilitate in Baltimore.

This team works on data-driven solutions for economic mobility and poverty reduction. Reducing car-dependency requirements near transit is a core component of improving economic mobility for urban residents.
The MTA operates the MARC, Light Rail, and Metro systems specifically cited in the bill. The policy aims to increase transit ridership by densifying residential use around their stations.
As Maryland's preeminent public urban research university located in Baltimore, the university is impacted by urban planning, housing availability, and transit access for its diverse student body.
The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies and the General Assembly regarding the legality and implementation of land-use laws that preempt local authority.

This multi-agency initiative focuses on sustainable development and reducing car dependency. The bill's prohibition on parking mandates near transit is a direct application of Smart Growth principles.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Homecare Worker Rights Act of 2024 prohibits the Maryland Department of Health from reimbursing residential service agencies for personal assistance services unless those services are performed by workers classified as employees rather than independent contractors.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Residential service agencies, personal care aides (homecare workers), and Medicaid participants receiving community long-term services and supports.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have no direct impact on Medicaid revenues or expenditures assuming agencies transition to an all-employee model by the implementation date. If agencies do not comply, the Maryland Department of Health may incur indeterminate administrative costs to disenroll and potentially re-enroll providers. Small business residential service agencies will face increased costs to convert independent contractors to employee status.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary implementing agency, the Maryland Department of Health (MDH) is directly responsible for enforcing this bill. The bill limits MDH's ability to reimburse residential service agencies (RSAs) for personal assistance services to only those provided by employees. The Office of Health Care Quality within MDH also licenses these agencies.

The bill addresses worker misclassification, a core regulatory area for the Department of Labor. Shifting workers from independent contractors to employees triggers compliance with labor standards, unemployment insurance, and occupational safety (MOSH) requirements managed by this agency.

The OAG is specifically mentioned in the fiscal note as being required to produce and update guidance on the application of employee protection laws to home care workers. The agency also serves as the legal advisor for MDH regarding the enforcement of reimbursement and licensing rules.

By requiring home care workers to be classified as employees rather than independent contractors, the bill directly impacts the jurisdiction of the Commission. Employees are entitled to workers' compensation benefits for workplace injuries, whereas independent contractors are generally not.

The bill's mandate that home care workers be employees means RSAs must obtain workers' compensation insurance. As the state's 'insurer of last resort,' this agency (Chesapeake Employers’ Insurance Company) will likely see a significant increase in policy applications and claims management for this sector.

RSAs provide essential personal assistance services to older adults. Changes in the labor and reimbursement model for these agencies directly affect the provider network that the Department of Aging relies on to support independent living for Maryland's senior population.

Personal assistance services are vital for many individuals with disabilities to maintain community-based living. The Department of Disabilities is interested in the stability and compliance of the RSA workforce to ensure equal access and independence for its constituents.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The fiscal note indicates that many RSAs are small businesses that will incur meaningful costs to transition workers to an employee model. This office monitors and supports small and minority-owned businesses that may be economically impacted by the regulatory change.

Worker misclassification often leads to significant tax consequences. The shift from contractor to employee status involves changes in payroll tax collection and withholding, which falls under the Comptroller's responsibility as the state's tax collector.

The transition of workers to employee status requires agencies to obtain various forms of insurance, including workers' compensation and potentially group health coverage, which are regulated by the MIA to ensure compliance and consumer protection.

The OAH may be required to adjudicate disputes if the Department of Health disenrolled RSAs for failing to comply with the employee-only reimbursement requirement, as providers have the right to challenge such administrative decisions.

OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits of executive agencies. They would likely audit the Department of Health's Medicaid reimbursement processes to ensure public funds are only being paid to RSAs compliant with the bill's employee classification mandate.

As the chief executive agency, the Governor's Office oversaw the signing of this legislation (Homecare Worker Rights Act) and its alignment with statewide initiatives focused on public safety and economic opportunity for the workforce.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill aligns Maryland law with federal law by repealing the tobacco sales exception for active-duty military members under age 21, making 21 the uniform minimum age for all tobacco and electronic smoking device purchases. It also authorizes the Maryland Department of Health to reallocate unspent cancer grant funds between counties, transfers the payment responsibility for child abuse emergency medical treatments to the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy, and consolidates child abuse reporting duties under the State Council on Child Abuse and Neglect.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
qa_results.stakeholders: Active-duty military members aged 18 to 20, tobacco and electronic smoking device retailers, local health departments, victims of child abuse and neglect, and medical providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State operations or finances. Local governments may be impacted by the reallocation of projected unspent grant funds for cancer prevention and treatment programs between counties, which may reduce the total amount of funds that revert to the Cigarette Restitution Fund at the end of the fiscal year.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MDH is a primary agency for this bill; it is authorized to reallocate cancer grant funding between counties, is relieved of the duty to pay for child abuse medical treatment, and must collaborate on tobacco enforcement strategies.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP is a primary agency for this bill as it takes over responsibility from MDH as the payor of last resort for emergency medical treatment charges in cases of child abuse and neglect.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly alters the duties and reporting requirements of the State Council on Child Abuse and Neglect (SCCAN), which falls under this category of state entities.
The Comptroller is explicitly required to collaborate and consult with the Department of Health to develop ongoing strategies for the enforcement of tobacco distribution laws.
The bill modifies penalties and defenses for tobacco-related violations, which impacts the judicial system's processing of criminal misdemeanors and civil infractions.
As the principal executive agency overseeing GOCPP and receiving annual reports from the State Council on Child Abuse and Neglect, the Governor's Office has administrative and oversight relevance.

The bill identifies local law enforcement as collaborators in developing tobacco enforcement strategies; as the primary statewide law enforcement agency, the State Police are relevant to these efforts.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes counties and municipalities to designate specific local highways where individuals may operate golf carts without registration. It establishes uniform statewide conditions for golf cart operation, including a maximum speed limit of 30 miles per hour (with an exception for 35 miles per hour in Golden Beach Patuxent Knolls), requirements for driver's licenses, lighting standards for night use, and limits on the number of occupants. The bill repeals several existing site-specific golf cart authorizations in favor of this general local authority.
qa_results.responsible_party: Local governing bodies (counties and municipalities) and the Maryland Department of Transportation
qa_results.stakeholders: Golf cart owners and operators, licensed drivers, residents of Maryland counties and municipalities, and local government officials.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect State or local finances or operations. No significant changes to revenues or expenditures are anticipated.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the 'Administration' cited throughout the Maryland Vehicle Law, the MVA is directly responsible for administering the registration exemptions created by this bill and establishing the lighting and safety device requirements for legal golf cart operation.

MDOT is the parent agency for the Motor Vehicle Administration and oversees the State’s comprehensive multi-modal transportation network; the bill makes significant changes to the Maryland Transportation Article regarding vehicle registration and highway use.

MSP is responsible for enforcing motor vehicle laws and ensuring highway safety; their officers must enforce the new operational standards, speed limits, and lighting requirements for golf carts on public roadways.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the Maryland Department of Transportation and the MVA, providing counsel on the interpretation and implementation of the revised transportation statutes.

The Judiciary is responsible for adjudicating citations related to the Maryland Vehicle Law; violations of the bill's requirements for driver licensing and golf cart operation will be processed through the court system.

The bill impacts several rural communities (e.g., Smith Island, Crisfield) by repealing their specific local authorizations and shifting authority to the local governing bodies, which aligns with the Council's mission to advocate for rural transportation and governance interests.

The Governor's Office oversees the execution of state laws and the operations of MDOT and the MVA; the Governor signed this legislation which shifts the policy for golf cart regulation from state-level local laws to general local authority.

DBM is the central fiscal authority that coordinates the fiscal note process and ensures that the implementation of the new registration exemptions does not negatively impact state revenue or personnel resources.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows for the sale, barter, or exchange of legally acquired mounted specimens of game birds (excluding migratory birds) or game mammals that belong to a deceased person's estate when that estate is being liquidated or distributed.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Heirs, legatees, and personal representatives of deceased individuals' estates; auctioneers; and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State finances or revenues. There is no impact on local government finances. Small businesses, specifically auctioneers, may see a minimal positive impact from being allowed to sell taxidermy mounts on behalf of estates.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for the management of the state's living resources and the enforcement of the Natural Resources Article, DNR requested this bill to create a specific exception for the sale of wildlife specimens from liquidated estates.

The Register of Wills oversees the administrative probate of decedents' estates and the liquidation of personal property; this bill directly affects the legality of selling specific assets (taxidermy) during that process.

The AOC supports the state's judicial system, including the probate processes handled by the courts; the fiscal note identifies the judiciary as a source of information regarding the bill's impact on estate-related legal procedures.

The OAG provides legal counsel to the Department of Natural Resources and would be involved in interpreting these amendments and ensuring that enforcement actions by the Natural Resources Police align with the new exception.
The Comptroller was consulted as a source of information for the fiscal note to assess potential tax or revenue implications resulting from the authorized sale of personal property from estates.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the Maryland Pediatric Cancer Fund by refocusing its use specifically on pediatric cancer research and administrative expenses, removing the previous authorization for prevention and treatment. It also establishes the Pediatric Cancer Research Commission to oversee the competitive grant award process, develop research criteria, and conduct progress reviews of grant recipients.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Pediatric Cancer Research Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Pediatric cancer patients, survivors, caregivers, medical researchers, physicians, hospitals, and educational institutions in Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures increase by $52,900 in FY 2025 to hire a part-time physician program manager to support the commission, with costs rising to approximately $69,000 by FY 2029. Administrative and promotional expenses are capped at 5% of the fund. The fund currently retains a $5,000,000 balance from a prior appropriation. There is no impact on local government revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) is the primary agency responsible for administering the Maryland Pediatric Cancer Fund and staffing the newly created Pediatric Cancer Research Commission. The Secretary of Health serves on the Commission and is tasked with adopting regulations for the grant program.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Pediatric Cancer Research Commission, a specialized body of experts and stakeholders tasked with overseeing the evaluation and award of competitive grants for pediatric cancer research.

The Governor is responsible for appointing the majority of the members of the Pediatric Cancer Research Commission and retains the authority to remove members for cause. The Governor also approved the legislation.

As the agency responsible for recruiting and vetting candidates for state boards and commissions, the Office of Appointments will manage the application and selection process for the newly created Pediatric Cancer Research Commission.

The bill explicitly requires each member of the Pediatric Cancer Research Commission to disclose financial interests or employment with potential grant applicants to the State Ethics Commission to prevent conflicts of interest.

The bill mandates that the Commission include four scientists and three physicians from the University of Maryland with expertise in pediatric cancer, directly involving the University System's faculty and clinical staff in state policy and grant oversight.

The fiscal note indicates a need for new personnel (a part-time physician program manager) and administrative spending. DBM oversees the state personnel system and the allocation of funds within the state budget to support these new requirements.
As the custodian of state funds, the Treasurer's Office is responsible for the management and protection of the Maryland Pediatric Cancer Fund's assets.

The Office of Legislative Audits is responsible for auditing the Maryland Department of Health and its special funds. The modification of the Pediatric Cancer Fund and the creation of a new Commission will fall under their regular fiscal and compliance oversight.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes paid parental bereavement leave for State employees in the Executive, Judicial, and Legislative branches, including temporary employees and staff at public institutions of higher education. Employees may use up to 10 days of paid leave within 60 days of the death of a child aged 6 months to under 27 years, and up to 60 days of paid leave within 60 days of a stillbirth or the death of an infant under 6 months of age. Appointing authorities are prohibited from requiring employees to use other types of accrued paid leave before utilizing parental bereavement leave.
qa_results.responsible_party: Secretary of Budget and Management
qa_results.stakeholders: State employees in the Executive, Judicial, and Legislative branches, including temporary employees and employees of public institutions of higher education.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect State operations or finances, as regular employee salaries are already budgeted. Minimal expenditure increases may occur in limited circumstances to provide overtime coverage for employees on leave. It is estimated that fewer than 90 State employees will be eligible for this leave annually. Any costs associated with training human resources staff or configuring personnel systems are expected to be handled with existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Secretary of Budget and Management is explicitly required by the bill to adopt regulations governing the new parental bereavement leave policy for the state personnel management system.

The bill explicitly applies to all employees in the Judicial Branch, and the Administrative Office of the Courts is responsible for managing the personnel and budgetary infrastructure for the judiciary.
As a large state unit with an independent personnel system, MDOT is explicitly subject to the bill and will need to update its internal leave policies and system configurations.
The bill explicitly applies to all employees of public institutions of higher education; USM is the primary governing body for the state's public university system.
Morgan State University is a public institution of higher education specifically covered under the bill's provisions for parental bereavement leave.
Saint Mary's College of Maryland is a public institution of higher education specifically covered under the bill's provisions for parental bereavement leave.
The Comptroller manages the state's central payroll for over 100,000 employees and will be responsible for configuring payroll systems to accommodate the new paid leave category.
PERB oversees collective bargaining and labor relations for state and higher education employees, who are the primary subjects of this new leave mandate.
As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the departments implementing this law and the Governor signed the bill into law.
The OAG acts as the legal advisor to the state agencies tasked with implementing and regulating the new leave requirements.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows residential property to be transferred from a decedent's estate to an heir or legatee without first paying all outstanding property taxes, provided the recipient enters into an installment payment plan. It requires the State Tax Sale Ombudsman to contract with a vendor to operate an installment payment program for homeowners to pay taxes in advance, currently, or in arrears. Additionally, the bill authorizes local governments to establish their own installment payment programs for residential property taxes in arrears.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Tax Sale Ombudsman (State Department of Assessments and Taxation)
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland homeowners, heirs and legatees of residential property, local tax collectors, and the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by at least $67,300 in FY 2025 for a program manager to oversee the new installment program, with costs rising to approximately $89,900 by FY 2029. While the bill requires the vendor contract to be funded by participant fees, additional state support may be needed. Local revenues are not significantly impacted, though local governments may incur administrative costs and see variations in interest or penalty revenue if they choose to implement optional local payment programs.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly involves the Clerks of the Circuit Court, whom the Administrative Office of the Courts supports. Clerks are responsible for recording instruments that effect a change in ownership, and the bill requires heirs or legatees to provide affidavits of payment plans to the Clerks to facilitate these recordings.

The bill specifically addresses the transfer of residential real property from the estate of a decedent to an heir or legatee. The Register of Wills oversees the administrative probate of such estates and is identified as a source of information regarding the impact of these changes on estate administration.

The fiscal note indicates a direct increase in general fund expenditures and the need for a new Program Manager position to oversee the installment payment program and vendor contract. DBM is responsible for managing state personnel systems and the annual operating budget.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the primary legal advisor for state agencies and will likely be involved in drafting or reviewing the contract between the State Tax Sale Ombudsman and the third-party vendor required by the bill.

The bill requires the State Tax Sale Ombudsman to contract with a vendor to operate a statewide installment payment program. Such a contract may require review and approval by the Board of Public Works depending on the procurement threshold and fiscal impact.

The Maryland Tax Court is the highest level of administrative review for tax controversies, including real property tax disputes. Legal challenges regarding the implementation or terms of the new payment plans could eventually be adjudicated here.

PTAAB hears appeals related to property tax assessments and tax credit programs. The bill's changes to payment requirements and installment plans for residential property taxes are relevant to the broader property tax ecosystem in which the Board operates.

OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits of executive agencies. It will be responsible for auditing the financial controls and vendor management of the new installment payment program operated by the State Tax Sale Ombudsman.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the Department of Assessments and Taxation (where the Ombudsman resides) and approved this legislation to advance state priorities related to housing stability and tax collection reform.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill establishes the Maryland Commission on Veterans and Military Families to study and develop a statewide strategic plan to make Maryland the best state for veterans and military families. The Commission is required to identify key performance indicators to assess the quality of life for these groups and must submit a report with legislative and budgetary recommendations by December 1, 2024.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Veterans Affairs
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland veterans, military families, military spouses, and organizations advocating on behalf of veterans and military members.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $74,200 in FY 2025 only for contractual support to staff the commission and complete the required report. Member expense reimbursements are expected to be minimal and absorbable within existing resources. The bill has no effect on revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office is responsible for appointing several members to the newly established Commission and receives the Commission's final report and strategic recommendations.
The bill has a fiscal impact requiring $74,200 for a contractual position, which falls under DBM's oversight of state personnel and the annual operating budget.

The bill mandates that the Commission consult with the Office of Military and Federal Affairs and the Maryland Military Installation Council, both of which are units within the Department of Commerce.
The Commission's study includes healthcare quality of life for veterans, and the bill specifically requires a member with healthcare expertise, aligning with the department's public health mission.

The Commission's mission to improve veterans' lives includes workforce development, and the bill requires a member with specific expertise in that field, which is a core function of the Department of Labor.
This agency is the primary implementing body; its Secretary chairs the Commission, and the department is responsible for providing staffing and administrative support.
The Adjutant General (or their designee) is a statutory member of the Commission and advises on matters relating to the National Guard and state defense.
The Commission includes the chair of the Student Veterans commission, and veteran education/workforce alignment is a key part of the strategic plan overseen by MHEC.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill establishes a new executive commission within the state government to study and recommend policy changes for veterans and military families.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the definition of disability for the provision of rehabilitation services in Maryland to align with federal law. It changes the definition to mean any physical or mental impairment that constitutes or results in a substantial impediment to employment or independent living, replacing older terminology.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education, Division of Rehabilitation Services (DORS)
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals with physical or mental disabilities seeking vocational rehabilitation and independent living services in Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no state or local fiscal impact. The bill alters definitions to closely conform to federal rehabilitation acts and is not expected to affect governmental operations or finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) houses the Division of Rehabilitation Services (DORS), which is the primary state entity responsible for administering the rehabilitation programs impacted by this definition change. The bill specifically amends the Education Article which governs MSDE operations.

As the state's cabinet-level agency responsible for coordinating cross-disability policy, this agency is highly relevant to any legislative change that alters the legal definition of 'disability' regarding employment and independent living services.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Education and the state government, ensuring that statutory changes to definitions for state services are legally sound and properly aligned with federal laws such as the rehabilitation acts of the U.S. Congress.

The GWDB is responsible for removing barriers to employment and overseeing the state's workforce system; the bill's updated definition directly relates to identifying individuals with impediments to employment who are eligible for vocational rehabilitation services.

The Department of Labor administers workforce development and apprenticeship programs; aligning the definition of disability for rehabilitation services affects how these individuals are integrated into the broader workforce system and job training initiatives.

As the chief executive agency, the Governor's Office signed the bill into law and oversees the Department of Education, ensuring that executive agencies align their definitions and services with federal standards to improve economic opportunity for residents.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the timeframe for investigating and issuing a written decision regarding complaints of harassment or discrimination filed by Maryland State Executive Branch employees or applicants. It increases the standard investigation and decision period from 30 days to 60 days and permits an additional 30-day extension if the complainant provides written authorization.
qa_results.responsible_party: Equal employment officers, fair practices officers, and heads of principal units within the Executive Branch, and the Secretary of Budget and Management.
qa_results.stakeholders: Executive Branch employees and applicants for employment in the State of Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact as the changes are procedural in nature. The Department of Budget and Management notes that many equal employment officers already require extensions for these investigations, and the bill aligns the statutory timeframe with current administrative needs without affecting governmental finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly amends the State Personnel and Pensions Article which DBM is responsible for administering. DBM is the central personnel authority for the Executive Branch and manages the statewide personnel system, including the oversight of the complaint and appeals process modified by this legislation.

The bill concerns the investigation of harassment and discrimination complaints. MCCR is the primary agency responsible for enforcing anti-discrimination laws in Maryland and was consulted for its perspective on these procedural changes.

As a principal unit with a large workforce and its own Equal Employment Officers, MDOT is directly impacted by the extension of timeframes for investigating personnel complaints. It was also identified as an information source for the fiscal note.

USM is a major state employer that manages a significant portion of Maryland's public workforce. The procedural changes regarding the investigation of harassment and discrimination complaints directly affect its internal personnel operations.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies (principal units) regarding personnel actions and ensures that investigations and written decisions meet legal standards. They represent agencies in appeals and related litigation.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees all state departments (principal units) whose personnel procedures are altered by this bill. The Governor also signed this legislation into law.

The AOC was consulted as an information source for this bill. While the bill primarily targets the Executive Branch, the Judiciary monitors such personnel law changes to ensure consistency in state employment protections or to provide input on legal frameworks.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the eligibility for an optional local property tax credit for disabled veterans to include individuals with a nonpermanent service-connected disability of 100%. It provides for a property tax credit of 50% for veterans with a disability rating of 75% to 100% (provided they do not already receive a full property tax exemption) and a 25% credit for those with a disability rating of 50% to 74%. Local governments are authorized to adopt these changes or maintain existing eligibility criteria, and eligibility remains subject to an income cap of $100,000.
qa_results.responsible_party: Governing bodies of Maryland counties and municipal corporations, including the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City
qa_results.stakeholders: Disabled veterans with service-connected disabilities of at least 50%, surviving spouses of such veterans, and local Maryland municipal and county governments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State revenues and expenditures are not affected. Local property tax revenues may decrease beginning in fiscal 2025 if local jurisdictions choose to grant the expanded credit.
