qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the calculation and modification of child support for incarcerated parents. It specifies that incarceration may be considered a material change of circumstance for modifying support, prevents incarcerated parents from being deemed "voluntarily impoverished," and prohibits the imputation of potential income to them. It also removes the requirement that an obligor be sentenced to at least 180 days for child support arrearages to stop accruing during incarceration.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Incarcerated parents (obligors), custodial parents (obligees), and the Department of Human Services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $124,800 in FY 2025 for one-time computer programming costs to update the Department of Human Services' systems. The bill helps protect federal funding by ensuring Maryland law complies with federal child support enforcement requirements. There is no material impact on local government operations or finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill was requested by the Department of Human Services (DHS). The DHS Child Support Administration is responsible for administering child support services and adjusting payment accounts for incarcerated obligors as described in the legislation. The fiscal note also identifies $124,800 in one-time computer programming costs for DHS.

The bill alters statutory standards used by the Judiciary to modify child support awards, specifically defining when incarceration constitutes a material change of circumstance and prohibiting courts from considering incarcerated parents as 'voluntarily impoverished' or imputing potential income to them.

The OAG serves as the primary legal representative for state agencies, including the Department of Human Services and its Child Support Administration, and would be involved in the legal interpretation and litigation of modified child support orders under this new framework.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts individuals in the custody of the state's adult correctional system managed by DPSCS. The agency's records regarding incarceration and work release status are the primary triggers for the suspension of child support accruals and the modification of orders.

DBM oversees state personnel and fiscal authority. The fiscal note indicates a one-time general fund expenditure of $124,800 to update state computer systems, which falls under DBM's broader budgetary oversight.
The Governor signed this bill into law and the office oversees the executive agencies (DHS and DPSCS) responsible for the target population and the administration of the support system.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill codifies the Maryland Zero Emission Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Council (ZEEVIC) into the state's Transportation Article and modifies its membership. The legislation expands the Council to include the Secretary of General Services, representatives from heavy-duty plug-in electric vehicle manufacturers, and the automotive dismantling and recycling industry. It tasks the Council with developing action plans, statewide standards, and infrastructure recommendations to integrate zero-emission vehicles into Maryland's transportation network, with a final report due in 2026.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation
qa_results.stakeholders: State and local government agencies, electric vehicle and infrastructure manufacturers, electric utilities, automotive dismantlers and recyclers, environmental advocacy groups, electrical workers, and electric vehicle drivers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact. Altering the representation of the Council and codifying its existence does not affect governmental finances or state expenditures beyond standard staff support provided by existing agencies. No revenues or additional expenditures are anticipated.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MDOT is the primary agency responsible for providing staff support to the Council and the Secretary of Transportation (or designee) is a mandated member of the Council.
The Director of the MEA is a mandated member of the Council, and the agency is specifically tasked with assisting MDOT in providing staff support to the Council.
The Executive Director of the Technical Staff of the PSC is a mandated member, and the commission is specifically required to assist MDOT in providing staff support to the Council.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill codifies and defines the membership and duties of the Maryland Zero Emission Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Council, which is a specialized advisory body within the executive branch.
The Governor is responsible for appointing numerous members to the Council (including industry and public representatives) and designating the Chair or Co-Chairs.
The Secretary of the Environment (or designee) is a mandated member of the Council, reflecting the bill's focus on zero-emission vehicles and climate policy.
The Secretary of General Services (or designee) is added as a mandated member of the Council, likely due to the agency's role in managing state-owned facilities and vehicle fleets.
The Secretary of Planning (or designee) is a mandated member of the Council, as the placement of EV infrastructure directly impacts state land use and development policies.
The Secretary of Commerce (or designee) is a mandated member, as the Council's work involves private sector investment and attracting economic opportunities in the EV industry.
The People's Counsel (or designee) is a mandated member of the Council, representing the interests of residential utility consumers as infrastructure standards are developed.
This office would be responsible for recruiting and vetting the various industry and public stakeholders that the Governor must appoint to the Council.

The Council must include a representative of an institution of higher education with expertise in energy, transportation, or the environment, which would typically be sourced from the state's public university system.
The Council includes a representative of electrical workers, and its mission involves workforce development goals related to the installation of EV charging infrastructure.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows individuals to claim a nonrefundable State income tax credit of up to $75 for qualified expenses incurred to butcher and process an antlerless deer for human consumption, provided the deer is harvested in compliance with State laws and donated to a 501(c)(3) venison donation program. The total credit is generally limited to $300 per tax year unless the deer were harvested under a deer management permit.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Hunters, 501(c)(3) charitable organizations operating venison donation programs, and food-insecure Maryland residents.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues are estimated to decrease by $175,000 annually from fiscal 2025 through 2029 due to the tax credits claimed. The Comptroller's Office can implement the bill's requirements using existing resources. There is no fiscal impact on local governments.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes a new state income tax credit for venison donation, which the Comptroller must administer. Furthermore, the bill explicitly requires venison donation programs to report donor names, addresses, and donation counts directly to the Comptroller by January 31 each year.

The bill incentivizes the harvesting of antlerless deer, a primary wildlife management function of the DNR. The tax credit is contingent upon compliance with state hunting laws and regulations overseen by DNR, which also manages the separate Venison Donation Grant Program mentioned in the fiscal note.

The MDA is involved in food supply oversight and was identified as a key information source for the fiscal note. The bill's intersection with food processing and resource-based donations affects MDA's regulatory and marketing interests.

The MDH oversees food safety and public health services. Since the bill concerns the processing and donation of venison for human consumption, it involves health standards and was listed as a consulted agency in the fiscal analysis.

The bill references and incorporates civil liability protections for food donors under Section 5–634 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article. The Judiciary was consulted for the fiscal note regarding the legal implications of these provisions.
DBM is responsible for state revenue estimation and budget formulation. The bill is projected to decrease general fund revenues by $175,000 annually, which DBM must account for in fiscal planning.
The MFCA manages food distribution infrastructure and was identified as a stakeholder in the fiscal note process regarding the logistics and reporting of food donations.
As the chief executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing the legislation and overseeing the agencies (Comptroller, DNR, MDH) tasked with its implementation and enforcement.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires that at least 40% of the funding provided under the Comprehensive Flood Management Grant Program be used for projects located in or directly benefiting underserved or overburdened communities beginning in fiscal year 2026. It also authorizes the Governor to include an appropriation of up to $20,000,000 in the annual State budget for the program starting in fiscal year 2026.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
qa_results.stakeholders: Local government subdivisions, residents of underserved or overburdened communities, and the Maryland Department of Planning.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill authorizes, but does not mandate, an annual appropriation of up to $20,000,000 for the Comprehensive Flood Management Grant Program starting in fiscal 2026. Current state capital plans already include $10,000,000 annually for the program through fiscal 2029. While overall state finances are not directly affected, local governments will experience a shift in the allocation of grants to prioritize underserved and overburdened communities. If the maximum authorized funding of $20,000,000 is provided, the Maryland Department of the Environment may require approximately $270,261 in fiscal 2026 for additional administrative staff.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comprehensive Flood Management Grant Program is established and managed within this department. MDE is responsible for awarding grants, adopting necessary regulations, and ensuring that at least 40% of the program's funding is allocated to projects benefiting underserved or overburdened communities.

The bill explicitly requires that the department’s use of proceeds from state debt and the awarding of grants for watershed studies, capital projects, and property acquisitions be 'subject to the approval of the Board of Public Works.'

Grant applications must be reviewed by the State Clearinghouse of the Department of Planning. Furthermore, MDE must consult with MDP on program regulations and prioritize projects in historic districts designated by the Maryland Historical Trust, which is an entity within MDP.

The bill requires that local response plans for automated flood warning projects be reviewed and approved by the Maryland Department of Emergency Management to ensure coordination with emergency authorities.

The bill authorizes the Governor to include a specific appropriation for the grant program in the annual State budget. Additionally, the Governor chairs the Board of Public Works, which must approve all grant awards under the program.

DBM is responsible for formulating and overseeing the annual State budget. The bill authorizes an appropriation of up to $20 million annually for the grant program, which DBM would manage as part of the executive budget process.
As a member of the Board of Public Works, the Comptroller is responsible for reviewing and approving the significant state expenditures and grants authorized under this program.

The State Treasurer sits on the Board of Public Works, which approves the grants. Additionally, the Treasurer's Office manages the general obligation bonds used to fund the capital portions of the grant program.

The grant program allows for the acquisition of flood-damaged owner-occupied dwellings, which overlaps with the department's mission of ensuring safe, decent, and sustainable housing and community revitalization.

The bill aligns with this multi-agency initiative's goals of environmental stewardship and sustainable community growth by focusing flood mitigation efforts and watershed restoration in vulnerable areas.

As the chief legal advisor for the state, the OAG would review and approve for legal sufficiency the regulations that the Department of the Environment is required to adopt to administer the grant program.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases funding for tax assistance services for low-income Marylanders by requiring an annual $500,000 distribution from unclaimed property funds to the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund and increasing the mandated annual budget appropriation for the CASH Campaign of Maryland to $800,000 starting in fiscal year 2026. It also requires the CASH Campaign to provide grants for on-demand or mobile tax clinics serving seniors, rural areas, and under-resourced communities.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Maryland Comptroller and the Governor
qa_results.stakeholders: Low-income Maryland residents, senior populations, rural communities, under-resourced communities, New American populations, the CASH Campaign of Maryland, the University of Maryland School of Law, the University of Baltimore School of Law, and the Maryland Volunteer Lawyers Service
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues decrease by $500,000 annually beginning in FY 2025 as funds are diverted from the Unclaimed Property Fund to the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund. General fund expenditures increase by $300,000 annually beginning in FY 2026 to fulfill the increased mandate for the CASH Campaign. Higher education revenues and expenditures increase by approximately $333,300 annually reflecting the share of grants distributed to state law schools. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that the Governor include specific annual appropriations in the State budget for the CASH Campaign of Maryland and provides for discretionary appropriations to the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund.
The Comptroller is the primary administrator of the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund and is responsible for distributing abandoned property funds to it as mandated by the bill.
The bill requires the State Treasurer to hold the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund separately and manages the investment of the money within that fund.
The bill mandates funding for tax clinics that specifically serve senior populations, aligning with the department's mission to provide essential resources and advocacy for older adults.
As the agency responsible for formulating and overseeing the state budget, DBM must ensure the bill's mandated appropriations for the CASH Campaign and the tax clinics fund are properly allocated.
The bill provides tax assistance and access to credits for low-income residents, which is the primary demographic served by DHS through various economic assistance and social service programs.

The bill mandates that two-thirds of the grant funding from the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund be distributed to the law schools at the University of Maryland and the University of Baltimore, both of which are USM institutions.
The bill mandates funding for mobile tax clinics to serve rural communities, directly supporting the Council's mission to improve the quality of life and access to services in rural counties.
By enhancing access to tax credits for low-income families, the bill supports the office's mission to eliminate childhood poverty and improve the economic well-being of Maryland families.

The bill's focus on providing tax assistance to 'new American populations' through mobile clinics aligns with GOCI's role in coordinating outreach and advocacy for the state's diverse constituent groups.

The bill's objectives of reducing poverty and increasing economic mobility for low-income residents via tax assistance align with the Innovation Team's core mission to address childhood poverty and modernize services.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Stop Scam Tax Preparers Act requires the State Board of Individual Tax Preparers to establish and publish a code of ethics and rules of professional conduct by 2026. It mandates communication between the Board and the Comptroller's Office regarding disciplinary actions and electronic filing bans. The bill also expands the enforcement authority of the Field Enforcement Bureau to include tax preparation laws and creates a misdemeanor for preparing taxes without proper registration, with fines directed to the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Individual Tax Preparers and the Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Individual tax preparers, the Maryland Comptroller's Office, the State Board of Individual Tax Preparers, and low-income taxpayers who benefit from tax clinics.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $32,300 in FY 2025 for one-time programming changes by the Judiciary. Revenues for the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund (TCLIM) will see a minimal increase from new fines of up to $5,000 per violation for unregistered tax preparation. The Comptroller's Office and Department of Labor can implement the bill's requirements using existing resources. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Labor houses the State Board of Individual Tax Preparers, which is the primary entity responsible for adopting the new code of ethics, rules of professional conduct, and managing the registration and investigation of tax preparers.

The bill grants peace officer powers to the Comptroller's Field Enforcement Bureau for tax preparation law enforcement and requires the Comptroller to coordinate with the Board regarding electronic filing prohibitions and notifications of violations.

The fiscal note identifies specific programming costs for the Judiciary to implement the new misdemeanor offense and penalties. The agency also supports the court system where these cases will be prosecuted.

The bill directs fines collected from violations into the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund, which provides grants to the University of Maryland School of Law and the University of Baltimore School of Law, both of which are USM institutions.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Board and the Comptroller, and would be responsible for representing the state in legal matters related to the enforcement and disciplinary actions mandated by the bill.
As the independent reviewer for tax controversies, the Tax Court may handle appeals or disputes resulting from the Comptroller's enforcement actions or tax-related penalties established by this bill.

DBM is relevant due to the fiscal impact on the state budget, specifically the requirement for general fund expenditures for judicial programming and the management of the special fund receiving fine revenue.
The Governor's Office oversaw the signing of the bill and exercises executive authority over the implementing departments (Labor and Comptroller).

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill makes technical corrections to Maryland's income tax laws by repealing obsolete provisions concerning the distribution of income tax revenue to municipalities and correcting an erroneous cross-reference related to the catalytic revitalization project tax credit.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of the Comptroller
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland taxpayers, including individuals, nonprofit organizations, and business entities, as well as the Office of the Comptroller.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact. The changes are technical in nature and do not directly affect governmental revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller is the primary agency responsible for the collection and distribution of income tax revenue. This bill was introduced at the request of the Comptroller's Office to clean up obsolete distribution provisions and technical errors in the tax code.
The bill corrects an erroneous cross-reference relating to the catalytic revitalization project tax credit, which is governed by the Housing and Community Development Article of the Maryland Code.
The bill repeals an obsolete provision (Section 2-608.1) that required the Comptroller to distribute funds based on census data provided by the Department of Planning.
As the state's principal executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation, including technical corrections to the state's tax laws.
As the state’s central fiscal authority, DBM oversees the formulation of the budget and the estimation of state revenues, though the bill has no direct fiscal impact.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of tax information and authorizes the Maryland Comptroller to disclose specific tax information to tax compliance organizations and governmental entities to assist in tax enforcement and compliance activities. It requires recipients of this information to enter into binding data use agreements and establishes penalties for unauthorized disclosure of the shared information.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Comptroller
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland taxpayers, tax compliance organizations, and state and local tax collection agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to potentially increase state and local revenues starting in FY 2025 due to enhanced tax compliance and audit capabilities. Any administrative costs associated with implementing data use agreements or increased compliance activity are expected to be handled by the Comptroller's Office using existing budgeted resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller is the primary implementing agency for the bill. It authorizes the Comptroller to disclose tax information to tax compliance organizations, requires the Comptroller to manage binding data use agreements, and mandates the Comptroller to supervise recipients of such information to ensure security and compliance.

The bill explicitly lists the Maryland Tax Court as an entity to which tax information may be disclosed. The broader definition of 'tax information' and the new requirements for data use agreements may impact how the Court receives and handles information from the Comptroller.

The bill specifies that tax information may be disclosed to a legal representative of the State (the OAG) to review information about taxpayers involved in appeals or legal actions. Additionally, the OAG would likely provide legal counsel on the binding data use agreements required by the bill.

The bill explicitly names the Maryland Department of Health as an authorized recipient of tax information for specific programs and mandates that the Department enter into binding data use agreements with the Comptroller before receiving such data.

The Department of Human Services is explicitly named as an entity that receives tax information for the administration of certain health-related provisions and is now subject to mandatory binding data use agreements under the bill.

The State Department of Education is specifically mentioned as an authorized recipient of tax information for administrative purposes and will be required to enter into binding data use agreements with the Comptroller.

The Maryland Higher Education Commission is explicitly listed as a recipient of tax information and is subject to the new requirements regarding binding data use agreements and oversight by the Comptroller.

The bill explicitly identifies the HSCRC as an entity authorized to receive tax information and subjects it to mandatory binding data use agreements to ensure the security of the information received.

The Maryland Small Business Retirement Savings Board (MarylandSaves) is named as an authorized recipient of tax information and is explicitly required to enter into binding data use agreements with the Comptroller as a condition of receiving such data.

The fiscal note indicates a potential increase in general and special fund revenues resulting from increased tax compliance activity authorized by the bill. As the state's central fiscal authority, DBM is responsible for managing the impact of these revenue changes.

The bill mentions license-issuing authorities, including verification of unemployment insurance contributions payable to the Secretary of Labor, as entities that may receive tax information, making the Department of Labor a relevant party for information exchange under the bill's protocols.

The bill mentions the Maryland 9-1-1 Board as an entity authorized to receive tax information. As the department responsible for overseeing the state’s 9-1-1 system, MDEM has an interest in the data sharing and confidentiality provisions of the bill.

The bill establishes that unauthorized disclosure of tax information by recipients is a misdemeanor. The AOC is responsible for the administrative infrastructure of the court system where such criminal cases would be prosecuted.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill mandates electronic filing for various Maryland tax and fee returns, including income tax, sales and use tax, and environmental fees, with implementation dates phased in between 2026 and 2030. It also prohibits tax return preparers and software companies from charging separate fees for electronic filing and provides exemptions for certain taxpayers based on age, income, disability, or religious beliefs.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland taxpayers, tax return preparers, tax software developers, and businesses subject to state taxes and fees.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues may see a minimal increase starting in fiscal 2030 from civil penalties for illegal electronic filing fees. The Comptroller's Office anticipates operational efficiencies and faster processing times from the transition to digital returns. No impact on local government finances is expected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller is the primary agency responsible for implementing and overseeing the mandate for electronic filing of tax and fee returns, collecting the associated revenues, and enforcing the new prohibitions and civil penalties against tax preparers and software companies.

The bill mandates electronic filing for the tire recycling fee and the bay restoration fee, both of which are established under the Environment Article and support programs managed by this department.

The bill specifically provides for a hearing under the Administrative Procedure Act for any tax return preparer or software company facing civil penalties, a process handled by Administrative Law Judges within this office.
This department licenses and regulates individual tax preparers in Maryland; the bill directly impacts these professionals by prohibiting them from charging separate fees for electronic filing.

The bill contains explicit filing exemptions for individuals with disabilities as defined by the Americans with Disabilities Act, which aligns with the department's role in monitoring policy impacts on this population.
The bill provides specific exemptions from electronic income tax filing for residents aged 65 and older, a demographic served and advocated for by this department.

As the chief legal advisor to the Comptroller, this office would be responsible for legal oversight of the new regulations and representing the state in enforcement actions related to the prohibited filing fees.

The bill is expected to improve operational efficiencies in revenue processing and requires that new civil penalties be paid into the General Fund, which falls under the department's fiscal oversight.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires producers or sellers of synthetic turf to disclose maintenance requirements and typical costs for removal, replacement, and disposal to customers before a sale. It also mandates that the Maryland Department of the Environment conduct a comprehensive study on the synthetic turf industry in the State, including current disposal methods and recycling rates, and report its findings by July 1, 2026.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE)
qa_results.stakeholders: Synthetic turf producers and sellers, customers including local governments, county school systems, and higher education facilities, and environmental and community stakeholders.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $59,400 in FY 2025 and $63,900 in FY 2026 to hire a contractual environmental compliance specialist to conduct the required study and report. Expenditures terminate at the end of FY 2026. Local governments and higher education facilities are expected to consult on the study using existing resources. There is no impact on State or local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MDE is the primary agency responsible for implementing this bill. It is tasked with conducting a comprehensive study on synthetic turf, consulting with industry and government stakeholders, and submitting a report of its findings to the General Assembly by July 1, 2026.

The bill mandates consultation with 'professional sports organizations' and 'higher education facilities,' and requires a study of existing turf fields. MSA manages world-class sports facilities and major infrastructure projects, including many with synthetic turf components, making their expertise and facilities highly relevant to the study.

The bill requires a study of existing turf fields and consultation with county school systems. The IAC oversees and funds public school facility projects, including the installation and maintenance of sports fields where synthetic turf is commonly used.

As a 'higher education facility' stakeholder specifically mentioned for consultation, USM is relevant because its member institutions own and manage numerous synthetic turf sports fields impacted by the study's scope.

Morgan State is specifically listed in the fiscal note as a higher education stakeholder and an information source. The university manages athletic facilities that would likely be included in MDE's study of existing fields.

Named in the fiscal note as a stakeholder and information source, St. Mary's is a public higher education institution with athletic facilities that will be consulted as part of MDE's industry and field study.

MSDE oversees the county school systems that the bill identifies as essential stakeholders for consultation. The outcomes of the synthetic turf study could influence academic and safety standards for school athletic facilities.

DNR manages extensive state park and forest lands, some of which contain recreational sports and playing fields. The agency is identified in the fiscal note as a relevant information source for MDE's study.

DGS manages the design, construction, and maintenance of state-owned facilities. Because the bill studies synthetic turf maintenance, disposal, and replacement, DGS's role in procuring and managing state infrastructure makes them a key participant in the study.

The fiscal note identifies that MDE will require additional general fund expenditures and a contractual environmental compliance specialist to conduct the study. DBM oversees the state's personnel and budget allocations necessary to fulfill this mandate.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies involved (MDE, DNR, etc.) and is responsible for signing the legislation and ensuring its implementation by the executive branch.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor for MDE and other state agencies and may be required to provide guidance on the disclosure requirements and statutory interpretations within the Environment Article.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits courts and parties in criminal or juvenile delinquency cases from disclosing or allowing the inspection of court filings by nonparties unless identifying information of a minor victim is redacted. The redaction requirement applies to both electronic and paper filings, including charging documents, upon notice that the filing contains identifying information, unless the court finds good cause to allow the disclosure. The bill defines 'identifying information' as the name of and any other details that could reasonably be expected to identify a victim who was a minor at the time of the incident.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Minor victims of crimes or delinquent acts, court clerks, legal parties in criminal and juvenile cases, and nonparties (such as the public or media) seeking access to court records.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to cause a minimal increase in State general fund expenditures and have an operational impact on the Judiciary due to the additional clerical time required for court staff to redact documents. Local circuit courts may also experience a similar operational impact. There is no projected impact on State or local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts court operations by requiring redaction of minor victim information in court filings before disclosure to nonparties. The fiscal note highlights operational and potential fiscal impacts on the Judiciary, specifically regarding court clerks and the management of public kiosks for viewing documents.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As a primary party in criminal and juvenile delinquency cases, the Office of the Public Defender will be responsible for redacting identifying information of minor victims in their court filings to comply with the bill's requirements.

The bill specifically applies to juvenile delinquency cases. As the agency responsible for the management and supervision of youth in the juvenile justice system, DJS is involved in these proceedings and often acts as a party or generates filings that will require redaction.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to state agencies and handles criminal and juvenile appeals. They may act as a party in cases affected by the bill and will be responsible for ensuring compliance with redaction requirements in those contexts.

The Maryland State Police initiate criminal cases by submitting charging documents, which are specifically mentioned in the bill as court filings that must be redacted if they contain identifying information of minor victims.

The Natural Resources Police (NRP) within the DNR initiate criminal filings for hunting, fishing, and boating violations. The fiscal note identifies DNR as an information source, as their law enforcement division will be subject to the bill's redaction requirements for filings.

MDOT includes the MDTA Police and the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA), both of which are involved in criminal filings and law enforcement activities. The fiscal note identifies MDOT as an agency impacted by the operational requirements of the bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS manages the Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS) and provides support services to victims. The protection of victim identities in court records is relevant to the management of criminal justice data and victim advocacy within their jurisdiction.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office advises the Governor on criminal justice strategies and manages victim services programs. The policy changes regarding the protection of minor victims fall within their scope of public safety and victim policy oversight.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill renames the State Advisory Council on Quality Care at the End of Life to the State Advisory Council on Serious Illness Care and updates references to the council within the Maryland Annotated Code.
qa_results.responsible_party: The State Advisory Council on Serious Illness Care, supported by the Maryland Department of Aging and the Office of the Attorney General
qa_results.stakeholders: Marylanders with life-limiting or serious illnesses, healthcare providers, hospice care organizations, long-term care facilities, and the health insurance industry.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact. Renaming the advisory council does not affect State finances or operations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Office of the Attorney General (OAG) is a statutory member of the Council and is explicitly required by law to jointly provide staff support and technical assistance to the Council alongside the Department of Aging. The Council also provides recommendations to the OAG.

The Secretary of Aging is a statutory member of the Council. The Department is legally mandated to jointly provide staff support and technical assistance to the Council and receives recommendations from it regarding care at the end of life.

The Secretary of Health is a member of the Council. The Council monitors care trends and provides recommendations to the Department regarding activities affecting the provision of care to Marylanders with life-limiting illnesses.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The State Advisory Council on Quality Care at the End of Life (renamed to the State Advisory Council on Serious Illness Care) is an advisory body that falls under this functional classification within the executive branch.
The Governor is responsible for appointing the chair and 17 members of the Council, and the Council is tasked with carrying out duties requested by the Governor.

The Secretary of Disabilities is a statutory member of the Council, which coordinates policy and recommendations related to serious illness and life-limiting conditions that often involve individuals with disabilities.
The Office of Appointments is responsible for identifying, recruiting, and vetting the 17 candidates appointed by the Governor to serve on this Council.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the definition of the practice of audiology to include evaluating, diagnosing, and treating auditory or vestibular conditions, and prescribing or fitting sound processors for cochlear implants and osseo-integrated devices. It clarifies that the practice includes tasks such as health screenings, cerumen removal, and ordering certain tests and imaging, while explicitly excluding surgical procedures and the actual performance of radiographic imaging.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Examiners for Audiologists, Hearing Aid Dispensers, Speech-Language Pathologists, and Music Therapists
qa_results.stakeholders: Audiologists and individuals seeking treatment for hearing or vestibular conditions.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The State Board of Examiners for Audiologists, Hearing Aid Dispensers, Speech-Language Pathologists, and Music Therapists can implement the bill's requirements using existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on state or local revenues, and the fiscal impact on small businesses is expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Health is the primary agency impacted because the bill alters the definition of 'practice audiology' under the Health Occupations Article. The State Board of Examiners for Audiologists, Hearing Aid Dispensers, Speech-Language Pathologists, and Music Therapists, which resides within the MDH, is responsible for regulating these professionals and must update regulations to reflect the expanded scope of practice.

The Maryland School for the Deaf is directly impacted as it provides specialized audiology services to its students. The expansion of the audiological scope of practice—including device fitting, non-impacted cerumen removal, and ordering bloodwork or imaging—directly affects the clinical operations and protocols of the audiologists employed by the school.

The Maryland State Department of Education is relevant because it oversees the public K-12 system and early childhood programs where audiology services are provided. School-based audiologists will have an expanded scope of practice that impacts how they serve students with hearing impairments in educational settings.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the primary legal advisor to the Department of Health and its health occupation boards. They will likely be involved in drafting or reviewing the new regulations required to implement the redefined scope of practice for audiologists.

The Department of Budget and Management is relevant as it oversees the state personnel system and the fiscal accountability of the executive branch. While the fiscal note indicates the impact can be handled with existing resources, DBM maintains interest in changes to professional regulations that affect state-employed healthcare providers.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the maximum civil penalty from $5,000 to $10,000 per employee for employers who knowingly misclassify employees as independent contractors under the Workplace Fraud Act. Additionally, it requires the Commissioner of Labor and Industry to refer suspected tax violations discovered during workplace fraud or prevailing wage investigations to the Comptroller, State’s Attorneys, and relevant federal agencies including the U.S. Department of Justice and the U.S. Department of the Treasury.
qa_results.responsible_party: Commissioner of Labor and Industry (Maryland Department of Labor)
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland employers (specifically in the construction and landscaping industries), public works contractors and subcontractors, and misclassified employees.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund revenues may increase due to higher civil penalties and improved tax compliance resulting from referrals. General fund expenditures may increase by approximately $88,000 to $100,000 annually if the Comptroller's Office requires additional staff to process increased tax compliance referrals. Local governments are not significantly affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that the Commissioner of Labor and Industry refer certain complaints alleging tax fraud or withholding violations directly to the Comptroller. The Comptroller is also named as an entity required to share information on misclassification and may see a fiscal impact due to increased audit and compliance staff needs.

The Maryland Department of Labor, specifically the Commissioner of Labor and Industry, is the primary agency responsible for investigating workplace fraud and prevailing wage violations, assessing increased civil penalties, and making the mandated referrals to state and federal authorities.

The bill explicitly names the Department of Budget and Management as one of the units required to cooperate and share information concerning the suspected failure to properly classify individuals as employees.

The Maryland Insurance Administration is specifically named in the bill as an agency required to share information on misclassification. It is also recognized as a relevant unit for ordering restitution and ensuring compliance, as misclassification often involves insurance fraud.
The Secretary of State is explicitly named in the bill as one of the units required to cooperate and share information concerning suspected workplace fraud and employee misclassification.

The bill identifies the Workers' Compensation Commission as an administrative unit that may order restitution and compliance. Employee misclassification is a major issue for the commission as it is often used to evade mandatory workers' compensation insurance requirements.
The bill establishes new misdemeanor criminal penalties for knowing violations of workplace fraud and prevailing wage laws, which will be adjudicated in the state court system managed by the AOC.
The Board of Public Works oversees and approves large state procurement contracts where prevailing wage laws and worker classification regulations are primary requirements.
As a major contracting agency for state public works (highways, bridges, and transit), MDOT is directly impacted by changes to prevailing wage enforcement and worker classification oversight.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly relates to the mission of the Joint Enforcement Task Force on Workplace Fraud, which coordinates inter-agency information sharing and enforcement as described in the fiscal note.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies named in the bill and issued the Executive Order establishing the Joint Enforcement Task Force on Workplace Fraud, which is central to the bill's information-sharing mandates.
DGS manages state-owned facility construction and procurement, requiring rigorous adherence to prevailing wage and classification laws by contractors.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency monitors state procurement to ensure fair competition; workplace fraud and misclassification often create an uneven playing field for legitimate small and minority-owned businesses.
The Maryland Stadium Authority is specifically mentioned in the fiscal note regarding its unique status and voluntary compliance with state prevailing wage laws.
Morgan State University is explicitly mentioned in the fiscal note as an institution that is exempt from prevailing wage laws but voluntarily complies with them.
The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for the agencies involved in the bill (Labor, Comptroller) and is listed as an information source for the legislation.
Saint Mary's College of Maryland is explicitly noted in the fiscal note's appendix as an institution exempt from the prevailing wage law.
The University System of Maryland is explicitly identified in the fiscal note as being exempt from the prevailing wage law, though its institutions often voluntarily comply.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Commission to Advance Lithium-Ion Battery Safety in Maryland to study and develop recommendations for safety standards, fire prevention, and recycling practices for lithium-ion batteries in consumer, transportation, and utility applications.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of the State Fire Marshal
qa_results.stakeholders: Lithium-ion battery manufacturers, vehicle propulsion battery manufacturers, fire and emergency response personnel, public utilities, recycling and waste management entities, and the general public.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund expenditures increase by $64,700 in FY 2025 and $27,600 in FY 2026 to provide staffing and administrative support for the Commission via a contractual management associate. There is no effect on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Office of the State Fire Marshal is a unit within the Maryland State Police. The bill requires the State Fire Marshal to be a member of the Commission and specifically mandates that the Office of the State Fire Marshal provide staff for the Commission. The fiscal note identifies the State Police as the entity incurring general fund expenditures for this staff.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill directly establishes a new state commission (the Commission to Advance Lithium-Ion Battery Safety in Maryland) to study policy and make recommendations.

The MEA Director is responsible for appointing several members to the Commission. Additionally, the Commission is tasked with studying battery safety in utility applications and grid-scale storage, which falls under MEA's energy and clean technology mandate.

The Secretary of the Environment appoints a representative to the Commission. The Commission's scope includes studying battery recycling and decommissioning, which are regulatory and safety areas relevant to MDE.
The Secretary of Natural Resources is required to appoint a representative from the Power Plant Research Project to the Commission, given the implications for utility-scale energy storage.

The Chairman of the PSC appoints a representative to the Commission. The Commission's focus on lithium-ion battery safety in utility and grid-scale applications directly impacts the regulated utility sector overseen by the PSC.
The Commission is required to report its findings and legislative recommendations directly to the Governor by December 2025.
The fiscal note identifies a general fund expenditure increase to cover the cost of a contractual staff position to support the Commission. DBM oversees state personnel and budget allocation.
The Commission is tasked with studying battery safety in transportation applications, which impacts MDOT's mission regarding safe and sustainable transit and vehicle regulations.

The Commission's recommendations regarding fire suppression and first responder training for lithium-ion battery emergencies are relevant to MDEM's role in disaster preparedness and emergency response coordination.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates post-election procedures in Maryland, specifically regarding the canvassing and certification of election results. It expands the types of election records local boards must investigate for errors, allows the State Board of Elections and Board of State Canvassers to reject inaccurate local results based on clear and convincing evidence, and authorizes members of the Board of State Canvassers to appoint specific designees. It also aligns the Governor's role in certifying presidential and congressional election results with federal requirements.
qa_results.responsible_party: The State Administrator of Elections, the Maryland State Board of Elections, and the Board of State Canvassers
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland voters, political candidates, local boards of elections, and State election officials
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State or local government finances. Both revenues and expenditures are anticipated to remain unchanged according to the Fiscal and Policy Note.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill is highly relevant to SBE as it expands the duties of the State Administrator in investigating election errors and reviewing dissents. It also grants the State Board new authority to reject inaccurate local statements and adopt regulations governing the certification of election results.

The bill alters the Governor's specific legal responsibilities regarding the ascertainment of election results for presidential electors and members of Congress, including the issuance of certificates of electors and proclamations.

The Secretary of State is a statutory member of the Board of State Canvassers. The bill allows the Secretary to appoint a Deputy Secretary of State as a designee and modifies the board's meeting and certification timelines.

The Comptroller is a statutory member of the Board of State Canvassers. The bill allows the Comptroller to appoint the Chief Deputy Comptroller as a designee and modifies the board's responsibilities in certifying election results.

The State Treasurer is a statutory member of the Board of State Canvassers. The bill clarifies the Treasurer's ability to appoint the deputy treasurer as a designee and alters the board's role in verifying and rejecting inaccurate election statements.

The Attorney General is a statutory member of the Board of State Canvassers. The bill allows for the appointment of the Deputy Attorney General as a designee and impacts the board's legal mandate to ensure accurate election certification.

The Clerk of the Supreme Court of Maryland is a statutory member of the Board of State Canvassers. The AOC provides the administrative and financial infrastructure for the Judiciary, which includes the office of the Clerk.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the School Mapping Data Program within the Maryland Center for School Safety to provide grants to local school systems for creating digital mapping data of public schools and charter schools. These maps are intended to assist first responders during emergencies and must meet uniform standards developed by the Interagency Commission on School Construction. The bill also ensures that school mapping data is kept confidential and is not subject to public inspection under the Maryland Public Information Act.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Center for School Safety and the Interagency Commission on School Construction
qa_results.stakeholders: Local school systems, public schools, public charter schools, first responders, and the School Safety Subcabinet.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no net effect on total State revenues or expenditures because the program is supported by the existing Safe Schools Fund. However, directing these resources toward school mapping may reduce the funds available for other authorized school safety activities. Local school systems that apply for and receive grants will see an increase in revenues and expenditures to develop the required mapping data.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the School Mapping Data Program within the Maryland Center for School Safety, which is responsible for coordinating the program and consulting with the Interagency Commission on School Construction.
The bill requires the Interagency Commission to adopt facility mapping standards for public schools and consult with the Center for School Safety to ensure mapping data meets these standards.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The School Safety Subcabinet, an executive body, is responsible for administering the Safe Schools Fund and providing grants to local school systems for mapping data.
The Maryland Center for School Safety is an independent unit within the Department of Education, and the State Superintendent of Schools chairs the School Safety Subcabinet overseeing the program.
The Secretary of State Police is a member of the School Safety Subcabinet, and the agency is specifically authorized to inspect school mapping data in the performance of official duties.
The Secretary of Health serves as a member of the School Safety Subcabinet, which is responsible for administering the funds used for the School Mapping Data Program.
The Secretary of Disabilities serves as a member of the School Safety Subcabinet, which oversees the grants and implementation of the school safety program.
The Attorney General serves as a member of the School Safety Subcabinet, which manages the Safe Schools Fund and the program's grant eligibility.
The State Treasurer is responsible for holding the Safe Schools Fund separately from other funds and investing its money, supporting the financial mechanics of the program.
The Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the Safe Schools Fund in conjunction with the Executive Director of the Maryland Center for School Safety.
The agency is specifically listed as an entity authorized to inspect school mapping data, which is produced to assist first responders during emergencies.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency is explicitly authorized to inspect school mapping data records in the performance of its official duties.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The office was listed as a source of information for the bill's analysis and maintains a general policy interest in statewide school safety and crime prevention initiatives.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Open-Source Phonics Matching Grant Program within the Maryland State Department of Education. The program provides matching funds to nonprofit organizations, institutions of higher education, and public libraries that produce or distribute free, open-source phonics materials to be used by adults tutoring students in Maryland. These materials must align with best practices in literacy education and the science of reading.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland students, adult tutors, and open-source phonics organizations including nonprofits, higher education institutions, and public libraries.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund expenditures increase by $150,000 annually beginning in fiscal year 2025. This funding is discretionary in fiscal year 2025 and becomes a mandated appropriation starting in fiscal year 2026. The Maryland State Department of Education can likely administer the program using existing resources. Local school system finances and operations are not directly affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Open-Source Phonics Matching Grant Program specifically within this department. MSDE is responsible for administering the program, reviewing materials for consistency with the science of reading, disbursing grants, and reporting on program effectiveness.
The bill mandates that the Governor include a $150,000 annual appropriation for the program in the state budget bill. The Governor also oversees MSDE, the primary implementing agency.
DBM is responsible for formulating the state's annual budget and will manage the mandated $150,000 annual appropriation required by the bill.

Public libraries are explicitly listed in the bill as 'open-source phonics organizations' eligible to apply for and receive grants from the program. The State Library Agency coordinates these systems and was identified as a source of information in the fiscal note.

The bill defines 'institutions of higher education' as eligible organizations for the grants. MHEC coordinates the policies and growth of these institutions, which may seek funding to produce or distribute phonics materials.
As a system comprising 12 public universities, its member institutions are 'institutions of higher education' eligible to apply for grants under the newly established program.
As a public institution of higher education, Morgan State is an eligible 'open-source phonics organization' that can apply for grant funding to support literacy tutoring efforts.
As a public liberal arts college, it qualifies as an institution of higher education eligible for grants to provide phonics learning materials for tutoring.

The GGO provides technical assistance and training to state agencies and nonprofits to improve grant management. It may be called upon to support the administration of this new matching grant program.

The program's goal is to provide materials to be used by 'adults to tutor students.' Volunteer Maryland, which recruits and trains coordinators for service programs, may be involved in the coordination of the adults performing these tutoring services.
The OLA is responsible for regular fiscal compliance audits of MSDE. It will eventually audit the management and disbursement of the $150,000 annual appropriation established by this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill exempts forensic genetic genealogical DNA analysis and search (FGGS) from specific statutory restrictions and judicial authorization requirements when the analysis is conducted solely for the purpose of identifying a deceased individual or an individual who is the subject of a missing person report and whose whereabouts are unknown.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland law enforcement agencies and the Department of State Police
qa_results.stakeholders: Law enforcement agencies, families of missing persons, and unidentified deceased individuals
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect Maryland State or local government finances, according to the Department of Legislative Services.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's primary law enforcement agency responsible for investigating major crimes and missing persons, the Maryland State Police is the principal entity that will utilize the bill's exemption to expedite the identification of deceased individuals and missing persons using forensic genetic genealogical DNA analysis and search (FGGS) technology.

The bill directly impacts the Maryland Judiciary by removing the requirement for judicial authorization and oversight (including the review of affidavits and 30-day progress reports) for FGGS searches when conducted solely to identify a deceased or missing individual.

The Office of the Attorney General acts as the primary legal advisor for state agencies and manages criminal appeals; it must interpret these procedural changes to forensic DNA laws and ensure law enforcement and prosecutors apply the exemptions correctly.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the central hub for public safety policy and criminal justice strategy, this agency is responsible for advising the Governor on the implementation and impact of forensic technologies like FGGS in the state's criminal justice system.

The bill removes the applicability of current regulations that involve the Office of Health Care Quality (under the Department of Health), which is currently responsible for approving genetic counselor training for those obtaining DNA samples in FGGS investigations.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Office of the Public Defender is concerned with changes to criminal procedure and the state's use of forensic evidence; while this bill focuses on identification rather than perpetrator identification, it fundamentally alters the legal standards for collecting and searching genetic data.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes individuals to receive raffle tickets for each antlerless deer hunted during specific January raffle programs designed to encourage antlerless deer hunting, provided the program was held at least once between January 2020 and January 2024.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Hunters, the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, small businesses related to hunting, farmers, and vehicle owners and repair shops.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State or local operations or finances. There is a potential meaningful economic impact on small businesses through increased hunting-related expenditures and reduced crop or vehicle damage resulting from a possible decrease in the deer population.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for managing Maryland's land and living resources, the Department of Natural Resources (DNR) establishes hunting seasons and regulates wildlife populations. This bill directly amends the Natural Resources Article to authorize a specific antlerless deer hunting raffle program which falls under the DNR's oversight and enforcement via the Natural Resources Police.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency is the regulatory body for gaming in Maryland. Since the bill specifically authorizes a program where participants receive raffle tickets in exchange for hunting antlerless deer, it involves a gaming incentive that must comply with state standards for fair play and lottery integrity.

The Department of Agriculture is concerned with the economic viability of farming. As noted in the fiscal note, managing the deer population is critical for reducing crop damage on farms, which is a major concern for the agricultural community this agency serves.

The fiscal note indicates that hunting contributes over $260 million annually to Maryland's economy through food, lodging, and equipment expenditures. The Department of Commerce, which promotes tourism and supports small businesses, is relevant because the bill seeks to incentivize hunting activity which supports these economic sectors.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor for state agencies including the Department of Natural Resources. They would be responsible for ensuring the implementation of the new raffle program aligns with existing state and federal environmental and hunting laws.

The Governor's Office is responsible for overseeing the operations of state departments and signing legislation. The Governor signed this specific bill (Chapter 541) into law as part of their executive responsibility to manage natural resources and economic opportunity.

Deer population management and hunting programs are high-priority issues for rural communities. The Rural Maryland Council advocates for rural economic development and agriculture, both of which are impacted by the efficacy of deer population control measures.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates the Department of Planning, Environment, and Natural Resources to protect agricultural and forest lands. Incentivizing deer hunting helps protect forest regeneration and agricultural land from overgrazing by overpopulated deer herds.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires a seller of residential real property located within one mile of a National Priorities List (NPL) Superfund site to provide the buyer with a specific disclosure addendum to the contract of sale. The addendum must identify the Superfund site, define the term, provide links to Environmental Protection Agency websites, and notify the buyer of their right to void the contract within five days of signing for a full refund of any money paid.
qa_results.responsible_party: Sellers of residential real property and the Maryland Department of Labor (Real Estate Commission)
qa_results.stakeholders: Buyers and sellers of residential property, real estate brokers and agents, and the Maryland Department of the Environment.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect Maryland State or local government finances or operations. There is a minimal anticipated impact on small businesses, primarily real estate entities responsible for ensuring proper contract disclosures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MDE administers the state's Superfund program and oversees the cleanup of hazardous waste sites, making them the primary state authority for the environmental data regarding National Priorities List (NPL) sites central to the required disclosures.
The Department of Labor regulates and licenses the real estate professionals who must ensure that these mandatory disclosure addendums are properly included in residential property sales contracts.
The OAG enforces consumer protection laws and provides legal counsel regarding real estate disclosure requirements intended to protect buyers from hazardous site proximity.

The Judiciary's court system would be the venue for litigation resulting from contract voidance disputes, rescissions, or claims related to the failure to provide the required Superfund site addendum.
The Governor's Office signed the bill into law and oversees the executive agencies responsible for environmental safety and professional licensing.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date for a Maryland income tax subtraction modification for donations of diapers, feminine hygiene products, and other infant hygiene products to diaper banks and other qualified charitable entities. The subtraction modification, which is limited to $1,000 per taxpayer per year, is extended through tax year 2026.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Comptroller's Office
qa_results.stakeholders: Individual and corporate taxpayers; diaper banks; homeless shelters; domestic violence shelters; religious organizations; and other charitable entities registered as distributors.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues are estimated to decrease by approximately $250,000 annually from FY 2025 through FY 2027. Local income tax revenues are estimated to decrease by approximately $165,000 annually over the same period. Total annual fiscal impact is estimated at $415,000 in decreased revenue.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller is the primary agency responsible for administering the income tax subtraction modification. The bill requires the Comptroller to adopt regulations, manage the registration of qualified charitable entities (diaper banks, shelters, etc.), and process the tax returns including proof of donation value.

The bill has a direct fiscal impact on the state's general fund, reducing revenues by an estimated $250,000 annually through FY 2027. DBM is responsible for revenue estimation and overseeing the executive budget affected by this loss.

The fiscal note indicates that to the extent corporate taxpayers claim the subtraction modification, revenues for the Transportation Trust Fund (TTF) will decrease, potentially affecting capital transportation grants to local governments.

According to the fiscal note, corporate claims of this tax subtraction will lead to a decrease in revenues for the Higher Education Investment Fund (HEIF), which supports the state's higher education system.

As the office responsible for drafting the state budget and overseeing all departments, the Governor's Office is impacted by the reduction in general fund revenue and the implementation of social support initiatives for vulnerable residents.

The bill's focus on supporting diaper banks and child hygiene products directly supports the GOC's mission to eliminate childhood poverty and align government efforts to improve the well-being of Maryland's children and families.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission to publish the names of candidates for the Baltimore County Board of Education on its website before conducting interviews. It stipulates that meetings involving candidate interviews or deliberations must be closed to the public but must be recorded, with these recordings made available for public inspection within 48 hours of a request. Meetings involving official actions on candidates must remain open to the public.
qa_results.responsible_party: Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Candidates for the Baltimore County Board of Education, the Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission, and the residents of Baltimore County.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no State fiscal impact. Locally, the Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission is expected to fulfill the recording and publishing requirements using existing resources, with no impact on local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor is the final appointing authority for the Baltimore County Board of Education. The Nominating Commission is specifically tasked with recommending candidates to the Governor, and this bill modifies the transparency and meeting procedures for that recommendation process.

This office manages the recruitment and vetting process for gubernatorial appointments to boards and commissions. As the Governor appoints members to both the Nominating Commission itself and the Board of Education based on the Commission's work, this office is directly involved in the administrative workflow affected by these new transparency requirements.

The Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) oversees the public K-12 education system. Changes to the governance and selection process of a local board of education, such as Baltimore County's, impact the oversight and administrative framework of the state's education system.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the Governor and state agencies. They would be responsible for providing legal guidance on the interpretation and enforcement of the bill's new requirements regarding public meetings, recording, and the disclosure of candidate records under the General Provisions Article.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill redefines 'consent' for sexual crimes as a clear and voluntary agreement and removes 'force' or the 'threat of force' as a required element for second-degree rape. It establishes that consent must be determined based on the totality of the circumstances and specifies that factors such as a prior relationship or manner of dress do not constitute consent. Additionally, it requires the Maryland Judiciary to report annual data on sexual crime charges and convictions to the General Assembly through 2029.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Victims and defendants of sexual crimes, law enforcement agencies, the Office of the Public Defender, and the Maryland court system.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by at least $7,000 in fiscal 2025 for Judiciary information technology costs. Long-term expenditures may increase significantly due to potential rises in incarceration costs and increased workloads for the Office of the Public Defender, depending on changes in prosecution and conviction rates. Local government finances and the workloads of State's Attorneys' offices are not expected to be materially affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly mandates the Maryland Judiciary to report annual data on sexual crime charges and convictions to the General Assembly. The fiscal note identifies specific IT costs for the Judiciary to implement this reporting requirement.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The repeal of the 'force' element in second-degree rape and the new definition of consent may lead to increased prosecutions. The fiscal note indicates this bill may significantly increase agency caseloads and necessitate additional staff.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Altering the elements of sexual crimes to potentially include more acts under the definition of second-degree rape may increase the number of individuals committed to State correctional facilities and impact community supervision.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's central hub for public safety policy, this agency is relevant to the bill's significant shifts in criminal law policy and its focus on data-driven insights into crime trends and safety resources.

The OAG handles all criminal appeals and advises the executive branch on legal matters. Statutory changes to the elements of rape and the definition of consent directly affect the legal landscape for prosecutions and appeals.

As the primary statewide law enforcement agency investigating major crimes, the MSP must adapt its investigative protocols and charging standards to align with the revised definitions of consent and sexual offenses.

DBM oversees the state's operating budget and must account for the increased general fund expenditures for the Judiciary's reporting and the potential staffing increases for the Office of the Public Defender.

The Governor's Office oversees the operations of all state departments and enforces state laws, including new mandates regarding criminal justice reporting and statutory changes to the Criminal Law Article.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the fee for a nonresident sika deer stamp from $25 to $200 for individuals hunting sika deer in Maryland.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Nonresident hunters hunting sika deer in Maryland
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Net special fund revenues to the Wildlife Management and Protection Fund increase by an estimated $332,200 annually beginning in fiscal 2025. Federal fund revenues increase by an estimated $996,500 annually beginning in fiscal 2026 due to federal matching grant funding for conservation-related work. There is no impact on expenditures or local finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Natural Resources is the primary agency responsible for managing Maryland's wildlife populations and regulating hunting. The bill directly impacts their administration of hunting stamps and significantly increases revenue for the Wildlife Management and Protection Fund, as well as federal matching grants for conservation work.

The Department of Budget and Management is responsible for estimating state revenues and overseeing the budget. The bill has a notable fiscal impact, increasing state special and federal fund revenues by over $1.3 million annually by fiscal 2026.

The Comptroller serves as the state's chief financial officer and tax collector. This agency is responsible for monitoring and accounting for state revenues, including the fees collected from hunting licenses and stamps.

The Governor's Office oversees all state departments, including the Department of Natural Resources, and is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation. The Governor officially approved this bill in May 2024.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the annual reporting requirements for the Access to Counsel in Evictions (ACE) Program. It requires the Maryland Legal Services Corporation (MLSC) to provide more specific data in its annual report, including the number of cases disaggregated by type (such as nonpayment of rent, tenant holdover, and breach of lease), the amount paid to attorneys per case, geographic distribution of cases, disposition data, and the allocation of State and federal funds to designated organizations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Legal Services Corporation (MLSC)
qa_results.stakeholders: Low-income tenants (covered individuals), designated nonprofit legal organizations, and the Maryland Legal Services Corporation.
