DBM is responsible for the state's fiscal oversight. The fiscal note indicates a direct general fund expenditure increase of $50,000 to $75,000 in FY 2025 to implement the bill's information technology requirements.

The bill requires modifications to TEDCO's digital application systems to collect demographic data. As the state's central IT authority, DoIT oversees the standards and infrastructure for such system updates.

The bill specifically requires the collection of veteran status in the investment application, which supports the DVMF mission of identifying and advocating for the needs of veterans in the business community.

The bill requires the collection of disability status data from tech applicants. This aligns with MDOD's mission to improve service delivery and advocate for the economic participation of individuals with disabilities.

The Innovation Team focuses on data-driven solutions for economic mobility. The new reporting requirements regarding disaggregated demographic data on business founders would provide valuable evidence for their efforts to reduce poverty and increase economic opportunity.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the membership of the State Board of Social Work Examiners by allowing a licensed master social worker approved for independent practice to fill a board seat previously reserved for a licensed certified social worker. It also removes obsolete language and references to certified social worker licenses which the Board no longer issues.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Social Work Examiners
qa_results.stakeholders: Licensed social workers in Maryland, specifically Licensed Certified Social Workers (LCSW) and Licensed Master Social Workers (LMSW) seeking independent practice approval, as well as the State Board of Social Work Examiners and out-of-state social work license applicants.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact. It is clarifying in nature and does not directly affect governmental revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) provides regulatory oversight for health professional boards. The State Board of Social Work Examiners is a unit within MDH, and the Secretary of Health is specifically tasked by this bill to advise the Governor on board appointments.

The Governor is the appointing authority for all members of the State Board of Social Work Examiners. This bill directly alters the statutory requirements the Governor must follow when filling vacancies and selecting nominees for the board.

The bill maintains the requirement that one of the 12 board members must be a licensed social worker employed by the Department of Human Services (DHS). Any changes to board membership or licensing categories directly affect the selection of staff from DHS for this role.

The Office of Appointments is responsible for identifying, vetting, and recruiting candidates for state boards. This bill alters the qualifications for board membership and specifies timelines for filling vacancies, which directly impacts the office's recruitment and administrative tasks.

The Office of the Attorney General acts as the primary legal advisor to the Governor, the Secretary of Health, and state boards. The OAG would likely provide legal counsel regarding the implementation of the new licensing standards and the transition of board membership requirements.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Secretary of State to provide a Maryland State flag to drape the casket of an 'eligible decedent' upon request. Eligible decedents include certain state and local employees who died in the line of duty, as well as current or former high-ranking officials such as the Governor, members of the General Assembly, judges, and constitutional officers. The bill mandates that the flags be produced entirely in the United States unless a waiver is granted and outlines the process for the next of kin or associates to claim the flag after the burial.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Secretary of State
qa_results.stakeholders: Next of kin or close associates of deceased State and local government employees killed in the line of duty, as well as current or former Maryland Governors, members of the General Assembly, judges, and other specified high-level public officials.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by at least $14,000 in fiscal 2025 to allow the Secretary of State to purchase an initial inventory of 100 cotton flags. Ongoing expenditures are expected to increase annually by a minimal, indeterminate amount for postage and inventory replenishment. There is no impact on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill designates the Secretary of State as the primary implementing agency. The Secretary is responsible for furnishing the State flags, adopting regulations for the request and verification process, and ensuring the flags are produced in the United States.

The Governor is an 'eligible decedent' under the bill. Additionally, the Governor is given the authority to designate other individuals as eligible decedents through executive order, and the bill codifies protocols similar to existing Executive Orders.

Judges are specifically listed as a category of 'eligible decedent.' As the central support agency for the Maryland Judiciary, the AOC would likely be involved in verifying eligibility or coordinating requests for deceased members of the bench.

The bill creates an ongoing general fund expenditure ($14,000 initially) for the procurement of flags, which falls under DBM's fiscal oversight. The bill also relies on state personnel law (overseen by DBM) to define eligible categories of state employees and unit heads.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Secretary of State and would be responsible for assisting in the drafting and legal review of the regulations required to implement the flag request and verification process.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill, known as the Bridge to Medical Residency Act, allows medical school graduates who have passed parts 1 and 2 of the United States Medical Licensing Examination but have not yet entered a residency program to perform delegated medical duties under the direct supervision of a licensed physician for up to two years. Additionally, the bill permanently authorizes licensed physicians to delegate specific duties to registered cardiovascular invasive specialists in hospital cardiac catheterization laboratories by repealing a previous sunset provision.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Physicians
qa_results.stakeholders: Medical graduates, licensed physicians, registered cardiovascular invasive specialists, hospitals, and small business health care providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The State Board of Physicians can implement the bill's requirements, including the adoption of new regulations, using existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on state or local revenues. Small business health care providers may experience a meaningful beneficial impact by being able to utilize supervised medical graduates for delegated duties.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The State Board of Physicians is an entity under the Department of Health. The bill requires the Board to adopt regulations for the new 'supervised medical graduate' category and manages the ongoing delegation of duties to cardiovascular invasive specialists, which falls under the Secretary of Health's oversight.

The MHCC is responsible for health system planning and hospital regulation. The bill repeals the sunset for cardiovascular invasive specialists working in hospital cardiac catheterization labs, a sector previously studied and reported on by the MHCC as noted in the fiscal note.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Health and the State Board of Physicians. It would be involved in the legal review of the new regulations and the enforcement of civil penalties for non-compliance with delegation rules.

The bill allows for civil penalties of up to $5,000 for hospitals failing to comply with delegation requirements. Challenges to these penalties or Board decisions regarding medical graduates would be adjudicated by the OAH.
The bill is a significant executive-signed emergency measure (Bridge to Medical Residency Act) that impacts healthcare workforce policy, which is a key area of leadership for the Governor's office.

The bill creates a specific two-year 'bridge' career pathway for medical graduates to perform clinical work before starting a residency, aligning with the Board's mission to create pipelines for high-demand, high-wage professions.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires advanced practice registered nurses (APRNs) practicing in Maryland to notify patients in writing if they do not maintain professional liability insurance or if their coverage has lapsed. This notification must be provided at the patient's first visit and before any procedure, signed by the patient, and kept in the patient's records. Additionally, APRNs without insurance must post this information in a conspicuous location at their practice. The State Board of Nursing is tasked with developing the specific language for these notifications.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Nursing
qa_results.stakeholders: Advanced practice registered nurses (APRNs) and patients in Maryland
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland State Board of Nursing can develop the required notification language using existing budgeted resources. The bill does not affect state revenues or local government operations and finances. The impact on small businesses is expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill regulates Advanced Practice Registered Nurses (APRNs), who are licensed and certified by the State Board of Nursing, a unit within the Department of Health. The bill specifically mandates the State Board of Nursing to develop the notification language and oversees the health professional standards created by this act.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Health Care Alternative Dispute Resolution Office
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office manages the mandatory arbitration process for medical malpractice claims. Requirements for APRNs to disclose the lack of professional liability insurance directly impact the landscape of malpractice disputes and the information available to patients pursuing medical injury claims through this agency.

The MIA regulates the state's insurance industry, including professional liability (malpractice) insurance. While the bill focuses on healthcare provider disclosure, it pertains to consumer protection and information regarding the insurance market regulated by the MIA.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to nearly all state agencies, including the State Board of Nursing and the Department of Health. They would likely be responsible for reviewing the notification language and providing legal guidance on the enforcement of these new health occupation requirements.

The State Treasurer's Office acts as the state's internal insurance company and provides risk management for state property and employees. They were consulted as an information source, as these requirements could impact APRNs employed by the state who are covered under state risk management programs rather than private professional liability insurance.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires each local school system to submit a report to the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee regarding the status of corrective actions taken to address repeat findings and recommendations from the most recent six-year audit conducted by the Office of Legislative Audits. These reports must be submitted by November 1 of the third year of the audit cycle and published on the school system's website, with sensitive cybersecurity findings redacted.
qa_results.responsible_party: Local school systems
qa_results.stakeholders: Local school systems, county boards of education, and the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state fiscal impact. Local school system expenditures may increase by a minimal amount to address repeat audit findings and manage the reporting requirements, while local revenues are not affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill focuses on the audit cycle and findings of the Office of Legislative Audits (OLA). It establishes a specific reporting requirement for local school systems to address repeat findings and recommendations identified by OLA during its six-year audit cycle.

The bill amends the Education Article concerning the financial audits of county boards of education, which fall under the Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE). The State Superintendent is responsible for approving the auditors for these local boards and receiving the results of their financial audits.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits school bus stops from being located on undivided highways with five or more lanes in Montgomery County unless a school crossing guard is present or a traffic control device with a red signal is installed. It also requires that net revenue from school bus monitoring camera fines collected on State highways in the county be remitted to the State Highway Administration for roadway and pedestrian safety improvements near where the violations occurred.
qa_results.responsible_party: Montgomery County Public Schools, Montgomery County Law Enforcement, and the Maryland State Highway Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Montgomery County students, parents, school bus operators, and motorists traveling through Montgomery County.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Montgomery County expenditures may increase significantly starting in fiscal 2026 to comply with safety requirements at bus stops, which may include hiring crossing guards or installing traffic control devices. County revenues from school bus camera fines may decrease if bus stops are relocated to avoid undivided multi-lane highways. Net fine revenue from State highways will be redistributed to the State Highway Administration for safety projects, having a neutral to minimal impact on State finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill adds a new section to the Education Article (Section 7-801.1) regarding the placement and safety of school bus stops. As the primary agency overseeing the public K-12 system and the implementation of the Education Article, the Department is responsible for the regulatory framework governing student transportation safety.

The bill regulates school bus stops on highways with five or more undivided lanes and requires the use of traffic control devices or crossing guards. Many of the impacted roadways in Montgomery County are State highways maintained by the SHA, which would be involved in the approval and installation of traffic signals or other control devices.

MDOT is the parent agency for the State Highway Administration and the Motor Vehicle Administration. It oversees the state's comprehensive multi-modal transportation network and ensures that infrastructure changes, such as new traffic signals required by this bill, align with state safety standards.

Operating within the Department of Education, this agency is responsible for fostering safe learning environments and providing technical assistance for school safety. The safety of students boarding and exiting school buses at specific transit locations falls under their advisory and coordination mission.
The Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation passed by the General Assembly; Governor Wes Moore signed this bill into law on May 9, 2024.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes Class B beer, wine, and liquor license holders in Montgomery County, specifically restaurants and hotels, to sell beer and wine in sealed manufacturer containers for off-premises consumption to customers who have also purchased prepared food. The bill regulates how these products are displayed and requires that off-premises sales receipts be included in gross receipt calculations for auditing purposes.
qa_results.responsible_party: Montgomery County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Owners and operators of restaurants and hotels holding Class B beer, wine, and liquor licenses in Montgomery County, and their customers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State finances and is not expected to materially affect Montgomery County's operations or finances. Small businesses, specifically restaurants and hotels with Class B licenses, may see a meaningful increase in revenue due to additional sales of beer and wine for off-premises consumption.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state’s chief financial officer and tax collector, the Comptroller is responsible for the collection of sales and use taxes as well as alcoholic beverage taxes. Although the bill is local to Montgomery County, changes to off-premises alcohol sales directly impact the administration and monitoring of state revenues derived from these retail transactions.

The Department of Commerce is responsible for stimulating private investment and supporting the expansion of existing companies. This bill provides a new revenue stream for Class B license holders (restaurants and hotels) in Montgomery County, directly impacting the economic viability of small businesses within the hospitality sector.

The Maryland Department of Health manages behavioral health services for substance use disorders and coordinates disease prevention initiatives. Changes in alcoholic beverages policy, such as allowing off-premises consumption at previously on-premises-only locations, intersect with the department’s public health and substance abuse prevention mandates.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation passed by the General Assembly. This bill was signed into law by the Governor, and the office oversees the operations of state departments that may be involved in broader alcohol regulatory policy.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Many restaurants and hotels holding Class B licenses are small businesses. This office monitors procurement and economic opportunities for small businesses, making the expanded sales authority provided by this bill relevant to their mission of fostering a more inclusive marketplace for local entrepreneurs.

The MOTD promotes Maryland as a premier travel destination and supports tourism-related jobs in the hospitality sector. Legislation that expands the service capabilities of hotels and restaurants in a major jurisdiction like Montgomery County affects the overall visitor experience and the economic health of the local tourism industry.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the General Assembly and state agencies. They are responsible for interpreting and upholding the rule of law within the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article of the Maryland Code, which this bill amends.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the membership composition of the Maryland Commission on Hate Crime Response and Prevention by replacing various specific organization representatives with fifteen individuals who represent or advocate for protected classes under State hate crime laws. It also adds two representatives of the Muslim community, one representative from the Office of the Public Defender, and establishes a termination date for the commission.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of the Attorney General
qa_results.stakeholders: Protected classes under Maryland hate crime laws (based on race, color, religion, sexual orientation, gender identity, disability, national origin, or homelessness), the Muslim community, the Office of the Public Defender, state law enforcement, and the general public.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect State or local operations or finances. Although the bill mandates that the Governor include funds in the State budget to employ a full-time assistant Attorney General and operate the office, the fiscal note indicates no material impact on state finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Commission on Hate Crime Response and Prevention is located within the Office of the Attorney General. The Attorney General is responsible for appointing members, serving as or designating the chair, and providing staff, including a mandated full-time Assistant Attorney General.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly adds one representative of the Office of the Public Defender as a required member of the Commission.
The Maryland Commission on Civil Rights is specifically designated as a permanent member of the Commission on Hate Crime Response and Prevention.
The Maryland Center for School Safety is specifically designated as a permanent member of the Commission, reflecting its role in addressing bias-motivated incidents in K-12 environments.
The Commission is required to submit annual reports to the State Department of Education containing policy recommendations to address hate crimes that occur in schools.
The Governor is legally mandated by the bill to include specific funds in the State budget for the Commission's staffing and operations starting in fiscal year 2025.
DBM is responsible for implementing the bill's mandate to include funding for a full-time Assistant Attorney General and operational expenses for the Commission in the annual operating budget.
GOHS oversees the Maryland Coordination and Analysis Center (MCAC), which is specifically designated as a member of the Commission.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP is the state's central hub for public safety policy and crime reduction initiatives, which aligns with the Commission's mandate to evaluate hate crime laws and develop prevention strategies.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill modifies the structure, membership, and sunset provisions of an executive commission designed to study and provide recommendations on a specific policy area (hate crimes).

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill mandates fixed annual distributions of $27 million from the State Lottery Fund to both the Bus Rapid Transit Fund and the Prince George’s County Blue Line Corridor Facility Fund. It expands the authorized uses for the corridor fund to include all expenses incurred or approved by the Maryland Stadium Authority and requires the authority to submit a development and planning report for the Blue Line Corridor by December 15, 2024.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Stadium Authority, Maryland Department of Transportation, and the Comptroller
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland local governments, Prince George's County, Montgomery County, and transit commuters.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no fiscal impact in FY 2024. In FY 2025, general fund revenues decrease by $8.8 million because the bill increases the mandated distribution to the Blue Line Corridor Facility Fund to $27 million, up from the previously projected $18.2 million. Nonbudgeted revenues and expenditures for the facility fund increase correspondingly. The $27 million annual distribution to the Bus Rapid Transit Fund codifies current projections and does not result in a net fiscal change.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly tasks the Maryland Stadium Authority with administering the Prince George's County Blue Line Corridor Facility Fund and requires the agency to submit a detailed report on development activities and future opportunities in that corridor by December 2024.

The bill alters the distribution of monies from the State Lottery Fund. As the state's chief financial officer and revenue distributor, the Comptroller is responsible for processing these distributions to the Bus Rapid Transit Fund and the Blue Line Corridor Facility Fund.

The bill impacts the Bus Rapid Transit Fund (BRTF), which MDOT administers, and modifies how the department awards grants to eligible counties for bus rapid transit systems. MDOT is also a required consultant for the Blue Line Corridor report.
The bill specifies that the State Treasurer must hold the Prince George's County Blue Line Corridor Facility Fund separately and invest its money in the same manner as other state funds.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill modifies the allocation of funds derived from the State Lottery, which this agency regulates and operates. The changes affect the statutory prioritization and amounts distributed from the agency's proceeds.

The Maryland Stadium Authority is explicitly required to consult and meaningfully engage with the Department of Housing and Community Development to complete the mandated report on the Prince George’s County Blue Line Corridor.

As the state's central fiscal authority, DBM is responsible for revenue estimation and budget oversight. The bill modifies mandated lottery distributions, which directly affects the amount of revenue remaining for the General Fund.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes local governments, including Baltimore City, counties, and municipalities, to grant property tax credits for the construction or substantial rehabilitation of hotels and residential development projects. For residential projects to qualify, they must contain at least 20 units and designate at least 15% of those units as affordable housing for households earning less than 80% of the area median income. Hotel projects must significantly increase the assessed value of the property to be eligible for the credit.
qa_results.responsible_party: Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City, or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation
qa_results.stakeholders: Property developers of hotels and residential projects, local governments in Maryland, and households earning less than 80% of the area median income.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State revenues or expenditures. However, local property tax revenues will decrease beginning in fiscal 2025 to the extent that local jurisdictions choose to authorize the tax credit. The exact fiscal impact on local governments cannot be reliably estimated as it depends on the number of qualifying projects, the assessed values of those properties, and the specific terms of the credits established by local laws.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires that residential development projects must include at least 15% of units affordable to households earning less than 80% of the area median income to qualify for the tax credit. This directly aligns with DHCD's mission to expand access to affordable housing and revitalize communities.

This board hears appeals regarding property tax valuations and the rejection of property tax exemptions or credits. Because the bill establishes specific criteria for local property tax credits, including the requirement that hotels 'substantially increase the assessed value,' disputes over eligibility or valuation would be handled by this agency.

The agency is responsible for coordinating sustainable growth and community revitalization efforts. This bill provides local governments with a financial tool to incentivize urban revitalization and residential/hotel development, which falls under the agency's policy guidance for land use and smart growth.

The bill provides tax incentives specifically for new or rehabilitated hotel projects. As the agency responsible for promoting Maryland as a travel destination and stimulating the economy through tourism, the expansion or improvement of lodging infrastructure is directly relevant to their work.

MEDCO facilitates large-scale development projects and infrastructure, including student housing and community facilities, through revenue bonds and financing. Large hotel or residential developments qualifying for these credits may involve MEDCO partnerships or financing structures.

The Maryland Tax Court is the highest administrative review for tax controversies, including real property assessments and tax credit eligibility. It would serve as the final level of administrative appeal for disputes arising from the implementation of these local credits.

The agency focuses on stimulating private investment and economic development. These tax credits are designed to attract investment in hotels and residential housing, which supports the state's broader economic goals managed by the Department of Commerce.

This multi-agency initiative promotes sustainable growth and economic revitalization. The bill's focus on substantial rehabilitation of existing structures and creating denser residential developments (20+ units) aligns with the initiative's 'smart growth' and community revitalization goals.

The bill alters a specific property tax credit previously authorized for Wicomico County, a rural jurisdiction. RMC advocates for rural interests and community development in the state's 18 rural counties, making this shift in development incentive authority relevant to their mission.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits a person in Calvert County from standing in a roadway, median divider, or intersection for the purpose of soliciting money or donations from the occupant of a vehicle.
qa_results.responsible_party: Calvert County law enforcement and the Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals soliciting donations and vehicle occupants in Calvert County
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State or Calvert County finances or operations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office is responsible for signing the bill into law and oversees the executive departments responsible for enforcing state transportation and public safety laws.
The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor for the state and would be involved in interpreting or defending the enforcement of this addition to the Maryland Transportation Article.
The bill amends the State's Transportation Article and directly impacts the regulation of activity on Maryland's roadways and intersections, which are under MDOT's primary jurisdiction.

As the primary statewide law enforcement agency, the Maryland State Police are responsible for enforcing motor vehicle and roadway safety laws on state highways, including the new solicitation ban in Calvert County.

The AOC was identified as an information source for the fiscal note and is responsible for managing the court systems that will process and adjudicate any violations or citations issued under this law.
As a unit of MDOT, the SHA manages and maintains the physical state highways, medians, and intersections where the solicitation prohibition will be in effect.
The MVA is the MDOT unit responsible for the administration of the Maryland Transportation Article, which contains the specific section being amended by this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a line-of-duty death benefit for members of the Judges' Retirement System (JRS), providing eligible surviving spouses, children, or dependent parents with a return of the member's contributions and an allowance equal to two-thirds of the member's salary. It allows these survivors to enroll in the State health insurance program with the maximum State subsidy. The bill also applies retroactively to JRS members killed in the line of duty prior to the act's effective date.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System
qa_results.stakeholders: Members of the Judges' Retirement System and their surviving spouses, children, and dependent parents, as well as surviving family members of other State employees killed in the line of duty eligible for health insurance subsidies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have no discernible effect on State pension liabilities, contribution rates, or health care costs because it applies to a very limited number of cases. The State Retirement Agency has identified only one individual to whom the retroactive benefit may apply. There is no impact on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Retirement Agency is the primary administrative body for the Judges' Retirement System. The bill tasks the agency and its Board of Trustees with implementing the new line-of-duty death benefits and managing the retroactive application of these benefits for deceased members.

The Administrative Office of the Courts provides the administrative, financial, and budgetary infrastructure for the Maryland Judiciary. Since this bill establishes specific death benefits for members of the Judges' Retirement System, it directly impacts the personnel policies and budgetary considerations for the judicial branch managed by the AOC.

DBM manages the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program. The bill modifies eligibility and subsidy levels for health benefits for the surviving spouses and children of Judges' Retirement System members killed in the line of duty, requiring DBM to coordinate these new insurance provisions.

The State Treasurer serves as a key fiduciary leader and chair of the Board of Trustees for the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System, which includes the Judges' Retirement System. The office is also the principal custodian of the state funds from which these benefits will be paid and invested.

The OAG serves as the chief legal advisor for nearly all state agencies, including the State Retirement Agency and the Administrative Office of the Courts. They will be responsible for providing legal guidance on the interpretation of line-of-duty deaths and ensuring the retroactive provisions of the bill are implemented legally.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies responsible for implementing the bill (SRA and DBM) and is responsible for drafting the state budget, which must account for any fiscal impact related to the new judicial death benefits and health insurance subsidies.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Individuals With Disabilities and Service–Disabled Veterans Boating Fund to provide grant funding to nonprofit organizations that offer sailing, boating, kayaking, canoeing, paddleboarding, and surfing opportunities for individuals with disabilities and service-disabled veterans.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Disabilities
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals with disabilities, service-disabled veterans, and 501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations providing recreational boating and water activities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by at least $47,018 in FY 2025 for the Maryland Department of Disabilities to hire a part-time grants coordinator. Special fund revenues and expenditures increase accordingly. Starting in FY 2026, the Governor is authorized to appropriate $500,000 annually to the fund for grants. Individual grants are capped at $40,000 per fiscal year per grantee. The bill has no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly mandates that the Department of Disabilities (MDOD) shall administer the newly created Individuals With Disabilities and Service-Disabled Veterans Boating Fund, including the grant process and administrative expenses.

The fund specifically targets service-disabled veterans as a primary beneficiary group. The agency acts as an advocate and resource hub for this population and was consulted in the preparation of the bill's fiscal note.

DBM is responsible for formulating the state budget and managing personnel. The bill suggests an annual appropriation of $500,000 and requires the creation of a new part-time grants coordinator position.
The bill supports boating and recreational activities on 'State waters,' which are managed and regulated by the DNR. The agency was also consulted for the fiscal note.
The bill authorizes the Governor to include a specific appropriation for the fund in the annual budget bill starting in fiscal 2026.
The bill explicitly requires the Comptroller to account for the Individuals With Disabilities and Service-Disabled Veterans Boating Fund.
The bill explicitly requires the State Treasurer to hold the newly established special fund separately.
As the primary legal advisor to state agencies, the OAG would likely assist the Department of Disabilities in developing grant regulations and reviewing contracts for the new fund.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Technology Development Corporation (TEDCO) to provide administrative services and support to entities it creates, owns, or controls, and to receive compensation for these services through written agreements.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Technology Development Corporation
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland Technology Development Corporation (TEDCO) and the business entities it creates, owns, or controls, such as corporations, limited liability companies, and partnerships.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is generally clarifying and does not directly increase state expenditures or revenues. TEDCO is explicitly authorized to be reimbursed for administrative costs like marketing and reporting from the entities it supports. There is no local fiscal impact and minimal impact on small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly amends the statutory authority of TEDCO, authorizing it to provide administrative services to its subsidiary entities and receive compensation for doing so.
The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor for state agencies and will be responsible for reviewing and drafting the written agreements required by the bill for TEDCO's administrative services.

OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits of state agencies; it will be responsible for auditing the compensation received by TEDCO and ensuring that administrative service agreements comply with state law.
TEDCO is the state's primary engine for technology-based economic development and frequently coordinates with the Department of Commerce, which has historically transferred programs to TEDCO.

As the central fiscal authority, DBM oversees the efficiency of executive branch operations and the allocation of state resources, including the personnel and budgeting related to TEDCO's expanded administrative functions.
The BPW oversees major state procurement and contracts; it may be involved in approving or reviewing the fiscal frameworks under which TEDCO establishes its administrative service agreements.

The Comptroller acts as the state's fiscal watchdog and sits on the Board of Public Works, overseeing the financial integrity and revenue collection processes that include state-instrumentality activities like TEDCO's.

The Treasurer is responsible for managing and protecting state financial assets and sits on the Board of Public Works, providing oversight for the fiscal management of independent state entities like TEDCO.
As the head of the executive branch, the Governor oversees TEDCO's operations and signed this legislation into law as part of the state's broader economic development strategy.
The Innovation Team works with small businesses and state agencies to modernize services and drive economic mobility, which overlaps with TEDCO's mission to support high-growth business entities.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes that the competitive sealed proposal procurement method is the preferred method for state agencies to solicit security services for contracts with an expected value greater than $1,000,000.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State procurement units, the Department of General Services, and the Board of Public Works
qa_results.stakeholders: Security service providers and Maryland State agencies
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to have a material effect on State operations or finances. There is no local impact and the impact on small businesses is expected to be minimal. The bill codifies a preference for a procurement method that allows agencies to consider evaluation factors other than just the lowest price for high-value security contracts.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Board of Public Works is the highest administrative authority for state procurement and is responsible for approving major contracts, including those for security services exceeding $1,000,000 affected by this bill. The fiscal note also identifies them as an information source.

As a primary procurement unit for the state, DGS is responsible for the procurement of services for state facilities, including security. The bill directly changes the preferred method for the high-value security contracts DGS manages.

The bill explicitly requires the Office of the Attorney General to provide written approval if a procurement officer allows an offeror to correct or withdraw a proposal or best and final offer under Section 13-104(e)(2)(ii).

MDOT is a primary procurement unit that manages massive security contracts for its business units, such as BWI Thurgood Marshall Airport and the Maryland Transit Administration, which frequently exceed the $1,000,000 threshold established by the bill.

DBM serves as a primary procurement unit and a central fiscal authority for the state. It oversees significant service contracts and will be responsible for implementing this preferred procurement method for relevant security services under its jurisdiction.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that requests for proposals for these security contracts include factors regarding the expected degree of Minority Business Enterprise (MBE) participation, which this office is responsible for monitoring across state agencies.
The Comptroller sits on the Board of Public Works and is responsible for reviewing and approving the high-value security contracts that must now prioritize the competitive sealed proposal method.

The Treasurer holds a seat on the Board of Public Works and participates in the approval of significant state contracts, including the $1,000,000+ security service contracts impacted by this legislation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes certain volunteer fire company officers and fire police to equip their privately owned vehicles with specific colored lights, including red and white for officers and red, red and green, or red and white for fire police, for use during emergencies or at emergency scenes.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation Motor Vehicle Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Volunteer fire company officers, emergency medical services commanders, and fire police.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect State finances or operations and does not directly affect local government finances as it is authorizing in nature.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the chief executive, the Governor signs or vetoes legislation and oversees the operations of all state departments and agencies tasked with implementing changes to the Maryland Vehicle Law.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for state agencies like the Maryland State Police and the Department of Transportation, providing guidance on the enforcement and implementation of new vehicle equipment laws.
The bill impacts volunteer fire companies and rescue squads, which are critical components of the state’s disaster response and emergency management infrastructure coordinated by this department.
The bill amends the Transportation Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland, which is the primary legal framework managed and operated by the Department of Transportation and its business units.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency is explicitly mentioned in the bill's statutory amendments and coordinates the state’s emergency medical services, including the EMS commanders who are granted expanded lighting permissions for their vehicles.

As the primary statewide law enforcement agency, the State Police are responsible for enforcing motor vehicle laws, ensuring highway safety, and monitoring the lawful use of authorized signal devices on Maryland roadways.

The MVA regulates vehicle equipment standards and governs the administration of the Maryland Vehicle Law, which is directly modified by this bill to authorize new lighting for private emergency responder vehicles.

The SHA manages state highway safety and roadside operations, where volunteer fire police and emergency responders utilizing these authorized lights would be active during traffic accidents and other road emergencies.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Freedom to Read Act establishes state-level standards for Maryland's school and public libraries, prohibiting the exclusion or removal of materials based on the creator's background or partisan, ideological, or religious disapproval. It requires local school systems to develop uniform procedures for handling library material objections and protects library employees from retaliation for adhering to these standards. Compliance with these standards is a condition for receiving state library funding, which the Comptroller may withhold for non-compliance.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Library Board, Maryland State Library Agency, and the State Comptroller
qa_results.stakeholders: Students, parents, school and public library personnel, and the general public using state-funded library services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland State Library Agency can implement the bill's requirements using existing resources. There is no significant impact on state or local revenues or expenditures, though state funding for libraries is now contingent on compliance with the new standards. The State Comptroller is authorized to withhold existing state funding from libraries or regional resource centers that fail to adopt policies consistent with the Freedom to Read Act standards.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Library Agency (MSLA) is the primary agency responsible for implementing the bill. It is tasked with developing policies that align with State Standards for Libraries, ensuring compliance from State-funded libraries, and certifying to the Comptroller if a library has failed to meet these standards to trigger funding withholding.

The bill establishes State policy for school library media programs, which are overseen by the Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE). MSDE must ensure local school systems follow the new standards regarding material selection, removal, and objection procedures.

The bill explicitly requires the State Comptroller to withhold funding from public libraries, regional resource centers, or county library systems upon certification from the State Library Board that the entity has failed to meet the State Standards for Libraries.

The bill provides specific protections against retaliation for library personnel who perform their duties consistent with State standards. As the entity overseeing collective bargaining and labor relations for state, school, and higher education employees, PERB would handle disputes or unfair labor practice charges arising from these protections.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill's definition of 'library' specifically includes the Maryland Deaf Culture Digital Library, which is a key resource for the constituents served by this office. The office would be interested in the equitable access and non-discrimination provisions of the bill.

As a state-funded educational institution with library facilities, MSD must ensure its library programs and personnel management comply with the standards and anti-retaliation provisions established by the bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill includes 'correctional facility library' in its definition of libraries that must operate in a manner consistent with State standards. DPSCS would need to ensure their institutional libraries comply to maintain potential state support.

The bill establishes standards prohibiting the exclusion of materials based on origin, background, or views, which aligns with the MCCR's mission to enforce anti-discrimination in public accommodations (including libraries).

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the State Library Agency and MSDE. They would be responsible for providing legal counsel on the implementation of these standards and defending the state in the event of litigation regarding the First Amendment or personnel disputes.

DBM oversees the state's personnel system and annual budget. While the bill uses existing resources, DBM is involved in the overall funding and administrative oversight of the library resource centers and school systems affected by the bill's fiscal mandates.
OAH may be used as a forum for administrative hearings if state library employees contest disciplinary actions or if local systems challenge state decisions regarding funding withholding.

OLA conducts fiscal and performance audits of state agencies. They may be tasked with auditing whether the Maryland State Library Agency and local libraries are in compliance with the fiscal requirements and standards set forth in this bill.

The bill specifically applies to the Maryland State Library for the Blind and Print Disabled. MDOD works to ensure state programs are accessible and equitable for residents with disabilities, coinciding with the bill's focus on universal access.

The Governor signs or vetoes legislation and oversees the executive agencies (MSDE, MSLA) responsible for implementation. The bill sets a significant state policy regarding First Amendment principles and educational standards that align with executive branch priorities.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the State Board of Dental Examiners to waive certain education requirements for applicants seeking a limited license to practice dentistry for adults, extending a waiver program that was previously limited to pediatric dentistry. It establishes a pathway for these practitioners—typically foreign-trained dentists—to obtain a general license after completing a two-year service commitment in public health clinics, federally qualified health centers, or Maryland qualified health centers.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Dental Examiners
qa_results.stakeholders: Foreign-trained dentists, adult dental patients in underserved areas, local health departments, and federally or Maryland qualified health centers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The State Board of Dental Examiners can implement the bill using existing budgeted resources. There is no expected impact on state revenues. Local health departments may benefit from a larger pool of dental professionals to fill vacancies in adult dental programs, with associated impacts absorbed within existing budgets.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Health oversees the State Board of Dental Examiners, which is the primary body responsible for issuing the limited licenses and granting the education waivers mentioned in the bill. The agency also coordinates the public health dental clinics and Medicaid services that are the primary practice sites for these licensees.

The University of Maryland School of Dentistry (a USM institution) is specifically named in the bill as a site for the dental fellowships required for the waiver, and its Dean is involved in requesting waivers from the State Board of Dental Examiners.

The bill expands limited licenses to include adult dentistry, which directly impacts the access to oral healthcare for Maryland's older adult population, a primary focus of this department's advocacy and service preparation.

This agency handles medical assistance eligibility and services for indigent and uninsured residents, who are the primary patient populations the bill's licensees are contractually obligated to serve.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to the State Board of Dental Examiners and would be responsible for advising the Board on the implementation and enforcement of these new licensing and waiver regulations.
As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing the legislation and overseeing the operations of the Department of Health and the State Board of Dental Examiners.

DBM oversees the state's personnel and fiscal management; the fiscal note indicates that the bill's administrative requirements will be managed within existing budgeted resources overseen by this agency.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Allegany Regional Recreational Economic Development Authority in Allegany County to support the development and construction of regional recreation facilities, such as athletic fields and indoor sports complexes, to promote economic development and recreational tourism for the benefit of county residents.
qa_results.responsible_party: Allegany Regional Recreational Economic Development Authority
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents of Allegany County, local government entities in Cumberland and Frostburg, Frostburg State University, Allegany College, and the Allegany County Board of Education.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no direct effect on State or local revenues because it does not require or mandate specific appropriations. State and local authority members are expected to use existing resources for staff support and expense reimbursements. While the authority may manage future funds from the State or local governments for regional recreation facilities, such expenditures are contingent on future appropriations not required by this bill.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The President of Frostburg State University, which is a constituent institution of the University System of Maryland, is a designated member of the newly established Authority. The fiscal note also identifies USM as an information source for the impact of this bill.

The bill establishes an economic development authority under the Economic Development Article with a focus on stimulating the regional economy and tourism, which are core components of the Department of Commerce's mission.

A primary duty of the new Authority is to develop facilities specifically designed to create 'recreational tourism,' a goal that aligns directly with the Office of Tourism Development's mission to stimulate the economy through travel promotion.
The Authority is required to report its activities and progress annually to the Governor. Additionally, the office oversees all state departments and regional initiatives of this nature.

The Authority is authorized to manage state-appropriated funds, and its members are entitled to travel reimbursements provided in the state budget, which is overseen by DBM. DBM also oversees the fiscal accountability of such entities.

Because the Authority may receive and manage state-appropriated funds for construction projects, significant capital improvement contracts or real estate acquisitions would likely require approval from the Board of Public Works.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Authority functions as a specialized executive body that brings together state, local, and academic leaders to address the specific public concern of regional recreational and economic development.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the County Commissioners of Carroll County to borrow up to $29,800,000 through the issuance and sale of general obligation bonds to finance the acquisition, construction, or improvement of various public facilities. These projects include public schools, roads, bridges, water and sewer infrastructure, and agricultural land preservation easements. Additionally, the funds may be used to provide loans to volunteer fire departments for fire or emergency-related equipment and facilities.
qa_results.responsible_party: County Commissioners of Carroll County
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents of Carroll County, Carroll County Government, Carroll County Public Schools, Carroll Community College, and volunteer fire departments within the county.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no impact on State finances. Carroll County will receive up to $29.8 million in bond proceeds. Local debt service expenditures are estimated to increase by approximately $2.1 million annually over a 20-year period, assuming a 3.37% interest rate.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the chief executive, the Governor is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation. Governor Wes Moore signed this bill into law on May 9, 2024.

The bond proceeds are primarily allocated to public school facilities, including HVAC replacements, roof replacements, and kindergarten/PreK additions, totaling over $20.8 million of the authorized amount.
The IAC oversees and funds the construction, renovation, and maintenance of public school facilities in Maryland, which constitutes the majority of the projects funded by this bond authorization.

The bill explicitly authorizes the county to use installment purchase obligations for the acquisition of agricultural land and woodland preservation easements, with specific funding listed in the fiscal note.
The bill authorizes funding for water and sewer infrastructure facilities, watershed assessments, and stormwater facility renovations.
The bond includes funding for public works projects such as roads, bridges, and storm drains, which fall under the scope of transportation infrastructure.
The Comptroller is the state's tax collector; the bill specifies that the bonds, interest, and income derived from them are exempt from State and local taxation.
The bill includes Carroll Community College buildings and facilities within the definition of public facilities that may be financed by the bond proceeds.
Public libraries are explicitly mentioned as eligible public facilities for construction or improvement using the authorized bond funds.
DBM is the central fiscal authority responsible for estimating state revenues and overseeing the budget; it monitors the fiscal impact of tax exemptions and state authorizations for local debt.
The bill authorizes loans for fire or emergency-related equipment and buildings for volunteer fire departments, which relates to the state's emergency management and public safety coordination.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the legal procedures for individuals committed to the Maryland Department of Health after being found not criminally responsible. It applies Maryland Rules for civil discovery to administrative release proceedings, requires the Department of Health to share clinical reports and evaluations with legal parties upon request, and establishes a preponderance of the evidence standard for applicants seeking to change their conditional release status.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals found not criminally responsible and committed to the Maryland Department of Health, the Office of the Public Defender, State's Attorneys' offices, and the Maryland Department of Health staff.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by an estimated $377,041 in FY 2025, rising to $500,600 by FY 2029, to support six new positions at the Maryland Department of Health required to handle discovery requests and additional court hearings. No impact on State revenues is expected. Local governments may experience operational efficiencies in State's Attorneys' offices but no material fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates specific court actions, including providing notifications to the Health Department and counsel of record, and requiring courts to hold hearings upon request regarding changes in conditional release. The AOC supports the Judiciary in implementing these procedural changes.

The fiscal note indicates a significant increase in general fund expenditures (estimated at $377,000 in FY 2025) to accommodate new personnel and procedural requirements, which falls under the oversight of DBM's budget management responsibilities.

MDH is the primary agency responsible for committed persons found not criminally responsible. The bill requires MDH to notify parties of release violations, provide comprehensive reports and documents on request, and handle new discovery requirements, resulting in a notable fiscal impact for additional staff.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's central hub for public safety and criminal justice policy, GOCPP is relevant to legislation modifying criminal procedure and the oversight of individuals committed following criminal proceedings.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: OPD represents the majority of indigent committed persons in these proceedings. The bill significantly impacts their practice by granting access to civil discovery in administrative hearings and ensuring they receive mandatory notifications regarding their clients' release status.

OAH conducts the administrative hearings for conditional release or discharge. The bill establishes that Maryland Rules for civil discovery apply to these OAH proceedings, requiring ALJs to manage discovery disputes and procedural training.

The OAG provides legal counsel to the Maryland Department of Health. The bill's discovery provisions will require OAG's involvement in managing information requests and representing the state in administrative and court proceedings.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters distance and zoning restrictions for cannabis dispensaries and growers, prohibiting local governments from imposing zoning requirements on cannabis businesses that are more restrictive than those for similar entities like retail alcohol dealers or hemp farms. It also establishes a process for at least 10 nearby residents, commercial tenants, or property owners to file a formal protest against the renewal of a cannabis license with the Maryland Cannabis Administration (MCA) based on specific violations or disturbances of the public peace.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Cannabis Administration (MCA)
qa_results.stakeholders: Cannabis dispensaries, outdoor cannabis growers, local governments, and residents or business owners located within 1,000 feet of a cannabis facility.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Special fund expenditures for the Maryland Cannabis Administration (MCA) may increase minimally between fiscal 2028 and 2030 to manage license renewal protests, with estimated costs of $44,100 in FY 2028 and $78,700 in FY 2029. Because MCA administrative costs are paid from cannabis tax revenue before distribution, any increase in these costs will cause a corresponding minimal decrease in tax revenues distributed to the State general fund, other special funds, and local governments. Local zoning departments are expected to implement the bill's provisions using existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary regulator for the cannabis industry, the MCA is the central agency responsible for implementing the bill's provisions, managing license renewals, and overseeing the new protest and hearing process.

The fiscal note indicates that the MCA currently delegates its hearing authority to the OAH. This agency will be responsible for conducting the hearings resulting from protests against cannabis license renewals.

The Comptroller manages the distribution of cannabis sales and use tax revenues. The bill's fiscal note highlights that minimal increases in MCA expenditures will affect the distribution of funds to the General Fund and other special accounts managed by the Comptroller.
The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the MCA and would be involved in defending the state's zoning restrictions and the administrative protest process established by the bill.

The bill directly impacts land use policy by limiting the ability of political subdivisions to establish zoning requirements for cannabis businesses, a core area of coordination for the Department of Planning.
The bill benchmarks zoning requirements for outdoor cannabis growers against the requirements for hemp farms, which are registered and regulated under the Department of Agriculture.
The bill sets specific distance restrictions for dispensaries relative to schools and child care centers, both of which are regulated or overseen by the MSDE.
DBM oversees state personnel and fiscal accountability; the fiscal note identifies a need for additional contractual staff at the MCA to handle the increased workload from license renewal protests.
The Department of Commerce administers the Cannabis Business Assistance Fund, which receives a portion of the tax revenues that could be minimally affected by the fiscal impacts noted in the bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS manages the Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS), which is used for the fingerprinting and background checks required for the cannabis license renewal process discussed in the bill.

Protests against license renewals can be based on conduct that 'disturbs the public peace,' such as assault, battery, or disorderly conduct, which involves law enforcement standards and criminal law violations.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch agencies involved in the bill's implementation and is responsible for signing the legislation and coordinating statewide public safety initiatives related to the cannabis industry.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill transitions the practice model for physician assistants (PAs) in Maryland from a delegation agreement with a supervising physician to a collaboration agreement with a patient care team physician. It authorizes PAs to perform medical acts consistent with their education, training, and experience as outlined in their collaboration agreements. The act updates licensure requirements, expands the number of PAs a physician may collaborate with, and requires the State Board of Physicians to update the list of advanced duties that PAs are permitted to perform.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Physicians
qa_results.stakeholders: Physician assistants, licensed physicians, healthcare facilities, and patients in Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The State Board of Physicians (MBP) can implement the bill using existing budgeted resources. Special fund revenues are not expected to be materially affected; while there may be a loss in revenue from delegation agreement fees, MBP may impose new fees for collaboration agreements that include advanced duties. There is no local fiscal impact. Small businesses involving physician assistant practices may experience a meaningful impact due to the expanded scope of practice.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) houses the State Board of Physicians, which is the primary regulatory body responsible for licensing physician assistants (PAs), reviewing collaboration agreements, and updating the list of advanced duties as required by the bill.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the State Board of Physicians and would be involved in defending regulatory changes, handling disciplinary appeals, and ensuring the new collaboration agreement framework complies with state law.

The bill amends the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article to explicitly include physician assistants in the definition of a 'health care provider' for the purposes of medical malpractice claims, affecting judicial proceedings and court records.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically addresses physician assistant practice and supervision ratios within correctional facilities and detention centers, which are managed by DPSCS.

The bill amends the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article to update the requirements for physician assistants acting as certifying providers for medical cannabis, replacing delegation agreements with collaboration agreements.

The OAH adjudicates contested cases for state agencies, including the State Board of Physicians; changes to PA licensing, scope of practice, and disciplinary procedures will impact the hearings managed by this office.
The bill amends the Education Article regarding the authority of physician assistants to perform required physical examinations for students and updates definitions related to PA licensure.

The bill updates the definition of a licensed physician assistant within the Transportation Article, specifically regarding their authority to certify disabilities for special registration plates managed by the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA).
The bill alters the educational and accreditation requirements for PA licensure, which relates to MHEC's oversight of academic programs and student financial assistance for healthcare professions.

USM institutions (such as the University of Maryland, Baltimore) operate physician assistant training programs that must align their curriculum and degree requirements with the new licensure standards established by the bill.

The bill authorizes physician assistants who are federal employees to perform medical acts during declared disasters, which falls under MDEM's coordination of emergency response and healthcare resources.
DBM oversees the fiscal notes and personnel standards for state agencies; they must monitor the implementation of these regulatory changes by the State Board of Physicians within the MDH budget.

As the executive authority, the Governor's Office oversaw the signing of this legislation and provides policy direction for the healthcare regulatory boards and emergency disaster protocols mentioned in the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill redefines 'aerial survey' as 'SAV survey' to allow for alternative methodologies for mapping submerged aquatic vegetation in the Chesapeake Bay and Atlantic Coastal Bays. It requires the Department of Natural Resources (DNR) to study and report on the feasibility and implications of using alternative methods for delineating SAV protection zones by December 1, 2025.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Commercial fishermen, aquaculture lease applicants, and environmental conservation organizations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures are not directly affected as the Department of Natural Resources can conduct the required study with existing budgeted resources. General fund expenditures could increase by an unknown amount if DNR chooses to implement additional survey methods in the future. The bill has no material impact on local government finances or operations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for delineating SAV protection zones and managing the state's living resources, DNR is tasked with conducting the study, submitting the report to the General Assembly, and overseeing the expanded methodologies for SAV surveys.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Council on the Chesapeake Bay
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This council integrates the efforts of various departments to protect and restore the Chesapeake Bay; SAV mapping is a critical metric for their regional restoration goals and interagency policy coordination.
MDE is specifically mentioned in the fiscal note as a contributor to SAV survey funding and relies on SAV data for regulatory work related to water clarity attainment and environmental restoration.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates the state's smart growth and environmental stewardship efforts; updating SAV survey definitions and protection zones is central to its mission of improving the health of the Chesapeake Bay.
The Trust awards millions in grants for Bay restoration; accurate and expanded SAV survey data is vital for their grant-making decisions and evaluating the impact of local restoration projects.
MES manages environmental infrastructure and restoration projects, such as nutrient reduction in the Bay, which are directly informed by the health and distribution of submerged aquatic vegetation.

The MPA is responsible for dredging shipping channels; since SAV protection zones restrict certain dredging activities, the methodologies and delineations established by this bill directly impact their operations.

As a member of the Chesapeake Bay Cabinet, the department's resource conservation efforts are linked to the health of the Bay's aquatic vegetation, which acts as a key indicator of the success of agricultural runoff management.
The department coordinates land use and sustainable growth; these policies impact the runoff and water quality that directly influence the growth and protection of SAV beds mapped under this bill.

SAV mapping is a regional effort involving interstate partnerships, such as the Virginia Institute of Marine Science and the EPA Chesapeake Bay Program, which are central to the survey methodologies discussed in the bill.
The bill impacts rural economic interests by regulating the use of commercial gear (like hydraulic clam dredges) in SAV protection zones, particularly in the state's tidal rural counties.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a local delivery service permit that allows third-party contractors, independent contractors, or agents to deliver alcoholic beverages from authorized retail license holders to purchasers within the same jurisdiction. It sets specific requirements for delivery, including a $1,000 annual permit fee, age requirements for delivery personnel and recipients, and a structured penalty system for violations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Local licensing boards and the Executive Director of the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage retail license holders, third-party delivery services, independent contractors, and Maryland consumers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Local government revenues will increase by $1,000 for each permit issued and may further increase from fine revenues ranging from $1,000 to $6,000 per violation. State revenues and expenditures are not materially affected. Local licensing boards are expected to manage the permit process and enforcement within existing budgeted resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes a penalty framework including fines and permit revocations for violations of delivery regulations. The Administrative Office of the Courts manages the judicial infrastructure for any subsequent appeals or legal challenges that enter the court system.

As the state's chief tax collector and fiscal watchdog, the Comptroller oversees sales and use tax collection and various business licenses. This bill impacts the regulatory and fiscal landscape for retail alcohol sales and delivery services.

DBM oversees the Governor's annual operating budget and estimates state revenues. It is responsible for the fiscal oversight and personnel management of the state commissions tasked with implementing and enforcing the new permit regulations.

The Department of Commerce supports business expansion and private investment. This bill creates a new commercial framework for retail license holders and third-party delivery contractors to expand their operations through regulated alcohol delivery.

MDH oversees public health and substance use disorder prevention. The regulation and expansion of alcohol delivery services have implications for community health standards and the agency's mission to manage substance-related initiatives.

The bill sets specific age requirements (21+) for delivery drivers. MDOT, via the Motor Vehicle Administration, manages driver licensing and ensures compliance with state laws regarding driver eligibility and road safety.
The Governor's Office oversees the operations of all state departments, including the commissions responsible for alcoholic beverage regulation. The Governor also signed this legislation into law.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP coordinates statewide public safety policies and initiatives to reduce substance abuse. The bill's provisions regarding delivery restrictions and age verification align with the office's crime prevention and public safety goals.

The Maryland State Police enforce criminal and motor vehicle laws. They are responsible for investigating violations related to public safety, including the illegal distribution of alcohol and ensuring compliance with age-restricted sales.

OAH adjudicates contested cases for state agencies. If a state regulatory body takes enforcement action or denies a permit under this bill, OAH provides the impartial forum for residents and businesses to challenge those decisions.

OLA conducts fiscal and compliance audits of state agencies. They would be responsible for auditing the regulatory bodies that manage the new permit system to ensure fees are collected and laws are followed properly.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the state agencies and commissions implementing this bill. It will provide counsel on drafting regulations for the local delivery service permits and defend the state in any related legal proceedings.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a standardized process for the removal or suspension of members of State boards, committees, commissions, task forces, or workgroups created by State law. It allows the appointing individual or entity to remove or suspend a member for misconduct, incompetence, neglect of duties, or other good cause, provided they first consult with the body's chair and give the member notice and an opportunity to be heard.
qa_results.responsible_party: Appointing authorities of State boards, committees, commissions, task forces, or workgroups
qa_results.stakeholders: Members of Maryland State boards, committees, commissions, task forces, and workgroups, and the individuals or entities that appoint them.
