The bill includes significant provisions prohibiting the marketing and advertising of tianeptine products to minors, which falls within the Governor's Office for Children's mission to lead policy actions that improve the well-being of Maryland's youth.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill repeals a legal provision that prohibited the Maryland Department of Natural Resources from reducing or altering the boundaries of specific oyster sanctuaries until an updated fishery management plan was developed. It requires the management plan to focus on ending overfishing, increasing oyster abundance and habitat, and facilitating sustainable harvests for the public fishery.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Commercial oyster harvesters, the Oyster Advisory Commission, the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science, and the public oyster fishery.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no direct effect on State or local finances. There are no anticipated changes to revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Natural Resources is the primary agency responsible for managing Maryland's oyster stock, establishing and altering sanctuary boundaries, and developing the fishery management plans mandated by this bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Oyster Advisory Commission is specifically tasked by the bill to lead a facilitated consensus solutions process and develop management recommendations to increase oyster abundance.

The bill explicitly requires DNR to coordinate with the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science (a USM unit) for the development of science-based modeling tools and scientific determination of management strategies.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Council on the Chesapeake Bay
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the coordinating body for Bay-related policies, this council is directly impacted by changes to oyster management strategies, which are a cornerstone of Chesapeake Bay restoration and health.
The bill requires the Department of Natural Resources to submit multiple interim and final reports on the development of oyster management recommendations directly to the Governor.
The bill includes nitrogen removal as a key metric for evaluating the impacts of management actions, a domain that directly relates to the environmental and water quality mandates overseen by MDE.
This multi-agency initiative focuses on sustainable Chesapeake Bay health, which aligns with the bill’s mandates for scientific management, increasing oyster abundance, and habitat protection.
The Office of the Attorney General provides the necessary legal counsel to DNR for drafting management plans and implementing the statutory repeal of boundary restrictions.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the expiration dates for two specific Class B-D-7 alcoholic beverages licenses in Baltimore City—located in the 5517 block of Harford Road and the 2200 block of East Fayette Street—to July 1, 2025, for the purposes of transfer or renewal. These extensions are contingent upon the license applicants entering into a memorandum of understanding with their respective local community associations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license holders and applicants in Baltimore City, the Hamilton Community Association, and the Cleaning, Active, Restoring, Efforts (C.A.R.E.) Community Association.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no effect on State finances. Baltimore City revenues may increase minimally in fiscal 2025 from license renewal fees ($50) and annual fees ($1,320) if the specified transfers and renewals occur.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the chief executive office, the Governor is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation passed by the General Assembly, including this bill which specifically concludes with 'Approved by the Governor, May 16, 2024.'

The Comptroller's Office is responsible for tax collection and general business license oversight in Maryland. Alcohol license transfers and renewals typically require tax clearances from the Comptroller's Office to ensure the business is in good standing before local boards can process administrative changes.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the Governor and state agencies, and is responsible for ensuring that legislation (such as these specific license extensions) conforms to the state code and the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Higher Education Commission (MHEC), the Maryland Department of Labor, and the Department of Commerce to collaborate on identifying state and regional workforce needs to inform postsecondary education policies. It overhauls the process for academic program approval and institutional mission statement reviews, emphasizing workforce alignment, preventing unnecessary program duplication, and protecting historically Black colleges and universities (HBCUs) from programs that cause demonstrable harm. Additionally, the bill establishes a grant fund to incentivize institutions to collaborate on new graduate programs and mandates the creation of an administrative procedures guide for program reviews.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission, Maryland Department of Labor, and Department of Commerce
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland public and private institutions of higher education, historically Black colleges and universities (HBCUs), postsecondary students, and the Maryland workforce.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund expenditures increase by at least $264,000 in FY 2025 to cover staffing costs at MHEC and the Department of Labor, as well as one-time data setup costs for the Maryland Longitudinal Data System Center. Ongoing annual expenditures are estimated between $195,900 and $222,900 through FY 2029. The bill also establishes the Proposed Programs Collaborative Grant Fund; while its capitalization is not mandated, any state funding for the grant would increase general fund expenditures and special fund activity. Local community colleges and public four-year institutions may face indeterminate fiscal impacts due to changes in program approval processes and potential collaboration incentives.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for postsecondary education oversight in Maryland, MHEC is tasked with implementing the bill's major provisions, including the academic program review process, the Proposed Programs Collaborative Grant Fund, the state higher education plan updates, and the robust review of institutional mission statements.

The bill mandates that the Department of Labor designate staff to define and identify state workforce needs and work collaboratively with MHEC and the Department of Commerce to produce consistent baseline data to inform postsecondary education policy.

The bill requires the Department of Commerce to identify and compile data on state and regional workforce needs and collaborate with MHEC and the Department of Labor to ensure baseline data is uniform for state education policies.

MHEC is required to consult with the MLDS Center to identify workforce needs. The fiscal note indicates that the Center will incur significant one-time costs to incorporate additional data sets and labor market projections into its system.

As a historically Black college and the state's preeminent urban research university, Morgan State is specifically granted first-mover rights to propose programs in emerging workforce needs and is directly affected by the new graduate program approval and mission statement review requirements.

The bill directly impacts the USM and several of its constituent institutions (Bowie State, Coppin State, UMES, and UMCP), which are granted specific roles in the emerging workforce program process and are subject to modified program approval and letter of intent requirements.

MHEC is required to consult with the Attorney General to adopt regulations for standards for conducting analysis of program duplication objections, particularly regarding equal educational opportunity obligations.

The bill establishes the Proposed Programs Collaborative Grant Fund, and the Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the fund's assets and managing interest accruals as part of the state's financial reporting.
The State Treasurer is tasked with holding the new Proposed Programs Collaborative Grant Fund and managing its investment in the same manner as other state money.

DBM is responsible for the fiscal oversight and personnel management associated with the new staff positions required by the bill at MHEC and the Department of Labor, as highlighted in the fiscal note.

The Governor's Office oversees the Secretary of Higher Education, who is a member of the Governor's Executive Council, and ensures that the Commission's updated State Plan for Higher Education aligns with the administration's broader economic and workforce priorities.
As a public institution of higher education, Saint Mary's College is subject to the bill's new letter of intent requirements for graduate programs and the modified mission statement approval process.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Distributed Renewable Integration and Vehicle Electrification (DRIVE) Act requires investor-owned electric companies to offer opt-in time-of-use (TOU) tariffs and establish enrollment targets for those tariffs by 2028. It directs the Public Service Commission (PSC) to develop regulations for the interconnection of bidirectional electric vehicle systems and to establish pilot programs or temporary tariffs that compensate owners and aggregators of distributed energy resources for providing distribution system support services. Additionally, the bill authorizes the PSC to require incentives or rebates for renewable on-site generating systems, specifically prioritizing low- and moderate-income customers, and allows utilities to recover reasonable costs associated with these programs.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Public Service Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Investor-owned electric companies, residential and commercial electricity customers, low- and moderate-income households, electric vehicle owners with bidirectional charging equipment, and owners or aggregators of distributed energy resources.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures for the Public Service Commission increase by $410,600 in FY 2025, rising to approximately $458,500 by FY 2028, to cover the costs of new staff and technical consultants. These costs are offset by a corresponding increase in special fund revenues from assessments on public service companies. The Office of People’s Counsel may also see an increase in expenditures. There is no material impact on local government finances, although local governments and small businesses may experience changes in electricity costs as utility customers.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Public Service Commission (PSC) is the primary implementing agency for the DRIVE Act. The bill mandates the PSC to adopt regulations for interconnecting bidirectional electric vehicle systems, develop pilot programs for distributed energy resource compensation, review time-of-use tariffs, and report to the General Assembly on grid impacts.

The Office of the People's Counsel (OPC) is responsible for advocating for residential utility consumers. The fiscal note indicates that OPC will need to participate in the complex proceedings initiated by this bill, such as reviewing new tariffs and pilot programs, which may lead to increased expenditures.

The bill explicitly requires the PSC to consult with the Maryland Energy Administration (MEA) to ensure that upfront incentives and rebates for renewable on-site generating systems are designed to supplement existing state and federal programs.

The bill's primary goal is to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions and support the state's climate goals through electrification and renewable energy integration, which aligns with the Department of the Environment's mission to lead Maryland's climate change initiatives.

As the agency overseeing vehicle registration and sustainable transportation solutions, MDOT is impacted by provisions regarding bidirectional electric vehicle (EV) systems and the broader goal of vehicle electrification (the DRIVE Act).

The Department of General Services (DGS) manages state facilities and ensures their energy efficiency. As a major consumer of electricity, the transition of state buildings to time-of-use tariffs under this bill will directly impact DGS's operational costs and energy management strategies.

The Department of Budget and Management (DBM) oversees the state's personnel system and budget. The fiscal note indicates the need for new permanent positions at the PSC and potentially the OPC to handle the technical modeling and reporting required by the bill.

The fiscal note assumes the PSC will hire consultants for significant amounts ($250,000 annually) to assist with grid modeling and incentive design. Such procurement contracts typically require approval from the Board of Public Works.

The Maryland Clean Energy Center (MCEC) is tasked with accelerating the adoption of clean energy and facilitating grid modernization. The DRIVE Act's focus on distributed energy resources and innovative tariffs directly supports MCEC's core mission.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates state efforts on energy efficiency and resource conservation. The bill's focus on load management and renewable on-site generating systems aligns with the initiative's goal of balancing growth with sustainability.
As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office provides oversight for the statewide initiatives related to greenhouse gas reduction and grid reliability that are central to the DRIVE Act.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands health insurance coverage requirements by including image-guided breast biopsies in the definition of supplemental breast examinations and prohibiting cost-sharing for them. It also mandates coverage for lung cancer screening and follow-up diagnostic imaging, while prohibiting insurers from requiring prior authorization for these lung-related services.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents with health insurance, health insurance carriers, nonprofit health service plans, health maintenance organizations (HMOs), and local governments providing fully insured health benefits.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund revenues for the Maryland Insurance Administration will increase minimally from $125 rate and form filing fees in FY 2025. There is no impact on the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program as it already complies. Local governments purchasing fully insured plans may experience a minimal increase in insurance expenditures, and small business impacts are expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MIA is the primary regulator responsible for enforcing insurance mandates in Maryland. This bill specifically amends the Insurance Article to expand coverage requirements and prohibit prior authorization for breast and lung cancer screenings, which MIA must oversee through rate and form filing reviews.

MHCC is responsible for health system planning and was specifically tasked with studying the financial impact of eliminating health insurance cost sharing for image-guided biopsies, a central component of this bill's provisions.

MHBE administers the state's health insurance marketplace. The new mandates for breast and lung cancer screening coverage apply to private health plans offered on the Maryland Health Connection, requiring the exchange to ensure qualified health plans comply with the new standards.

DBM manages the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program. As a major purchaser of health insurance for the state's workforce, it must ensure its programs and contracts comply with the updated coverage and prior authorization mandates.

The Maryland Department of Health promotes public health and disease prevention. The expansion of cancer screening coverage aligns with its mission to ensure equitable access to quality care and improve statewide health outcomes.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies responsible for implementing these health mandates and the Governor signed this specific legislation into law as Chapter 868.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of the Environment to allow nonuniform payment schedules for contracts under the Clean Water Commerce Account for projects involving construction, reconstruction, or rehabilitation. It permits payment structures where the cost-per-pound of nitrogen reduced varies based on performance milestones and authorizes the department to require financial protections, such as performance bonds or letters of credit, for contracts exceeding $500,000.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
qa_results.stakeholders: Local governments, small businesses, and private project owners involved in water quality and nitrogen load reduction projects.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not change the overall $20 million annual transfer from the Bay Restoration Fund to the Clean Water Commerce Account, but it alters the structure of contract payments. The Maryland Department of the Environment will incur modest additional administrative costs starting in FY 2025 due to the increased complexity of managing nonuniform payment schedules. Local governments and small businesses may experience significant financial impacts depending on project competitiveness and the requirement for financial protections on larger contracts.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MDE is the primary agency responsible for the Clean Water Commerce Account (CWCA) and is the entity mandated by the bill to implement nonuniform payment schedules, require financial protections for large contracts, and verify environmental outcomes.

The CWCA is used to purchase nitrogen load reductions, which often result from agricultural resource conservation and nutrient management practices overseen by the MDA. Changes to payment structures and contract requirements directly impact the financial feasibility of these projects for agricultural owners.

The bill's purpose is to support the achievement of the Chesapeake Bay TMDL, a core mission of DNR. DNR leads state conservation efforts and is an information source for the fiscal impact on Bay restoration goals.

MES is a not-for-profit public business unit that often operates environmental infrastructure projects, including wastewater treatment and Bay restoration efforts. The bill's provisions regarding projects involving construction and rehabilitation apply to the types of projects MES implements.

The BPW reviews and approves state procurement contracts exceeding $200,000. This bill specifically regulates contracts for environmental outcomes, including those exceeding $500,000 which require additional financial protections.

DBM oversees the state budget and the Bay Restoration Fund, which provides the $20 million annual transfer to the Clean Water Commerce Account. It also manages administrative expenditures which the fiscal note indicates will increase for MDE under this bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Council on the Chesapeake Bay
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the Chesapeake Bay Cabinet, this body coordinates the efforts of MDE, MDA, and DNR to meet restoration goals such as the TMDL, which is the primary objective of the funding and contracts regulated by the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill permits the Baltimore County Board of License Commissioners to satisfy public notice requirements for alcoholic beverage license applications by posting notice of a hearing online at least 14 days before the hearing date, rather than publishing notice in a local newspaper for two consecutive weeks. It also clarifies that if newspaper publication is used, it must occur in one newspaper of general circulation in the county.
qa_results.responsible_party: Baltimore County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license applicants in Baltimore County, local residents and the public, and the Baltimore County Board of License Commissioners.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State finances. Local expenditures for Baltimore County are expected to decrease by as much as $40,000 annually beginning in fiscal 2025, as the county shifts from paid newspaper advertisements to lower-cost online postings for license application hearings. There is no impact on local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation passed by the General Assembly; Governor Moore signed this bill into law as Chapter 1037 of the 2024 Laws of Maryland.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the state and reviews all legislative changes to the Annotated Code of Maryland—including the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article—for legal sufficiency and constitutionality.

The bill allows a local board to fulfill public notice requirements by posting online rather than in traditional newspapers; this shift to digital government services aligns with DoIT's mandate to modernize state government IT and digital accessibility.

The bill facilitates government efficiency and waste reduction by allowing Baltimore County to replace costly newspaper advertisements with more efficient digital notices, resulting in an estimated annual savings of $40,000.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows licensed motor vehicle dealers and distributors to submit orders for new vehicles or truck component parts electronically. It prohibits manufacturers, distributors, and factory branches from refusing to deliver these items in reasonable quantities and timing after receiving an electronic order or an accepted allocation, provided the items are advertised as available for immediate delivery.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation
qa_results.stakeholders: Motor vehicle manufacturers, distributors, factory branches, and licensed motor vehicle dealers
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not affect State or local finances or operations, and has no impact on revenues or expenditures. Small business impact is described as minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill amends the Transportation Article of the Maryland Code, which is the primary legal framework managed by MDOT. The agency oversees the implementation of motor vehicle laws and the operations of the Motor Vehicle Administration, which is directly responsible for regulating the entities mentioned in the bill.

The MVA is the specific unit within MDOT responsible for licensing and regulating motor vehicle dealers, manufacturers, and distributors. This bill directly updates the statutory requirements for the delivery of vehicles following orders or allocations, a process that the MVA is tasked with monitoring and enforcing.

The OAH adjudicates contested cases for the Motor Vehicle Administration. Since the bill clarifies the burden of proof and standards for vehicle delivery and allocation disputes between manufacturers and licensed dealers, the agency serves as the venue for resolving such administrative conflicts.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for the MVA and MDOT. It would be responsible for providing legal counsel on the enforcement of these updated vehicle laws and representing the agencies in any litigation or appeals arising from regulatory disputes between dealers and manufacturers.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes Baltimore City, counties, and municipalities to create tourism zones. Qualifying for-profit and nonprofit businesses in these zones may be exempted from local admissions and amusement taxes and receive credits against county or municipal real and personal property taxes.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City, governing bodies of Maryland counties and municipalities, and the Comptroller of Maryland.
qa_results.stakeholders: Local governments, qualifying for-profit and nonprofit tourism businesses, and small businesses located within designated tourism zones.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state fiscal impact. Local revenues from property and admissions and amusement taxes may decrease starting in fiscal 2025, depending on local implementation. Baltimore City estimates its annual revenue could decrease by approximately $6,400,000 if specific tourism-heavy neighborhoods are designated. Local expenditures are not affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires local jurisdictions that establish tourism zones to notify the Comptroller's office of the zone's establishment and the specific qualifying tourism enterprises eligible for admissions and amusement tax exemptions, including the dates of eligibility.

As the state's primary agency for promoting tourism and travel, this office is directly impacted by the creation of new tourism zones and local tax incentives designed to attract tourism enterprises and stimulate economic activity in this sector.

The Department of Commerce is the state's primary economic development agency and the parent department for the Office of Tourism Development. It also manages related programs like Arts and Entertainment Districts, which the bill specifically mentions can coexist with tourism zones.

The bill involves the designation of geographic zones for development, which aligns with the department's mission to coordinate land use, sustainable growth, and support local governments with comprehensive planning.

Tourism is a vital economic driver for Maryland's 18 rural counties. The Council advocates for economic development tools like the tourism zones and tax credits provided in this bill to improve the sustainability of rural populations.

The creation of tourism zones is an economic development and revitalization tool that aligns with the department's mission to stimulate local growth through the rehabilitation of commercial areas and community development.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's office oversees the implementation of economic initiatives and signed this legislation to facilitate economic opportunity through local tourism incentives.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Many qualifying tourism enterprises within these zones are likely to be small or minority-owned businesses. This office advocates for the inclusion and success of these entrepreneurs in state-authorized economic opportunities.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates sustainable growth and community revitalization strategies, which includes the implementation of land-use policies such as the designation of specific development zones for tourism.

The Tax Court is the highest level of administrative review for tax controversies in Maryland. It would have jurisdiction over disputes regarding the property tax or admissions and amusement tax exemptions and credits authorized by the bill.

This board hears appeals related to property tax assessments and tax credit programs; it would be the venue for residents or enterprises contesting decisions related to the property tax credits established in tourism zones.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill consolidates two separate school leadership training programs into a single program developed by the Maryland State Department of Education and the Accountability and Implementation Board. It requires the State Superintendent, local school superintendents, and the chairs and vice chairs of state and local education boards to complete the training. The bill also updates the program content to include topics like the Blueprint for Maryland's Future and strategies for recruiting and retaining a diverse and inclusive workforce.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education and the Accountability and Implementation Board
qa_results.stakeholders: State Superintendent of Schools, local/county superintendents, senior instruction-related staff, school principals, and members of the State Board of Education, local boards of education, and the Accountability and Implementation Board
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State and local impacts are expected to be minimal. The State Department of Education and the Accountability and Implementation Board (AIB) can adapt existing development efforts for the previous two-track program into the unified program without additional expenditures. Minimal savings may occur for the State and local school systems due to a shorter program duration and the option for virtual participation. AIB may incur minor additional costs for its members to attend the training.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for the state's K-12 education system and a lead implementer of the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future, MSDE is tasked with developing the school leadership training program in collaboration with the Accountability and Implementation Board (AIB). The State Superintendent is also required to complete the training.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This category includes the Accountability and Implementation Board (AIB), which is explicitly required by the bill to collaborate with MSDE in developing the leadership training program. Additionally, the chair and vice chair of the AIB are mandated to complete the training.

As the umbrella organization for the state's public universities, USM institutions are among the 'public institutions of higher education' that may offer the school leadership courses mentioned in the bill. The bill mandates that these institutions must provide a virtual participation option for enrollees.

As a public institution of higher education, Morgan State may offer the leadership courses or programs described in the bill. The legislation requires any such institution to offer a virtual format for participating superintendents.

As a public liberal arts college and state agency, Saint Mary's is a public institution of higher education that may be involved in offering the leadership courses mentioned in the bill, triggering the requirement to provide a virtual option.

MHEC is the regulatory and coordinating board for Maryland's public and private colleges. It oversees the academic program approval process for the institutions (like USM, Morgan, and Saint Mary's) that may offer the mandated school leadership training.

The Governor's Office oversees the operations of state departments like MSDE and appoints the members of the State Board of Education and the Accountability and Implementation Board, both of which are central to the bill's mandates.

DBM serves as the state’s central fiscal authority and manages the statewide personnel system. It oversees the budget for MSDE and AIB, ensuring resources are allocated for the development of the mandated training program.

OLA is responsible for conducting fiscal compliance and performance audits of executive agencies. It would eventually be responsible for auditing MSDE’s compliance with the training program's development and the proper use of funds for these training mandates.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the State Department of Education and the State Board of Education. It would provide counsel on the execution of employment contracts for the State Superintendent and the implementation of the bill's regulatory requirements.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to develop and implement a three-year public education campaign on the prevention of prostate, lung, and breast cancer, specifically targeting communities disproportionately impacted by these diseases. The campaign must provide educational information on risks and warning signs, promote screenings and participation in clinical trials, and offer information regarding legislation that reduces cost barriers to prevention services.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Communities disproportionately impacted by prostate, lung, and breast cancer; healthcare providers; hospitals; and healthcare associations focusing on these cancers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill mandates a total appropriation of up to $750,000 from the Cigarette Restitution Fund (CRF) across fiscal years 2026 through 2030. This requirement is expected to shift existing CRF expenditures from other programs to the public education campaign rather than increasing overall State spending. If funds are diverted from entitlement programs like Medicaid, general fund expenditures might be needed to backfill the difference. There is no reported impact on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health is the primary agency tasked with developing, implementing, and reporting on the three-year public education campaign on prostate, lung, and breast cancer prevention. It is the lead entity for all activities mandated by the bill.
The bill mandates that the Governor include a specific appropriation in the annual budget bill from fiscal years 2026 through 2030 to fund the education campaign from the Cigarette Restitution Fund.

DBM is responsible for state budget formulation and fiscal management. The fiscal note indicates that the $750,000 required for the campaign will likely be reallocated from existing programs within the Cigarette Restitution Fund, which falls under DBM’s oversight.

The bill specifically requires that the Department of Health post all campaign materials on its website in an accessible format. DoIT is the lead agency for enforcing digital accessibility standards across state government.

The Department of Health is required to set measurable goals and submit annual reports to the General Assembly on the status of meeting those goals, which aligns with GOPI's mission to track progress on key priorities and performance cabinets.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Health and would likely review the public campaign materials, partnership agreements with private entities, and ensuring compliance with the new statutory requirements under the Health - General Article.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Public Service Commission (PSC) to open a proceeding to evaluate revised project schedules, sizes, and pricing for previously approved Round 2 offshore wind projects. It allows Round 1 projects to seek approval to increase the maximum amount of offshore wind renewable energy credits (ORECs) and modify schedules. Additionally, the bill mandates the Department of General Services (DGS) to conduct new procurements for offshore wind energy and requires several state agencies to develop a plan to achieve 8,500 megawatts of offshore wind energy capacity by 2031.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Public Service Commission and Maryland Department of General Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Offshore wind energy developers, Maryland electricity ratepayers, and Maryland State agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures increase by approximately $400,000 for the Department of General Services (DGS) across FY 2025 and FY 2026 for consultant costs related to new procurements. The Department of Natural Resources (DNR) may require up to $350,000 in FY 2025 for consultant costs to help develop the offshore wind capacity plan. The Public Service Commission (PSC) can likely manage requirements with existing resources, though additional consultant costs would be covered by special fund assessments. The net effect on state electricity expenditures and ratepayer impacts is unknown but subject to existing price caps and protections.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill designates the Public Service Commission as the primary authority to evaluate revised offshore wind project plans, approve adjustments to OREC pricing, and lead the development of a statewide plan for 8,500 megawatts of capacity.

The bill alters the Department of General Services' requirements and processes for the procurement of offshore wind energy, requiring the agency to issue multiple solicitations, draft procurements for public comment, and enter into power purchase agreements with specific financial and termination terms.

The Maryland Energy Administration is explicitly required to assist the Commission in planning for offshore wind capacity and is granted access to confidential project information produced during revised project proceedings.

The bill explicitly requires the Department of the Environment to assist the Public Service Commission in developing the statewide plan to achieve 8,500 megawatts of offshore wind energy capacity by 2031.

The bill explicitly requires the Department of Natural Resources to assist the Public Service Commission in developing the capacity plan and identifies a fiscal impact for the agency related to consultant costs for this participation.

As the advocate for residential utility consumers, the Office of the People's Counsel is impacted by proceedings that alter offshore wind renewable energy credit (OREC) pricing and overall ratepayer impacts.

The Board of Public Works is responsible for approving major state procurement contracts and has the authority to waive mandatory termination clauses for renewable energy contracts, a process directly addressed by the bill's procurement requirements.

The Governor's Office oversees the statewide goal of 8,500 megawatts of offshore wind energy and coordinates the various executive agencies tasked with implementing the bill's planning and procurement mandates.

The bill involves labor standards, workforce goals, and requires contractors to attest to labor peace agreements, falling under the agency's mission to promote economic welfare and workforce development.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill references minority business enterprise participation goals and community benefit agreements that focus on local, small, minority, women-owned, and veteran-owned businesses.

The development of offshore wind energy is cited as vital to the state's economic well-being, and the bill requires project applications to include commitments for in-state expenditures and investments in a local supply chain.
The Center's mission to accelerate clean energy adoption and create green jobs is directly relevant to the large-scale expansion of offshore wind capacity mandated by the bill.

The bill emphasizes career training opportunities in the manufacturing, maintenance, and construction industries related to offshore wind, aligning with the Board's strategy for high-demand career pipelines.
The bill's offshore wind expansion is a major component of the state's greenhouse gas reduction strategy, which is coordinated under this multi-agency initiative involving MDE and DNR.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Council on the Chesapeake Bay
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Council integrates the efforts of agencies like DNR and MDE, which are both tasked with assisting in the offshore wind capacity plan that impacts the state's coastal environment.
The Comptroller serves on the Board of Public Works, which must review and approve the significant state contracts and financing waivers authorized by the bill.
The Treasurer serves on the Board of Public Works, which must review and approve the significant state contracts and financing waivers authorized by the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the definition of 'provide esthetic services' within the context of cosmetology licensure to include specific services such as exfoliating, cosmetic microneedling, toning, applying eyelash extensions, superficial exfoliation, and nonablative skin rejuvenation. It also clarifies that these services do not include the diagnosis of illness, disease, or injury, nor the ablation of the dermis or hypodermis.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Cosmetologists (within the Maryland Department of Labor)
qa_results.stakeholders: Licensed cosmetologists, senior cosmetologists, estheticians, small beauty businesses (salons and spas), and consumers of esthetic services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect the State Board of Cosmetologists' finances or operations, as changes can be implemented with existing resources. There is no impact on local government finances. The bill is expected to have a meaningful impact on small businesses by allowing them to provide and charge for a broader range of esthetic services.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The State Board of Cosmetologists, which is housed within the Maryland Department of Labor, is the primary regulatory body responsible for licensing and overseeing the estheticians and cosmetologists affected by this definition change. The agency will need to update its regulations and guidance based on the expanded scope of practice.

The fiscal note indicates that the bill has a 'meaningful' impact on small businesses by allowing them to offer and charge for additional esthetic services. As the state's primary economic development agency, this aligns with their mission to support small businesses and entrepreneurs.

The bill explicitly clarifies that esthetic services do not include the diagnosis of illness, disease, or injury, nor the ablation of the dermis. This defines the boundary between cosmetic services and medical/healthcare services regulated by the Department of Health.
As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees all state departments including Labor and Commerce, and the Governor signed this legislation into law.
The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to state agencies, including the Department of Labor, and may be involved in interpreting the new definitions for enforcement or regulatory updates.
DBM oversees the state's fiscal accountability; although the fiscal note suggests no material impact, the agency monitors changes that could affect the operations of the Department of Labor.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to develop a process to inform enrollees and potential enrollees in various state health and prescription programs about the availability of Maryland's earned income tax credit. Additionally, the Maryland Department of Aging is required to provide training to the Maryland Access Point network to increase awareness of the tax credit among its service population.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and Maryland Department of Aging
qa_results.stakeholders: Enrollees and potential enrollees in the Maryland Medical Assistance Program, Maryland Children's Health Program, and Senior Prescription Drug Assistance Program; individuals receiving services through the Maryland Access Point network; and low-to-moderate income taxpayers eligible for the Earned Income Tax Credit.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State and local income tax revenues may decrease beginning in FY 2025 due to an expected increase in the utilization of the State earned income and poverty level tax credits. Administrative requirements for the Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland Department of Aging are expected to be met using existing budgeted resources. Montgomery County may experience increased expenditures for its local earned income tax credit supplement program.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill primary tasks the Maryland Department of Health with developing a process to distribute information about the Earned Income Tax Credit to enrollees in several of its programs, including Medicaid, the Children's Health Program, and the Senior Prescription Drug Assistance Program.
The bill explicitly requires the Department of Aging to provide periodic training to the Maryland Access Point (MAP) network regarding the availability of the State’s earned income tax credit.

The Comptroller is the state's tax collector and administrator of the Earned Income Tax Credit. The bill's efforts to increase awareness and utilization of the credit directly impact the Comptroller’s revenue collection and credit administration functions.

The fiscal note indicates that the Maryland Insurance Administration jointly administers the Qualified State Long-Term Care Insurance Partnership with the Department of Health, and may be required to assist in distributing the required tax credit information to policyholders.
The bill identifies the Department of Disabilities as a coordinating partner for the Maryland Access Point program, which is the network receiving mandatory training under this legislation.

While primary responsibility was shifted away from this agency during the legislative process, the bill still identifies the Department of Human Services as a collaborating partner in the administration and coordination of the Maryland Access Point program being trained.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency is listed in the bill as a cooperating entity for the Maryland Access Point program, which is the target of the new tax credit training requirements.

As the state's fiscal authority, this agency is responsible for overseeing the budget impacts noted in the fiscal note, specifically the potential decrease in general fund revenues due to increased tax credit utilization.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits the recordation of a deed or other instrument if the person knows it contains false information, such as incorrect property ownership details. A violation is classified as a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of up to $500, with a three-year statute of limitations for prosecution. Additionally, the bill allows courts to award legal costs and attorney's fees in quiet title actions if the case involves the recordation of an instrument with false information.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Property owners, individuals involved in real estate transactions, and the Maryland court system.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have a minimal impact on state and local finances. There may be a small increase in state revenue from fines (up to $500 per violation) collected in the District Court, but this is not expected to be material. Expenditures for state and local operations are not significantly affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts judicial operations by creating a new misdemeanor for recording false instruments and modifying procedures for 'quiet title' actions, including the recovery of attorney's fees and the requirement for court clerks to index judgments in land records.

As the state's chief legal advisor, the OAG would be responsible for providing counsel to state agencies on the implications of this law and would manage any criminal appeals that arise from the newly established misdemeanor regarding false property recordation.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency is responsible for statewide public safety policy. It would monitor and advise on the implementation of the bill's new criminal penalties and the expanded statute of limitations for deed-related fraud.

The Governor's Office is relevant as it is responsible for signing the bill into law and coordinating the executive branch's response to crimes involving property records through its public safety and economic opportunity initiatives.

The State Archives serves as the central depository for government records of permanent value, including land records; legislation aiming to prevent the recordation of false information directly impacts the integrity of the historical and legal collections they preserve.

The Maryland State Police may be tasked with investigating criminal violations of the new misdemeanor established by the bill, particularly those involving multi-jurisdictional fraud or complex financial crimes related to property ownership.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes a Southern Maryland code county to include provisions in its subdivision regulations for the dedication of real property for recreational use or, alternatively, the payment of a fee in lieu of dedication. Funds collected from these fees must be used by the county for the acquisition, development, and improvement of recreational facilities.
qa_results.responsible_party: Southern Maryland code counties, specifically the legislative body and planning commission of Charles County
qa_results.stakeholders: Property developers, small business developers, and residents of Southern Maryland code counties (currently Charles County).
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect State finances. Charles County revenues and expenditures may increase to the extent the county exercises the authority to collect fees in lieu of property dedication for recreational facilities. The bill may also have a meaningful impact on small business developers required to dedicate land or pay fees.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Planning (MDP) is the primary state agency responsible for coordinating land use and providing technical assistance and policy guidance to local governments regarding planning and subdivision regulations. This bill directly amends the Land Use Article and modifies subdivision regulation authority for specific counties, a core area of MDP’s oversight.

This multi-agency initiative focuses on sustainable growth and sound land-use policies. The bill concerns the dedication of land for recreation and open spaces within subdivision regulations, which aligns with the initiative's goal of balancing population growth with resource conservation and community vitality.

The Governor's Office is responsible for signing legislation into law and overseeing the operations of state departments such as the Department of Planning, which is impacted by changes to the Land Use Article.

The bill facilitates the acquisition and improvement of real property for recreational purposes and facilities. The DNR is the state agency responsible for managing public lands and maintaining diverse outdoor recreational spaces, giving them a vested interest in policies that promote recreational land use.

The Rural Maryland Council advocates for the interests of the state's rural counties, including those in the Southern Maryland class. The bill provides these counties with new mechanisms to fund and develop recreational infrastructure, directly affecting the quality of life in rural communities.

The Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD) works on neighborhood revitalization. Subdivision regulations and fees in lieu of property dedication can influence development costs and the provision of community amenities like recreational facilities in new developments.
The OAG reviews all legislation for legal sufficiency and provides legal counsel to the Governor and state agencies regarding the implementation of changes to the Land Use Article.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows individuals monitored by private home detention monitoring agencies as a condition of their probation, parole, or mandatory release to earn compliance credits. These credits provide a 20-day reduction in the period of home detention for every month that an individual complies with supervision requirements. Private monitoring agencies are required to report an individual's compliance and any infractions to the Division of Parole and Probation upon request.
qa_results.responsible_party: Division of Parole and Probation
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals under supervision by private home detention monitoring agencies, private home detention monitoring agencies, and the Maryland Judiciary.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect State or local finances. There may be a minimal increase in State expenditures for the Judiciary to process requests for adjustments to home detention periods. Small business private home detention monitoring agencies may experience a meaningful decrease in revenue as a result of shortened monitoring periods for compliant individuals.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Division of Parole and Probation (DPP), which is part of this department, is the primary agency responsible for implementing the earned compliance credit program and overseeing the monitoring reports from private home detention agencies. The department also licenses and regulates these agencies.
The bill requires the court to adjust supervision or home detention periods based on recommendations from the Division of Parole and Probation for earned compliance credits accrued by individuals.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency represents indigent individuals in criminal and probation matters; the bill directly impacts the supervision terms, compliance requirements, and potential for early abatement of their clients.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's central hub for public safety policy, this office advises on criminal justice strategies like earned compliance credits and may be involved in the oversight or policy development related to home detention monitoring.

The OAG acts as the legal advisor to the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and would provide counsel on the implementation of these new regulatory and reporting requirements for private home detention monitoring.

The bill impacts the allocation of state funds, specifically requiring that 75% of realized savings from the program revert to the Performance Incentive Grant Fund, which DBM oversees as part of the state budget process.
The bill mandates that the Department develop an automated application for the tracking and awarding of earned compliance credits, which likely requires coordination with or standards from DoIT.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The fiscal note indicates a potentially meaningful impact on private home detention monitoring agencies, many of which are small businesses that fall under the advocacy and monitoring scope of this office.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and is responsible for signing the legislation into law and enforcing its provisions.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill lowers the minimum age for individuals who may be employed by an alcoholic beverages licensee in Allegany County from 18 to 16. However, it maintains the requirement that an employee must be at least 18 years old to sell or serve beer, light wine, and liquor.
qa_results.responsible_party: Allegany County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Alcoholic beverages license holders and individuals aged 16 to 17 in Allegany County.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State finances and does not materially affect Allegany County operations or finances. Small businesses in Allegany County may experience a minimal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation; this bill was signed into law by the Governor as Chapter 1038 of the 2024 Laws of Maryland.

The OAG acts as the chief legal office for the State, providing guidance on the interpretation and enforcement of the Annotated Code of Maryland, which this bill amends regarding alcoholic beverage license regulations.

The Maryland Department of Labor oversees workforce standards and regulations. This bill alters the minimum age for individuals employed by alcoholic beverages license holders in Allegany County from 18 to 16, directly impacting local youth employment and labor standards.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill reconfigures the Maryland Commission on Health Equity to serve as the governance body responsible for developing and monitoring a statewide health equity plan as required by federal agreements with the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation. It adjusts the Commission's membership by adding health-focused officials and representatives from underserved communities while removing various state department heads. Additionally, the bill designates the Secretary of Health and the Executive Director of the Health Services Cost Review Commission as co-chairs and extends the termination date of the Commission on Public Health to June 30, 2026.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Health Services Cost Review Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents (particularly those in underserved communities), healthcare providers, hospitals, federally qualified health centers, health insurers, community-based organizations, and tribal communities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have no significant impact on state or local revenues or expenditures. The Maryland Department of Health and the Health Services Cost Review Commission can manage the additional workload and travel reimbursements for new commission members using existing budgeted resources. Extending the termination date of the Commission on Public Health is also expected to be absorbed within existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Secretary of Health serves as a co-chair of the Maryland Commission on Health Equity, and the Department is responsible for providing staff support and coordinating the advisory committee on data collection.

The Executive Director of the HSCRC co-chairs the Commission on Health Equity and plays a primary role in developing the statewide health equity plan required by federal Medicare/Medicaid innovation agreements.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly amends the governing statutes, membership, and reporting duties of two primary entities within this category: the Maryland Commission on Health Equity and the Commission on Public Health.

The Executive Director of the MHCC is added as a statutory member of the Maryland Commission on Health Equity, and the agency must provide data and coordinate on the commission's health equity data sets.
The Secretary of Aging is a statutory member of the Maryland Commission on Health Equity, contributing to the development of the comprehensive health equity plan.
The Secretary of Budget and Management remains a statutory member of the Maryland Commission on Health Equity.
The Secretary of Disabilities is a statutory member of the Maryland Commission on Health Equity, ensuring the health equity plan addresses the needs of residents with disabilities.
The State Superintendent of Schools is a statutory member of the Maryland Commission on Health Equity, assisting in the development of health equity goals related to education.

The Secretary of Housing and Community Development is a statutory member of the Maryland Commission on Health Equity, as housing is identified as a major factor in the state's health equity framework.
The Secretary of Human Services is a statutory member of the Maryland Commission on Health Equity, coordinating the human services component of the comprehensive health equity plan.
The Secretary of Planning is a statutory member of the Maryland Commission on Health Equity, supporting alignment with other statewide planning activities.
The Maryland Insurance Commissioner is a statutory member of the Maryland Commission on Health Equity.
The bill removes the Secretary of Agriculture from statutory membership on the Maryland Commission on Health Equity.
The bill removes the Secretary of Commerce from statutory membership on the Maryland Commission on Health Equity.
The bill removes the Secretary of the Environment from statutory membership on the Maryland Commission on Health Equity.
The bill removes the Secretary of General Services from statutory membership on the Maryland Commission on Health Equity.
The bill removes the Secretary of Information Technology from statutory membership on the Maryland Commission on Health Equity.
The bill removes the Secretary of Juvenile Services from statutory membership on the Maryland Commission on Health Equity.
The bill removes the Secretary of Labor from statutory membership on the Maryland Commission on Health Equity.
The bill removes the Secretary of Natural Resources from statutory membership on the Maryland Commission on Health Equity.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill removes the Commissioner of Correction from statutory membership on the Maryland Commission on Health Equity.
The bill removes the Secretary of State Police from statutory membership on the Maryland Commission on Health Equity.
The bill removes the Secretary of Transportation from statutory membership on the Maryland Commission on Health Equity.
The bill removes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs from statutory membership on the Maryland Commission on Health Equity.
The Governor's authority to designate the chair of the Health Equity commission is repealed, and the Governor receives the revised reports from the Commission on Public Health.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the Continuing the CORE Partnership Fund indefinitely by repealing its previous termination date of June 30, 2024. The fund is used by the Department of Housing and Community Development, in conjunction with the Maryland Stadium Authority and Baltimore City, to remove blighted property in Baltimore City. Starting in fiscal year 2026, the bill mandates a $50,000,000 annual appropriation to the fund.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents and property owners in Baltimore City, Baltimore City government, Maryland Stadium Authority, and the Department of Housing and Community Development.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Pay-as-you-go (PAYGO) general fund expenditures increase by $50.0 million annually beginning in FY 2026 due to the mandated appropriation. If these funds replace general obligation (GO) bonds already planned for Project CORE in the Capital Improvement Program, those bonds would become available for other capital projects. There is no expected material impact on Baltimore City finances unless the mandated funding supplements rather than replaces current planned capital spending.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary implementing agency, DHCD is responsible for administering the Continuing the CORE Partnership Fund and leading the 'Project CORE' initiative to remove blighted property in Baltimore City.
The bill explicitly names the Maryland Stadium Authority as the state partner required to work in conjunction with DHCD to utilize the fund for blighting removal projects.
DBM is responsible for formulating the state budget and must ensure the mandated $50 million annual appropriation is included in the operating budget starting in FY 2026.
The Governor is legally required by this bill to include a $50 million annual appropriation in the budget and oversees the high-priority urban renewal policy represented by Project CORE.
The bill specifically mandates that the Comptroller shall account for the Continuing the CORE Partnership Fund.
The bill specifically mandates that the State Treasurer shall hold the fund and invest its money in the same manner as other state funds.

The OAG provided the critical legal interpretation that the funding mandate must be met through the operating budget rather than capital bonds, and serves as the legal advisor to the implementing agencies.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the reporting requirements for health insurance carriers by requiring them to include additional data in their quarterly reports to the Maryland Insurance Commissioner. Specifically, carriers must now report the number of members entitled to health care benefits under their policies in Maryland and the number of clean claims for reimbursement they have processed.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commissioner
qa_results.stakeholders: Health insurance carriers and Maryland health insurance policyholders
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not substantively change Maryland State activities or operations, and it has no impact on local finances or small businesses. There are no specified revenue or expenditure changes for the State.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Insurance Administration (MIA) is the primary regulatory agency responsible for overseeing the health insurance appeals and grievances process. Under the bill, the Insurance Commissioner must receive expanded quarterly reports from carriers and is mandated to compile and distribute an annual summary report to the Governor and General Assembly.

The bill amends reporting requirements for an annual summary report compiled by the Insurance Commissioner. By statute, this report includes data provided by the Secretary of Health regarding health maintenance organizations. The Department of Health is therefore a key data contributor to the reporting framework modified by this legislation.

The Office of the Attorney General’s Health Education and Advocacy Unit (HEAU) plays a central role in the health insurance appeals and grievances ecosystem. While the specific workgroup was removed from the final bill, the expanded reporting requirements impact the data available to the OAG for consumer protection and advocacy efforts.
The bill requires the Maryland Insurance Commissioner to provide a copy of the annual summary report on health care appeals and grievances to the Governor.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill reduces the term of office for members of the Howard County Agricultural Preservation Advisory Board from five years to three years. Current members are permitted to serve out the remainder of their existing five-year terms before the new term length applies to subsequent appointments.
qa_results.responsible_party: Howard County Government (County Governing Body)
qa_results.stakeholders: Members of the Howard County Agricultural Preservation Advisory Board and the Howard County agricultural community.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State finances and does not materially affect Howard County operations or finances. The impact on small businesses is minimal or none.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill amends the Agriculture Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland. These local advisory boards are statutory bodies that provide critical recommendations to the Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation (MALPF), which is a program within the Department of Agriculture focused on farmland preservation and resource conservation.

County agricultural preservation advisory boards are responsible for approving or disapproving applications for the certification or recertification of local agricultural land preservation programs, a process that is conducted in coordination with the Maryland Department of Planning.

As the head of the executive branch, the Governor signed this bill into law and oversees the Department of Agriculture and the Department of Planning, both of which interact with the local boards affected by this legislation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires health insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations to provide coverage for all medically appropriate and necessary hearing aids for adults when prescribed, fitted, and dispensed by a licensed audiologist. Carriers are permitted to limit the benefit to $1,400 per hearing aid per ear every 36 months, though insured individuals may choose a more expensive device and pay the difference themselves.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Adults with hearing impairment covered under private health insurance, health insurance carriers, and licensed audiologists.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill results in a minimal special fund revenue increase for the Maryland Insurance Administration (MIA) beginning in FY 2025 due to $125 rate and form filing fees. MIA can handle form reviews with existing resources. There is no impact on the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program as it already complies. Local government finances and small businesses are not expected to be materially affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees all state departments and signs legislation into law. This bill, signed by the Governor, establishes a new healthcare mandate for Maryland residents.

Hearing loss is a significant concern for the older adult population (60+) served by MDOA. The mandate for hearing aid coverage for adults directly supports the department's mission of promoting independence and dignity for seniors.

DBM oversees the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program. While the fiscal note indicates the current program already complies with the bill's requirements, DBM remains a stakeholder as the central authority for state health benefit planning.

MDOD is the cross-disability policy leader in the state. Hearing loss is a major disability, and access to hearing aids as a form of assistive technology is a critical policy area that supports community-based living and independence.

MDH oversees public health and healthcare financing. The bill impacts the broader healthcare landscape in Maryland, and MDH coordinates with the Insurance Administration and the Health Benefit Exchange on health policy mandates.

Hearing loss and tinnitus are the most common service-connected disabilities. While many veterans receive care via the VA, this bill ensures that those using state-regulated private or group health plans have access to hearing aid coverage.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: ODHH is the primary agency advocating for residents who are deaf or hard of hearing. This bill's requirement to provide hearing aid coverage for adults is a central policy priority for this office's mission to improve access and quality of life for its constituents.

MHBE administers Maryland Health Connection. The bill's requirements interact with Essential Health Benefits (EHBs) and the State benchmark plan, which MHBE must manage for all qualified health plans offered on the exchange.
MHCC is responsible for health system planning and ensures residents have access to affordable care. The commission often monitors and reports on the impact and quality of mandated health benefits.

MIA is the primary regulator for this bill. It is responsible for enforcing the insurance mandate, reviewing rate and form filings from carriers, and investigating consumer complaints regarding hearing aid coverage.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill repeals the monopoly of the Liquor Control Board for Wicomico County and its dispensaries regarding the wholesale sale and distribution of certain wine and liquor. It authorizes Class A, B, C, and D alcoholic beverages license holders to purchase products from either a dispensary or a wholesaler and removes the previous prohibition on wholesalers delivering liquor directly to retailers in Wicomico County.
qa_results.responsible_party: Liquor Control Board for Wicomico County
qa_results.stakeholders: Alcoholic beverages license holders in Wicomico County (Class A, B, C, and D), alcohol wholesalers, and the Wicomico County Liquor Control Board.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Wicomico County revenues will decrease to the extent that license holders choose to purchase wine and liquor from wholesalers rather than through the county dispensary system. The specific amount of revenue loss cannot be estimated at this time. Enforcement can be handled with existing resources. State operations and finances are not materially affected. Small businesses acting as wholesalers may see increased sales, and retail license holders may experience savings by purchasing at lower prices.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically references wholesaler licenses issued by the Comptroller under Section 2-301 of the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article. As the state's chief financial officer and tax collector, the Comptroller oversees the licensing and revenue collection from the alcoholic beverages industry, which is directly impacted by the repeal of the Wicomico County monopoly.

The Governor's Office is the principal executive agency that signed this bill into law. It oversees the state departments responsible for regulating the alcoholic beverages market and ensures the enforcement of the state's updated distribution laws.

By repealing a government-held monopoly and opening the liquor market to private wholesalers, the bill creates a more competitive business environment in Wicomico County, which aligns with the Department of Commerce's mission to stimulate private investment and support small businesses.

The Department of Budget and Management oversees the state's fiscal health and revenue estimation; changes in the alcoholic beverage distribution structure in a major county can affect statewide revenue trends and fiscal policy oversight.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the primary legal advisor to the state agencies regulating alcoholic beverages and would be responsible for providing legal guidance on the transition from a local monopoly to a private wholesale model.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes Class B beer, wine, and liquor license holders in Wicomico County to purchase liquor for retail sale from licensed wholesalers as an alternative to the county dispensary. Additionally, it allows restaurant license holders who also possess a Class 9 limited distillery license to sell their own distilled products for both on- and off-premises consumption at their restaurant location.
qa_results.responsible_party: Wicomico County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Class B beer, wine, and liquor license holders (hotels and restaurants) in Wicomico County, Class 9 limited distillery license holders, and licensed alcohol wholesalers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on state finances. Wicomico County revenues are expected to decrease to the extent that license holders choose to purchase liquor from wholesalers rather than the county dispensary, though the exact amount cannot be estimated. Small businesses may experience cost savings and increased sales. Local enforcement can be handled with existing county resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the chief executive, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation passed by the General Assembly, including this bill which regulates alcoholic beverage sales in Wicomico County.

The Comptroller serves as the state's tax collector and fiscal watchdog. Changes to the distribution and purchase requirements for alcoholic beverages impact the tracking and collection of sales and use taxes from licensed wholesalers and retail businesses.

Wicomico is one of Maryland's 18 rural counties served by the Council. The bill impacts local economic sustainability and small business flexibility for restaurants and distilleries, which aligns with the Council's mission to support rural community interests.
The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to the General Assembly and the Governor, providing legal review of legislation to ensure constitutional and statutory compliance.

The Department of Commerce focuses on small business support and economic development. The fiscal note highlights potential meaningful economic benefits for small businesses (restaurants and distilleries) in Wicomico County as a result of this bill.
DBM serves as the state's central fiscal authority and tracks legislation with potential revenue or expenditure impacts on state and local governments.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes Howard County and property owners to enter into payment in lieu of taxes (PILOT) agreements for real property that maintains a number of moderate-income housing units exceeding local zoning requirements. The bill requires the Howard County Executive to publish the methodology used to calculate negotiated payments on the county website and to reevaluate that methodology at least once every five years.
qa_results.responsible_party: Howard County Government (County Executive and Governing Body)
qa_results.stakeholders: Real property owners and developers in Howard County, and moderate-income households.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no impact on State finances. Howard County property tax revenues may decrease beginning in fiscal 2025 due to property tax exemptions for qualifying moderate-income housing developments. The extent of the revenue decrease depends on the number of participating developments and their assessed values, though the impact will be mitigated by the negotiated PILOT payments.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor signed the legislation into law as part of the state's executive duty to enact legislation passed by the General Assembly, though the bill's primary administrative impact is at the local level in Howard County.

The bill's focus on expanding moderate-income housing through financial incentives aligns with the department's core mission of financing and preserving affordable housing units and fostering community revitalization.

The board has jurisdiction over appeals related to property tax exemptions; since the bill creates a specific path for real property tax exemptions in Howard County through PILOT agreements, the agency may be required to adjudicate disputes regarding these exemptions.

As the highest level of administrative review for tax controversies, including those involving real property assessments and local tax exemptions, the court would hear high-level appeals concerning the implementation of these PILOT agreements.
