The Governor’s Office is relevant as the Governor reviewed and signed the legislation into law. Additionally, the office oversees the operations of state agencies and is responsible for enforcing the laws passed by the General Assembly.

DBM serves as the state’s central fiscal authority. While OLA is a legislative branch entity, DBM is concerned with the overall administrative efficiencies and fiscal accountability of state government functions mentioned in the fiscal note.

The OAG serves as the chief legal advisor for the state and its agencies. It would provide legal guidance on the interpretation and implementation of the statutory changes to the State Government Article regarding audit cycles.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill adds the State Treasurer to the list of state officials, including the Governor and members of the General Assembly, who are prohibited from participating in certain campaign finance activities during a regular legislative session. Prohibited activities include receiving, soliciting, or depositing campaign contributions and conducting fundraising events.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Elections
qa_results.stakeholders: The Maryland State Treasurer, campaign finance entities, candidates for federal, State, or local office, and persons acting on behalf of the State Treasurer.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect State operations or finances. While violations of the campaign finance restrictions can result in civil penalties (typically $1,000 plus the amount of the contribution) distributed to the Fair Campaign Financing Fund, no significant fiscal impact is expected. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill is specifically directed at the State Treasurer, adding the officeholder to the list of state officials prohibited from engaging in certain campaign finance activities during the General Assembly's regular session.

As the primary regulator of campaign finance and elections, the SBE is responsible for enforcing these prohibitions, collecting civil penalties for violations, and distributing those funds to the Fair Campaign Financing Fund.
The OAG provides legal counsel on the enforcement of election laws and is also included in the list of officials subject to the existing campaign finance restrictions modified by this bill.
The Governor is one of the state officials subject to the same campaign finance restrictions that the bill expands to include the State Treasurer.
The Lieutenant Governor is one of the state officials subject to the same campaign finance restrictions that the bill expands to include the State Treasurer.
The Comptroller is one of the state officials subject to the same campaign finance restrictions that the bill expands to include the State Treasurer.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Transit Administration (MTA) to provide more detailed information on its website before holding public hearings regarding major bus service changes. This information must include demographics of riders, nearby schools and businesses, monthly ridership data, and the specific impact on commutes and paratransit services. Additionally, the bill mandates that the MTA distribute impact reports to specific government officials and any members of the General Assembly whose districts are affected by the proposed changes.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Transit Administration (MTA)
qa_results.stakeholders: Transit riders (specifically bus and paratransit users), schools and businesses located in transit service areas, and members of the Maryland General Assembly.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State Transportation Trust Fund expenditures will increase, likely minimally, for the MTA to modify existing consultant contracts to collect and publish the additional required information. Revenues are not affected, and there is no direct impact on local government operations or finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MTA is the primary implementing agency for the bill, as it is directly responsible for operating state bus routes and paratransit services, conducting the required equity and cost-benefit analyses, and publishing the impact reports on its website.

As the cabinet-level parent agency of the MTA, MDOT is responsible for the overall planning and operation of Maryland's transportation network. The bill requires the Secretary of Transportation to receive the impact reports and mandates MDOT's collaboration on transit equity analyses.
The bill explicitly requires that the impact reports for major transit service changes be distributed to the members of the Board of Public Works.
The bill requires MTA to conduct transit equity analyses regarding disparate impacts on persons with disabilities and consult with disabled riders before implementing major service changes.

The agency is responsible for enforcing anti-discrimination laws; the bill requires Title VI transit equity analyses to determine if service changes cause a disparate impact or disproportionate burden on minority populations.
The Attorney General is a designated recipient of the impact reports required under the bill for any major service changes.
The Comptroller sits on the Board of Public Works, which is a required recipient of the transit impact reports specified in the bill.
The Treasurer sits on the Board of Public Works, which is a required recipient of the transit impact reports specified in the bill.
The Governor's Office oversees executive departments like MDOT and ensures that state agencies comply with legislative requirements regarding public transparency and service delivery.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the MTA to analyze the impact of service changes on economic development and local businesses, and to perform community outreach to racial minority communities.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires consultation with disabled riders and those with limited English proficiency, groups whose interests the ODHH advocates for within state government.
The bill requires the MTA to perform a cost-benefit analysis that specifically evaluates the impacts of bus service changes on economic development and employment.
The Council advocates for rural transportation access; service changes or cancellations to routes connecting rural areas to metropolitan centers would impact the populations they serve.
DBM oversees state fiscal accountability; the fiscal note indicates a minimal increase in Transportation Trust Fund expenditures due to the bill's reporting and data collection requirements.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Baltimore Regional Water Governance Model Workgroup to study and analyze the implementation of a regional water governance approach for the Baltimore area. The workgroup is required to analyze equity impacts on vulnerable residents, financial transition plans, workforce transitions, legal requirements, and operational changes, ultimately reporting its findings by June 30, 2027.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Baltimore Regional Water Governance Model Workgroup, staffed jointly by the Mayor of Baltimore City and the County Executive of Baltimore County
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents and water/wastewater ratepayers in Baltimore City, Baltimore County, and surrounding counties (Anne Arundel, Carroll, Harford, and Howard); the workforce responsible for water distribution; and labor organizations representing Baltimore City employees.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $500,000 in FY 2026 due to a mandated appropriation to hire independent consultants. Baltimore City and Baltimore County will see a corresponding increase in revenues and expenditures of $500,000 to manage these consultants. Staffing and member reimbursements are expected to be handled with existing resources.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly establishes a new study group, the Baltimore Regional Water Governance Model Workgroup, which fits this agency classification.

The workgroup is legally required to consult with the OAG in developing its report, and the bill requires an analysis of legal and legislative actions including changes to city and county codes and charters.
The workgroup is mandated to consult with MDE, which is the primary state regulator for water and wastewater systems, during the development of its report and findings.

The Governor is responsible for appointing members to the workgroup and will receive the final report on regional water governance. Additionally, the bill mandates a $500,000 appropriation in the Governor's annual budget bill.
The bill mandates a $500,000 general fund appropriation in fiscal year 2026, which DBM must manage and incorporate into the state budget.

The workgroup is tasked with studying the creation of a City-County Rate Board and ensuring fairness and rate stability for consumers, which directly aligns with OPC’s mission to advocate for residential utility customers.
This office would facilitate the Governor's process of identifying and vetting the members appointed to the Workgroup.
The workgroup's study must assess the available workforce and issues related to transitioning existing employees from Baltimore City and counties to a new regional model.
The workgroup's financial transition plan is specifically required to analyze how a regional model would affect pension and benefit commitments for employees in the governance area.

qa_results.bill_summary: HB 1511 modifies the Forest Conservation Act by delaying the effective date of most 2023 legislative changes from July 1, 2024, to July 1, 2026. However, it specifically enacts certain provisions effective July 1, 2024, regarding forest mitigation banking (qualified conservation), identifies new priority forest areas for retention and protection, and exempts solar photovoltaic facilities from afforestation requirements. The bill also tasks the Department of Natural Resources with updating the State Forest Conservation Technical Manual and model local ordinances, as well as adopting new regulations to carry out the act.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Land developers, local government authorities, solar energy facility operators, forest mitigation bank owners, and property owners adjacent to priority retention areas.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill delays most state and local fiscal impacts of the 2023 forest conservation modifications until at least FY 2027. Potential long-term impacts include increased construction costs for state and local projects due to modified reforestation requirements. The Department of Natural Resources can implement the required manual updates and regulation changes using existing resources. There may be fluctuations in fee-in-lieu revenues for state and local forest conservation funds, though specific dollar estimates are not provided. Small businesses in construction and landscaping may experience meaningful economic impacts.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Natural Resources (DNR) is the primary implementing agency for the Forest Conservation Act. The bill requires DNR to update the State Forest Conservation Technical Manual, update the model local government ordinance, and adopt new regulations to carry out the modified act.

The bill explicitly references the Department of the Environment (MDE) for identifying Tier II or Tier III high-quality watersheds, which are designated as priority areas for forest retention and protection under the bill.

The bill establishes that solar photovoltaic facilities are not subject to certain afforestation requirements and ties applicability to certificates of public convenience and necessity (CPCN) issued by the Public Service Commission (PSC).

The bill outlines specific standards for judicial review of final determinations regarding forest clearing, including requirements for record compilation and adherence to Maryland Rules, which affects judicial administration.

MDOT manages large-scale infrastructure projects, including state highways, which are subject to Forest Conservation Act requirements. The fiscal note indicates that state construction costs may increase due to modified reforestation requirements.

DGS oversees the design and construction of state-owned facilities. The modified reforestation and afforestation requirements in the bill will impact the cost and planning of state construction projects managed by the agency.

The bill addresses 'agriculture and resource areas' in its afforestation requirements and requires that local forest conservation programs give due consideration to the state's agricultural land preservation goals.
The Department of Planning coordinates land use and sustainable growth. The bill links forest conservation to local comprehensive plans and smart growth strategies, which are core functions of MDP.

DBM oversees state personnel and budgets. The fiscal note indicates that the bill will have a fiscal impact on state pay-as-you-go general fund expenditures for construction projects starting in FY 2027.

The bill (via the 2023 acts it modifies/delays) includes specific exemptions and requirements for multifamily housing and transit-oriented development, directly impacting projects managed or financed by DHCD.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies like DNR and MDE. The agency will be responsible for advising on the new regulations and representing the state in judicial reviews of forest conservation determinations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill makes permanent the authority to use the Bay Restoration Fund (BRF) Septics Account to cover costs for connecting properties using on-site sewage disposal systems (septic systems) to municipal wastewater facilities that are under construction to achieve enhanced or biological nutrient removal standards by repealing a previously scheduled June 30, 2024, sunset date.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE)
qa_results.stakeholders: Homeowners with on-site sewage disposal systems (septic systems), local governments, and the Maryland Department of the Environment.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Overall finances of the BRF Septics Account are not affected, as the bill merely makes permanent an existing authorized use of the account. State revenues and expenditures remain unchanged. Local grant revenues and expenditures may be affected depending on whether funds are prioritized for facility connections over other authorized uses. Small business impacts are minimal but potentially meaningful depending on specific projects receiving funding.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of the Environment is the primary agency responsible for the Bay Restoration Fund and the Septics Account. The bill directly impacts their authority to use fund proceeds for municipal wastewater connections and their continued administration of the upgrade program.

The bill's text specifically identifies the Comptroller as the entity responsible for establishing the separate account within the Bay Restoration Fund and disbursing the funds collected from septic system users.

The bill reenacts language requiring that 40% of the funds from the Septics Account be transferred to the Maryland Agriculture Water Quality Cost Share Program in the Department of Agriculture to fund cover crop activities.

The bill links funding eligibility for septic-to-sewer connections to the property being located in a 'priority funding area' (PFA), a designation managed and coordinated by the Department of Planning.

As an agency that manages water and wastewater treatment plants and environmental restoration projects, MES is often involved in the technical implementation and operation of the infrastructure projects funded by the Bay Restoration Fund.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Council on the Chesapeake Bay
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This council integrates the efforts of various departments to oversee Bay restoration goals. The Bay Restoration Fund is a central component of the state's strategy to meet the Chesapeake Bay Watershed Agreement.

The bill supports 'smart growth' by facilitating the transition from septic systems to community sewerage systems within priority funding areas, balancing community development with environmental stewardship of the Chesapeake Bay.
The Governor's Office oversees all state departments and signs or vetoes the legislation. The Bay Restoration Fund is a major executive-branch priority for environmental health.
DBM oversees the state's budget and the allocation of special funds like the Bay Restoration Fund, ensuring that resource distribution aligns with state fiscal policy.
The Board of Public Works must approve significant state expenditures, including the major grants and procurement contracts issued by MDE using the Bay Restoration Fund.
The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for the Maryland Department of the Environment and the Department of Agriculture, overseeing the legal framework for the Bay Restoration Fund.

qa_results.bill_summary: This emergency bill extends the statutory deadline to May 1, 2024, for the State Department of Assessments and Taxation (SDAT) to mail out real property reassessment notices for the 2024-2025 taxable year. The extension prevents an irrebuttable presumption that property values have not changed, which would have occurred if notices were not sent within 30 days of January 1, thereby ensuring local and state governments can collect property taxes based on updated valuations.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Department of Assessments and Taxation
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland real property owners, county and municipal governments, and the State government.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill prevents a significant decrease in State and local property tax revenues by allowing reassessments to proceed. Absent the bill, State revenues would have decreased by $3.1 million in FY 2025 and $18.4 million over three years. County property tax revenues would have decreased by $30.1 million in FY 2025 ($180.6 million over three years), and municipal revenues would have decreased by $2.1 million in FY 2025 ($12.6 million over three years).

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DBM is responsible for estimating state revenues and formulating the annual budget. This bill prevents a projected $18.4 million loss in state property tax revenue over three years, which is essential for maintaining the fiscal stability of the budget DBM manages.

The Board hears disputes from property owners regarding valuations. By extending the statutory deadline for reassessment notices, the bill preserves the validity of current-cycle assessments, directly impacting the Board's hearing schedule and caseload.

As the state’s chief financial officer and fiscal watchdog, the Comptroller monitors state revenue streams and financial health. The bill prevents a massive revenue shortfall that would disrupt the state's fiscal planning and the tax collection oversight performed by this office.

The Governor’s Office oversees the executive branch departments and drafts the state budget. This departmental bill was requested to rectify a significant administrative failure within an executive agency and protect the state's long-term financial interests.

The Tax Court provides the highest level of administrative review for property assessment disputes. The bill ensures that the reassessments for the upcoming fiscal year remain legally valid and enforceable, preserving the Court’s jurisdiction and appellate processes for this cycle.

The Treasurer manages the state's bond debt and financial assets. Property taxes are the dedicated revenue source for the Annuity Bond Fund, which covers debt service for general obligation bonds; maintaining this revenue is critical for the state's fiscal management and credit rating.

OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits of state agencies. The administrative failure to mail reassessment notices within the statutory 30-day window is a significant compliance lapse that falls under OLA's oversight and would be subject to investigation during agency audits.

This agency tracks the efficiency and responsiveness of state government. The massive failure to mail core property tax notices on time represents a performance breakdown that GOPI would monitor or address through strategic planning and accountability initiatives.

The BPW, which includes the Governor, Comptroller, and Treasurer, protects the state’s fiscal integrity. The preservation of property tax revenues ensures the continued funding of capital projects and school construction overseen by the Board.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor for state agencies and would provide legal guidance on the emergency implementation of the deadline extension and the implications of the prior mailing failures.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill eliminates the Maryland Children's Health Program (MCHP) premium plan and the requirement for families with incomes between 201% and 300% of the federal poverty guidelines to pay monthly premiums for health coverage. It streamlines the program by providing comprehensive medical care for all eligible children under age 19 with family incomes at or below 300% of the federal poverty guidelines through a single administrative structure, effectively removing tiered family contributions.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Children under the age of 19 and their families with household incomes at or below 300% of the federal poverty guidelines.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill results in a net reduction in State expenditures of approximately $100,000 annually beginning in FY 2025 ($35,000 general funds and $65,000 federal funds). While the State will lose an estimated $866,167 in annual premium revenue, this is offset by an estimated $966,132 in annual savings from eliminating the administrative infrastructure and mailings required to collect premiums. Federal fund revenues decrease by approximately $65,000 annually. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) is the primary agency responsible for administering the Maryland Children’s Health Program (MCHP). This bill directly alters the eligibility requirements and administration of MCHP, including the removal of premium requirements for certain income levels, which MDH oversees.

The Maryland Health Benefit Exchange (MHBE) administers the Maryland Health Connection, which is the state's marketplace for health insurance enrollment, including public programs like MCHP. Changes to MCHP eligibility and the elimination of premium plans will require operational and technical adjustments to the MHBE enrollment platform.

The Department of Budget and Management (DBM) oversees the state’s fiscal authority and budget. The bill has a direct impact on the state's General Fund and Federal Fund expenditures and revenues as detailed in the fiscal note. DBM was also a consultant on the fiscal impact of this legislation.

The bill repeals and amends specific sections of the Insurance Article related to the MCHP private option plan. The Maryland Insurance Administration (MIA) regulates the state's insurance industry and was consulted in the preparation of the bill's fiscal note.

The Governor's Office serves as the principal executive agency that signs legislation into law and oversees the Department of Health. This bill is a departmental bill requested by the Governor's administration through MDH.

The Governor's Office for Children (GOC) is tasked with leading a 'whole-of-government' approach to childhood poverty and healthcare access. Removing financial barriers (premiums) for children's health insurance aligns directly with the GOC's mission to improve the well-being of Maryland families.

The Office of the Attorney General (OAG) serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Health and the Governor. They would be responsible for reviewing the legal implications of the statutory changes to the Health - General and Insurance Articles.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill transitions the ownership and operation of thoroughbred horse racing facilities in Maryland from the Maryland Jockey Club to the Maryland Thoroughbred Racetrack Operating Authority (MTROA). It authorizes the Maryland Stadium Authority to issue up to $400 million in bonds to finance the redevelopment of Pimlico Race Course and the construction of a new horse training facility. The legislation also alters funding distributions from the State Lottery Fund, mandates specific appropriations for community development in Prince George’s County, and reallocates grants for workforce housing in the Park Heights area of Baltimore City.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Thoroughbred Racetrack Operating Authority (MTROA)
qa_results.stakeholders: Thoroughbred horse owners, trainers, and breeders; the Maryland Jockey Club; the Maryland Stadium Authority; residents of the Park Heights community in Baltimore City; and the local governments of Baltimore City, Prince George’s County, and the City of Bowie.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill authorizes $400 million in bond debt for racing facility reconstruction, with annual debt service estimated at $24 million from FY 2026 through FY 2055. General fund expenditures increase by $10.7 million in FY 2026 for mandated appropriations to Prince George's County and the Racetrack Facility Renewal Account. State lottery revenue distributions to the general fund decrease by $3.6 million annually starting in FY 2025 due to new mandated grants and fund redistributions. Local property and transfer tax revenues in Baltimore City and the training site jurisdiction are expected to decrease due to various tax exemptions authorized for the redeveloped racing facilities.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly authorizes the Maryland Stadium Authority (MSA) to finance the planning, design, and construction of racing facilities at Pimlico and a new training site, increasing its bond issuance cap to $400 million for these purposes.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directs the agency to maximize revenue from the Racetrax lottery game to support the Racing and Community Development Financing Fund and manages the funds derived from video lottery terminals and racing.

The Department of Labor encompasses the State Racing Commission, which is responsible for issuing licenses, awarding racing days to nonprofit organizations, and overseeing racing operations as modified by this bill.

The Comptroller is responsible for depositing lottery funds into the Racing and Community Development Financing Fund, paying supplemental local impact grants, and distributing sales and use tax revenue from racehorse sales.

The bill requires a joint plan between the Maryland Thoroughbred Racetrack Operating Authority and the Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD) for investments in workforce housing and community revitalization around Pimlico.

The Board of Public Works must approve the issuance of bonds by the Maryland Stadium Authority and approve the long-term agreements and leases for the management and operations of the racing facilities.
The bill mandates that the Governor include specific appropriations for horse racing facilities and community development in the FY 2026 state budget, which is overseen by this department.

The Treasurer is a member of the Board of Public Works and is responsible for the investment and reinvestment of money in the Purse Dedication Account, which is impacted by the bill's funding reallocations.

As the local development council for Baltimore City, the PCDA oversees Local Impact Aid which is redistributed by the bill to benefit the Park Heights Master Plan and communities surrounding the track.

The Governor signs the legislation, appoints members to the Maryland Thoroughbred Racetrack Operating Authority, and ensures the executive branch executes the complex transition of ownership and operations.
The bill affects horse racing, which is a significant component of Maryland's economic development and tourism sector managed by the Department of Commerce.
The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the state agencies involved in drafting the multi-party agreements and leases required for the transfer of racetrack ownership and operations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes two special, nonlapsing funds, the Camden Yards Football Sports Facility Capital Works Fund and the Camden Yards Football Sports Facility Emergency Repair Fund, to be administered by the Maryland Stadium Authority (MSA). The funds are designated to pay for expenses related to capital improvements and emergency repairs at the Camden Yards football sports facility.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Stadium Authority
qa_results.stakeholders: The Maryland Stadium Authority, the Baltimore Ravens, and the public users of the Camden Yards football sports facility.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State nonbudgeted expenditures for the Maryland Stadium Authority increase by $10 million in FY 2025 to reflect the required transfer of bond proceeds into the new special funds. Special fund revenues increase correspondingly. From FY 2026 through 2030, special fund revenues increase by $2 million annually ($1 million each from MSA and the Ravens), and by $1 million annually thereafter through at least FY 2038. Special fund expenditures will increase as necessary for capital and emergency repairs at the facility. Local government finances are not materially affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Stadium Authority is the primary implementing agency that will administer both the Camden Yards Football Sports Facility Capital Works Fund and the Emergency Repair Fund, using them to pay for expenses related to improvements and repairs at the stadium.

The State Treasurer is explicitly required by the bill to hold the new funds separately, invest the money, and execute the transfer of $10 million from existing Series 2023B bond proceeds into the new accounts.

The Comptroller is tasked with accounting for the new funds and managing the interest earnings, ensuring they are credited to the specific funds rather than the General Fund as provided in the amendment to the State Finance and Procurement Article.

As the authority that approves significant state expenditures and capital improvements, the Board (comprising the Governor, Comptroller, and Treasurer) will likely oversee major renovation and repair contracts funded by these new special accounts.
The bill stipulates that the funds may receive money through appropriations in the State budget, which is formulated and managed by the Department of Budget and Management.

The Governor oversees the Maryland Stadium Authority, signed the bill into law, and serves as a member of the Board of Public Works, which has oversight over the large-scale expenditures these funds will support.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Maryland Protecting Opportunities and Regional Trade (PORT) Act provides economic relief following the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse. It establishes temporary financial assistance programs for Port of Baltimore workers and businesses, creates the Fallen Transportation Workers Scholarship Program for families of workers killed on duty, and increases the Maryland Transportation Authority’s bond cap by $1 billion. It also includes tax relief for bridge-related benefit payments and allows the state to waive certain unemployment insurance requirements for impacted individuals.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor and Maryland Department of Commerce
qa_results.stakeholders: Port of Baltimore workers, small businesses, labor unions, trade associations, and families of fallen transportation workers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures increase by at least $75 million in FY 2024, with up to $275 million authorized from the Rainy Day Fund for relief programs through FY 2025. MDTA nonbudgeted revenues and expenditures will increase if additional revenue bonds are issued under the new $4 billion cap. General fund expenditures increase to support the new scholarship program. Local tax revenues may be positively impacted by the preservation of Port-related jobs and business activity. The Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund will see decreased revenues due to benefit charge waivers for affected employers.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill authorizes the Governor to transfer funds from the Revenue Stabilization Account (Rainy Day Fund) by budget amendment to fund the temporary relief programs and oversees the state's response to the Port of Baltimore closure.

The bill establishes income tax subtractions for benefit payments and tuition assistance related to the bridge collapse and authorizes the disclosure of certain tax information to the Departments of Labor and Commerce to administer relief programs and prevent fraud.

The State Treasurer is required to hold and invest the money in the new Fallen Transportation Workers Scholarship Fund and serves as a member of the Board of Public Works, which oversees significant state fiscal moves related to the emergency.
The bill explicitly mandates that the Attorney General pursue options, including filing legal actions, to recover economic damages for the State arising from the bridge collapse and Port closure.
The bill involves transfers from the Revenue Stabilization Account and budget amendments, which fall under the fiscal management and budgetary oversight responsibilities of DBM.
The bill requires the Department of Commerce to establish and administer temporary relief programs for businesses impacted by the reduced operations of the Port of Baltimore.

The bill mandates the Department of Labor to establish relief programs for individuals and businesses, grants the Secretary authority to waive unemployment insurance work-search requirements, and oversees benefit charge waivers for affected employers.

As the parent agency for the Maryland Port Administration and the Maryland Transportation Authority, MDOT is central to the reconstruction efforts and the management of the transportation facilities impacted by the bridge collapse.
The bill establishes the Fallen Transportation Workers Scholarship Program and Fund, which the Commission is tasked with administering and allocating funds to postsecondary institutions.
The bill centers on the 'reduced operations of the Port of Baltimore,' which is managed and promoted by the Maryland Port Administration.
The bill specifically increases the revenue bond cap for the Maryland Transportation Authority by $1 billion to facilitate the reconstruction of the Francis Scott Key Bridge and other facilities.
OLA will be responsible for auditing the financial compliance and management of the newly created relief programs and the scholarship fund to ensure taxpayer dollars are spent responsibly.
The Board of Public Works oversees significant state expenditures and contract approvals that may arise from the emergency relief programs and reconstruction projects funded through the bill.
The relief programs aimed at Port workers and small businesses align with the board's mission to address barriers to employment and maintain workforce pipelines during economic disruptions.
The bill's focus on economic relief for families and individuals impacted by the port closure aligns with the GOC's mission to address childhood poverty and provide comprehensive support networks.
The team’s focus on economic mobility and poverty reduction is relevant as they may assist in piloting data-driven solutions for workers displaced by the Port's reduced operations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes comprehensive consumer protections for retail electricity and gas customers by regulating residential supply contracts, marketing practices, and licensing. It requires energy salespersons and vendors to be licensed by the Public Service Commission, sets price caps for residential energy supply relative to standard offer service rates, and limits contract terms to 12 months with specific renewal notice requirements. The bill also prohibits the sale of residential accounts receivable, regulates 'green power' marketing claims, mandates a training program for industry participants, and increases the Public Service Commission's assessment cap to fund expanded oversight and a new enforcement division.
qa_results.responsible_party: Public Service Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Residential electricity and gas customers, retail energy suppliers, energy salespersons, energy vendors, and Maryland public service companies (utilities).
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures increase by approximately $1.7 million in FY 2025 for the Public Service Commission (PSC) and the Office of People's Counsel (OPC) to support 17 new positions and administrative costs. These expenditures are expected to rise to $2.1 million by FY 2029. Revenues increase correspondingly through new licensing fees and assessments on public service companies. The bill doubles the PSC's annual assessment cap from 0.25% to 0.50% of gross operating revenues and authorizes a one-time special assessment of up to $275,000 in FY 2025. Local government finances are not materially affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Public Service Commission is the primary agency responsible for implementing this bill, including licensing energy salespersons and vendors, regulating 'green power' marketing, establishing a new division for retail supply oversight, and conducting a co-located load configuration study.

The bill explicitly involves the Office of the People's Counsel in investigations and complaints; the fiscal note also identifies funding for five new positions within the agency to handle the increased workload and consumer advocacy related to retail energy supply.

The Consumer Protection Division of the OAG must be consulted by the Commission on regulations, and the office maintains concurrent authority to enforce consumer protection laws against electricity and gas suppliers.
The bill and fiscal note require DBM to include specific new staffing positions (PINs) for the Public Service Commission in the fiscal 2025 budget to support the newly created retail supply division.
DGS is specifically mentioned and exempted from the definitions of energy salesperson and residential energy retailer when it sells energy under specific statutory authority.
The bill contains provisions regarding electricity and gas supply for customers who receive energy assistance through programs managed by the Department of Human Services.
The bill ties utility consumer education and green power marketing to the state's climate commitments established within the Environment Article of the Maryland Code.

The MEA is responsible for managing the Strategic Energy Investment Fund and renewable energy policies (like the RPS) which are directly impacted by the bill's new regulations on green power and Renewable Energy Credits (RECs).
The Comptroller is tasked with accounting for the Education and Protection Fund, which is renamed and modified by this legislation.
The State Treasurer is responsible for holding the Education and Protection Fund separately as a non-lapsing fund.
As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the Public Service Commission and the appointment of personnel for the new regulatory tasks mandated by the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services (DPSCS) to include system upgrades in any vendor contracts being negotiated that allow for the automated and partial expungement of criminal charges. It defines partial expungement as the ability to expunge specific eligible charges even when other charges arising from the same incident are ineligible, and it provides procedures for the court to shield eligible records from public websites and the Central Repository when full expungement is impracticable due to shared record narratives.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services (DPSCS)
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals with criminal records eligible for partial or automated expungement, IT vendors for State criminal justice systems, the Maryland Judiciary, and the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by an estimated $26,000,000 over five years for DPSCS to rebuild the Computerized Criminal History and CJIS-Central Repository systems. Ongoing annual expenditures for operation and management are expected following the initial five-year development period. There is no fiscal impact on local governments.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS is the primary implementing agency. The bill mandates them to rebuild the Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS) and include system upgrades in vendor contracts to support automated and partial expungement, with an estimated $26 million fiscal impact.

The bill explicitly names the Maryland Judiciary and its judicial case management system, requiring the court system to modify its procurement practices and issue specific orders regarding the exclusion of expunged records from public websites.

As the agency responsible for statewide IT policy, cybersecurity, and central procurement of IT services, DoIT will likely oversee or provide strategic direction for the $26 million system overhaul required by the bill.

DBM is responsible for the state budget and personnel authority. The significant general fund expenditure increase ($26 million) noted in the fiscal note directly impacts the budget formulation and fiscal oversight provided by this agency.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor signed this bill into law and oversees the departments tasked with its implementation. The bill aligns with broader executive policy regarding criminal justice and second-chance initiatives.

The bill involves major vendor contracts and state procurement. The Board of Public Works must review and approve significant state expenditures and contracts, such as the multi-million dollar IT upgrades required here.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Governor, the Judiciary, and state agencies. They would likely be involved in reviewing the new vendor contracts and interpreting the statutory changes to criminal procedure regarding expungement.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency advises the Governor on criminal justice strategies. Expungement policy is a core component of their policy portfolio and long-term public safety goals.

As the state's fiscal watchdog and a member of the Board of Public Works, the Comptroller will participate in the approval of the large procurement contracts and fiscal oversight related to the bill's implementation.
The Treasurer sits on the Board of Public Works and will review the major state procurement decisions and capital project financing associated with the required system upgrades.
OLA conducts fiscal compliance and performance audits. They will likely review the expenditure of the $26 million allocated for the CJIS rebuild to ensure accountability and adherence to state law.
While not the primary manager of the Central Repository, MSP is a major criminal justice unit that relies on the accuracy and status of records within CJIS for law enforcement activities.

The Archives is the central depository for permanent government records. Changes to expungement procedures affect the retention and accessibility of criminal records which eventually fall under their jurisdiction.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes procedures for shielding court records related to failure to pay rent proceedings in Maryland. It requires the District Court to automatically shield records within 60 days if a proceeding does not result in a judgment of possession. Additionally, for proceedings that did result in a judgment of possession, tenants may motion the court to shield the records if at least 12 months have passed and the tenant exercised their right of redemption, or if the court find good cause. The bill also mandates that the Maryland Judiciary develop and publish a specific form to facilitate these shielding petitions.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland tenants, landlords, and the District Court system.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $23,426 in FY 2025 for one-time programming costs to implement shielding timelines in the Judiciary's software. There may also be a minimal ongoing increase in District Court workload to process petitions for shielding. The bill does not affect State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly requires the Maryland Judiciary (Administrative Office of the Courts) to implement the shielding of court records in the District Court. It explicitly mandates that the agency develop and publish a new form, 'Petition to Shield a Failure to Pay Rent Action Record,' on its website by October 1, 2024.

The bill's primary goal is to remove barriers to housing access by shielding rent-related court records that did not lead to eviction. This aligns with the agency's mission to expand access to affordable housing and ensure sustainable housing opportunities for residents, particularly vulnerable individuals who face difficulty securing housing due to court records.

As the chief executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing the legislation and overseeing the implementation of state laws and the operations of state departments. This bill was signed by the Governor and affects executive branch policy regarding tenant protections.

The Office of the Attorney General (specifically the Consumer Protection Division) was consulted for the fiscal note and is the primary state entity for legal advocacy regarding consumer and tenant rights, which are directly impacted by regulations on rent-related court records.

The fiscal note identifies a specific general fund expenditure of $23,400 in FY 2025 for one-time programming costs to implement the bill's shielding requirements. DBM oversees the state's budget and manages the allocation of these funds.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill transfers the authority to appoint, fill vacancies for, and remove members of the Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners from the Mayor of Baltimore City and the President of the City Council to the Governor. It requires Board members and employees to comply with State ethics laws and financial disclosure requirements overseen by the State Ethics Commission rather than Baltimore City ethics requirements. Additionally, the bill allows the Board's executive secretary and deputy executive secretary to qualify for their positions if they have served in city government for at least five years, as an alternative to the existing city residency requirement.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Governor of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Members and employees of the Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners, the Governor, the Mayor of Baltimore City, the President of the Baltimore City Council, alcoholic beverage license holders in Baltimore City, and the residents of Baltimore City.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: According to the Fiscal Note, the bill does not materially affect State or Baltimore City operations or finances. No specific revenue or expenditure estimates are provided as the impact is considered negligible.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill shifts the authority to appoint and remove members of the Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners from the Mayor and City Council President to the Governor. This directly impacts the Governor's executive appointment responsibilities.

The bill explicitly transfers ethical oversight of the Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners from the local city board to the State Ethics Commission, requiring board members to comply with State public ethics laws and financial disclosure requirements.

As the agency responsible for recruiting and vetting candidates for the Governor's appointments to state boards and commissions, this office will be tasked with identifying qualified individuals for the Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners.
The bill requires that if the Governor removes a member of the Board, a statement of charges and findings must be filed with the Office of the Secretary of State.

The bill contains provisions requiring Board members who seek elective office to certify their resignation to the City Board of Elections, which operates under the supervision of the State Board of Elections.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill requires Maryland public high schools to inform students about employment and skills training opportunities, such as registered apprenticeships and industry certifications, in the same manner they inform them of postsecondary education options. High schools must highlight high-skilled, high-demand careers that do not require a college degree. Additionally, county boards of education that use college and career readiness software must treat vocational programs as equivalent to postsecondary education and provide a method for students or parents to authorize the release of student information to registered apprenticeship sponsors and employers.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland County Boards of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: Public high school students, parents or guardians, apprenticeship sponsors, and employers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no impact on State revenues or expenditures as the bill pertains to local school boards. The bill is not anticipated to have a material effect on local school system operations or finances, as requirements are expected to be handled within existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill adds provisions to the Education Article of the Maryland Code, requiring public high schools and county boards of education to inform students of career opportunities and pay for apprenticeship entrance exams if they pay for college entrance exams. As the overseer of the state's K-12 system, the Department is responsible for the implementation and regulatory guidance of these mandates.

The bill specifically references apprenticeship sponsors registered with the Department of Labor's Division of Workforce Development and Adult Learning, as well as employers registered with the Department. The agency manages the apprenticeship programs and registries that schools must now promote to students.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the operations of the state departments tasked with implementing this career-focused legislation and ensures alignment with broader state policy goals like the Blueprint for Maryland's Future.

The agency leads a 'whole-of-government' approach to building support networks for youth and families. Promoting high-demand, high-skilled career pathways through apprenticeships is directly related to its mission of improving long-term economic mobility.

The board oversees the state's workforce development system and advises on creating pathways to employment. This bill directly impacts the 'pipelines' to high-demand careers and involves local workforce development boards which the GWDB coordinates.

The bill requires high schools to inform students of skills training opportunities available through schools licensed by the Maryland Higher Education Commission. MHEC is responsible for regulating these for-profit career and skills-training schools.

The bill requires county boards to provide methods for students to release their personal information and career platform results to apprenticeship sponsors and employers. This intersects with the MLDS Center's role in governing and linking student data with workforce outcomes.

This team focuses on data-driven initiatives to increase economic mobility. The bill's focus on connecting career-focused students to high-demand jobs without requiring a college degree is central to the team's mission to improve economic outcomes for Maryland families.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Prince George’s County Board of License Commissioners to extend the application deadline for alcoholic beverages license renewals. It also grants a grace period until July 1, 2025, for licenses that lapsed between March 5, 2020, and December 31, 2023, because of a failure to file a renewal application, provided the license holder pays all past due fees and meets all other renewal requirements.
qa_results.responsible_party: Prince George’s County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Alcoholic beverages license holders in Prince George’s County
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state fiscal impact. It does not materially affect Prince George's County finances or operations. Small business impact is considered minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation passed by the General Assembly. This bill was signed into law by Governor Wes Moore on May 16, 2024.

The Comptroller serves as the state's fiscal watchdog and tax collector. While the bill specifically empowers a local board, the Comptroller oversees the broader business licensing and tax collection framework related to alcoholic beverages across the state.

The OAG serves as the chief legal office for the state, providing counsel on the implementation and legality of state laws, including the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article amended by this bill.

The Department of Commerce is dedicated to business retention and expansion. By providing a pathway for businesses to restore expired alcoholic beverage licenses, the bill supports the economic viability of hospitality and retail businesses in Prince George's County.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Safe Sleep Act of 2024 requires Maryland hospitals to provide oral and written educational resources on safe sleep practices to parents or legal guardians before discharging a newborn infant. Hospitals must discuss the infant's planned home sleep environment with the parents, explain the risks of suffocation and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS), and provide a list of resources for obtaining items necessary for a safe sleep environment. The Maryland Department of Health is responsible for developing and maintaining this list of resources by county.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Parents and legal guardians of newborns, infants, hospitals, and local health departments
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Maryland Department of Health general fund expenditures increase by $19,400 in FY 2025 only to hire a part-time contractual health educator to develop the required resource list. Local health departments are expected to update the list annually using existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on state or local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Treasurer's Office is not relevant as the bill focuses on infant health and hospital discharge protocols.

The commission is responsible for planning health system needs and oversight of healthcare facilities, including hospitals which are the primary entities tasked with the new educational and discharge requirements.
The commission regulates hospital services and performance standards. This bill creates new mandatory care and discharge procedures for hospitals across the state.

The office coordinates the 'whole-of-government' approach to child well-being. This bill involves inter-agency collaboration between the Maryland Department of Health and the Department of Human Services to improve infant safety.
The bill explicitly requires the Maryland Department of Health to collaborate with the Department of Human Services to promote best practices and safe sleep education for parents and caregivers.
While focused on economic mobility for families, this team is not directly involved in public health education or hospital discharge mandates.
The bill directs the Maryland Department of Health to partner with institutions of higher education as part of its public awareness campaign regarding infant safe sleep.

The Maryland Department of Health is the primary agency responsible for implementing the public awareness campaign, developing the resource list for parents, and consulting with local health departments.
The fiscal note identifies a need for general fund expenditures and the hiring of contractual personnel at the Department of Health to manage the mandates of the bill.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies (MDH and DHS) implementing the bill and signed the legislation into law.
The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Maryland Department of Health and other state agencies, providing counsel on the implementation and legal compliance of these new mandates.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of 'legally protected health care' in Maryland to include all gender-affirming treatments, medications, and supplies that are lawful in the state. By doing so, it extends legal protections to health care practitioners and patients, prohibiting state health occupations boards from taking disciplinary actions and restricting state agencies, courts, and law enforcement from cooperating with out-of-state investigations or legal proceedings related to the provision or receipt of such care.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Health Occupations Boards, the Maryland Department of Health, and Maryland State agencies and courts
qa_results.stakeholders: Health care practitioners, transgender and gender-diverse individuals seeking gender-affirming care, and Maryland state and local government agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to have a material impact on state or local finances. According to the fiscal note, the changes are procedural in nature and are not anticipated to affect state or local revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically amends the Criminal Procedure Article to prohibit the Governor from surrendering or extraditing individuals on demand of another state for acts relating to providing or procuring gender-affirming care, provided the acts are legal in Maryland.

The bill makes significant changes to the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article, prohibiting judges from ordering testimony or documents and clerks from filing foreign judgments or subpoenas related to out-of-state investigations of gender-affirming treatment.

MDH oversees health policy and the licensing of health occupations boards. The bill defines 'gender-affirming treatment' within the Health-General Article and prohibits health boards from taking disciplinary actions against practitioners for providing these services.

As the state's primary legal advisor, the OAG is responsible for providing counsel to state agencies and employees regarding the complex interstate legal protections and the prohibition against assisting in out-of-state investigations mandated by the bill.

The bill prohibits state agencies and personnel from using state resources, property, or equipment to further out-of-state investigations into gender-affirming care, directly impacting the operations and investigative conduct of the Maryland State Police.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS manages the Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS); the bill's restrictions on providing information to further out-of-state investigations regarding legally protected health care directly affect the agency's data-sharing protocols.

The core definition of 'legally protected health care' and the prohibitions on state agency resource expenditures are codified in the State Personnel and Pensions Article, which falls under DBM’s administrative and personnel policy oversight.

The bill expands the definition of legally protected health care that serves as a basis for protecting medical professional liability insurers and practitioners from adverse actions in the insurance market, which the MIA regulates.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's hub for public safety policy, this office is relevant to the bill's changes to criminal procedure and the establishment of statewide standards for non-cooperation with out-of-state law enforcement for specific acts.

The MCCR enforces anti-discrimination laws related to gender identity; the bill’s protections for gender-affirming care align with the agency's mission and its role as an information source for the fiscal note.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Office of the Correctional Ombudsman as an independent unit of State government to conduct investigations, reviews, and assessments of administrative acts by the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Department of Juvenile Services. It transfers the Juvenile Justice Monitoring Unit from the Office of the Attorney General to this new office, creates the Correctional Ombudsman Advisory Board, and mandates specific reporting and auditing requirements regarding correctional facility conditions and programming.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of the Correctional Ombudsman
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals confined in Maryland correctional and juvenile facilities, employees of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Department of Juvenile Services, and family members of confined individuals.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures increase by $1,000,000 in FY 2025, reflecting contingent funding provided in the budget. For FY 2026 through FY 2029, general fund expenditures are estimated to range from approximately $836,800 to $914,000 annually. The bill also requires the transfer of $603,067 and four positions from the Office of the Attorney General. There is a potential for increased federal fund grant revenue. Local government finances are not expected to be materially affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor has direct appointment authority over the Correctional Ombudsman (with Senate consent) and the 12 members of the newly established Correctional Ombudsman Advisory Board. The Governor is also responsible for transferring positions and funding from the Attorney General to the new Office.

The bill transfers the existing Juvenile Justice Monitoring Unit (JJMU) out of the Office of the Attorney General and into the newly created Office of the Correctional Ombudsman, resulting in a loss of positions and funding for the agency.
DJS is one of the two primary agencies subject to investigation, review, and assessment by the new Ombudsman. The bill also reallocates monitoring functions specifically related to DJS facilities.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS is a primary subject of the new Ombudsman's oversight. The bill establishes investigative and monitoring procedures for administrative acts, health services, and conditions within DPSCS facilities.

DBM is required to cooperate in setting salaries, qualifications, and standards for positions within the new Office. The agency is also involved in the fiscal transfer of positions and general fund allocations.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency's Executive Director and the Justice Reinvestment Oversight Board (housed within GOCPP) are authorized to recommend funding distributions to the new Office. GOCPP also currently interacts with the Juvenile Justice Monitoring Unit being transferred.

The Ombudsman is tasked with assessing health and mental health services in correctional facilities, and the bill requires collaboration with the Maryland Department of Health regarding the monitoring of children's residential facilities.
The bill requires the Juvenile Justice Monitoring Unit to collaborate with DHS on matters related to the licensing and monitoring of children's residential facilities.

The Judiciary is involved in enforcing subpoenas issued by the Ombudsman. Additionally, the Mediation and Conflict Resolution Office (under the Judiciary) is required to report on best practices for mediating grievances in the corrections system.
This office would facilitate the recruitment and vetting process for the Governor's appointment of the Ombudsman and the members of the Correctional Ombudsman Advisory Board.
As the agency responsible for state real estate and procurement, DGS would be involved in securing the office space and equipment mentioned in the fiscal note for the new independent unit.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly creates the Correctional Ombudsman Advisory Board to provide information and assist the new Office in its investigative processes.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Workgroup to Study Funding for the Westernport Wastewater Treatment Facility. The workgroup is tasked with identifying existing funding sources, studying potential federal, state, and local funding opportunities, and making recommendations to improve the facility's operations and financial sustainability.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents of Westernport and Luke, Maryland; residents of Piedmont, West Virginia; Allegany County officials; and the Upper Potomac River Commission.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures for the Maryland Department of the Environment to staff the workgroup and for member expense reimbursements are expected to be minimal and absorbable within existing budgeted resources. Local government finances are not materially affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of the Environment is explicitly tasked with providing staff for the workgroup, and the Secretary of the Environment (or a designee) is a formal member of the body.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill establishes a new workgroup, which is a specialized study group within the executive branch designed to address the specific public concern of wastewater treatment facility funding.
The Secretary of Budget and Management (or a designee) is a formal member of the workgroup, and the group's primary mandate is to study state and local funding sources.
The Secretary of Health (or a designee) is named as a formal member of the workgroup due to the public health implications of wastewater management.
The workgroup is required to submit its final report and findings to the Governor by December 1, 2024.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows local school systems and the Maryland School for the Deaf to rehire up to five retirees from the Teachers' Retirement System or Teachers' Pension System for any position within the school system without triggering a reduction in their retirement benefits. Previously, this exemption was limited to school-based positions. The bill also applies retroactively to a specific retiree in Harford County, requiring the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System to refund any benefit offsets incurred by that individual in 2023 or 2024.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System; local school system superintendents; Maryland School for the Deaf
qa_results.stakeholders: Retirees of the Teachers' Retirement System and Teachers' Pension System, local school systems, and the Maryland School for the Deaf.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have no discernible effect on State pension liabilities or contribution rates, as it applies to a limited number of individuals. There is no local fiscal impact or effect on revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency administers the Teachers’ Retirement and Pension Systems affected by the bill. It is responsible for enforcing reemployment offsets and is specifically directed by the bill to refund certain offsets for reemployed retirees who meet specific criteria.

The bill explicitly grants the Superintendent of the Maryland School for the Deaf the authority to rehire up to five retirees into any position within the institution without a retirement benefit offset.

The MSDE oversees the public K-12 education system. The bill expands the flexibility of local school superintendents to rehire retired teachers into non-school-based positions (such as central office roles) without affecting their pension benefits.

As the state's central fiscal and personnel authority, DBM oversees policies affecting state-funded retirement systems and personnel reemployment rules, ensuring fiscal accountability in the allocation of taxpayer resources for these benefits.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to the State Retirement and Pension System. It would provide legal guidance on the interpretation of the bill's retroactive provisions and the mandated refunding process.

The Governor's Office serves as the principal executive agency that signs legislation into law and oversees the operations of all state departments and agencies, including those tasked with implementing these pension and personnel changes.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Governor to provide an annual appropriation of $1,000,000 from fiscal year 2026 through 2028 for grants to qualifying nonprofit organizations that offer automotive repair training and reentry assistance to incarcerated or formerly incarcerated individuals. To qualify, organizations must train at least 50 individuals per year, provide nationally recognized certificates, and maintain a minimum 50% job placement rate.
qa_results.responsible_party: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Incarcerated and formerly incarcerated individuals, and qualifying nonprofit organizations providing automotive repair training.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $529,700 in FY 2025, which includes a $500,000 operating grant and administrative costs for a part-time contractual position. From FY 2026 through FY 2028, annual expenditures are estimated at approximately $1.03 million, assuming the $1 million discretionary grant is funded along with ongoing administrative expenses. A small administrative expenditure of $8,300 is expected in FY 2029 for closeout. There is no effect on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly mandates this office to administer the grant funds, establish performance measures, and receive reports on expenditures and outcomes from qualifying nonprofit organizations.

The bill authorizes the Governor to include a $1,000,000 annual appropriation in the budget for these grants and aligns with the office's core mission to oversee public safety and economic opportunity initiatives.

The agency oversees correctional education and workforce development. The fiscal note highlights the agency's current role in vocational training 'behind the fence' and its Re-entry Navigator initiative, which are directly related to the bill's goals.
As the state’s central fiscal authority, DBM is responsible for formulating the annual budget, which will include the $1,000,000 discretionary appropriation authorized by the bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill targets incarcerated and formerly incarcerated individuals, a population directly managed by this agency. Reentry services and the reduction of recidivism are core components of its correctional mission.

The bill's focus on automotive repair certification and employment placement aligns with the board's mission to build pipelines to high-demand careers and remove employment barriers for underserved populations.

The fiscal note identifies Commerce's role in the 'New Start Act,' which provides microloans to formerly incarcerated individuals, indicating a shared policy interest in the economic reintegration of the justice-involved population.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Prince George’s County government to grant a property tax credit of up to $2,500 for full-time employees of the Prince George’s County Public School System who have been employed for at least two years and purchase a home in the county after previously residing elsewhere. It also establishes the Office of Integrity and Compliance as an independent unit within the school system, tasked with investigating fraud, waste, and abuse and providing independent evaluations of school system programs.
qa_results.responsible_party: Prince George’s County Government and the Prince George’s County Public School System
qa_results.stakeholders: Full-time employees of the Prince George’s County Public School System and Prince George’s County residents.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Prince George’s County property tax revenues will decrease starting in fiscal 2025 to the extent the property tax credit is granted, with individual credits capped at $2,500. There is no impact on State revenues or expenditures. County expenditures are not directly affected as the Office of Integrity and Compliance's staffing costs are already integrated into the school system's budget.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires the newly established Integrity and Compliance Officer to report serious violations of law to the State Ethics Commission.
MSDE is the primary regulator for the public K-12 system, which includes the Prince George's County Public School System and its new Office of Integrity and Compliance.
This board has jurisdiction over appeals related to property tax credit programs, including the new credit authorized for school employees by this bill.
The office investigates misconduct in office and public ethics violations, which aligns with the investigations conducted by the new school system Integrity and Compliance Officer.
OLA performs fiscal compliance and performance audits; the bill's establishment of an Office of Integrity and Compliance mirrors these watchdog functions at a local level.
GOPI focuses on data-driven decision-making and eliminating fraud and waste, which are the primary mandates of the newly established school integrity office.
The Governor's Office oversees state agencies, signs legislation, and spearheads initiatives aimed at public safety and economic opportunity.
The bill promotes homeownership and neighborhood stability for public school employees through a local property tax credit.
The tax credit serves as a retention and recruitment incentive for the school workforce, which falls under the board's interest in creating pathways to employment.
The PERB oversees collective bargaining and labor relations for public school employees, whose employment status and internal compliance are affected by the bill.
The team focuses on economic mobility and poverty reduction; the bill provides a financial mechanism to support school employee homeownership and stability.
The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for state agencies and may be called upon to interpret the legal independence of the new office.
The IAC oversees school construction funds and fiscal sustainability, which may overlap with the integrity office's oversight of school system property and funds.
The Tax Court is the highest administrative review for tax controversies, potentially including disputes over the property tax credit authorized by this bill.
MLDS tracks education and workforce outcomes and may be used to analyze the impact of the school employee property tax credit.
DBM manages state personnel systems and fiscal accountability, and the bill defines a specific 'independent employee' category for the Integrity Officer.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Pricing and Selection Committee for Preferred Providers to grant waivers to State or State-aided or -controlled entities from the requirement to purchase supplies or services from Maryland Correctional Enterprises (MCE). A waiver may be granted if MCE's price is at least 10% above market rates or if MCE's delivery time does not meet the entity's needs. Additionally, MCE is required to provide an annual report on the length of time between orders and deliveries, and the Department of General Services is required to adopt implementing regulations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Pricing and Selection Committee for Preferred Providers and the Department of General Services
qa_results.stakeholders: State and State-aided or -controlled entities, Maryland Correctional Enterprises (MCE), and small businesses that compete for State contracts.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill may cause a significant nonbudgeted revenue decrease for Maryland Correctional Enterprises (MCE), potentially exceeding $1,000,000, depending on the volume of waivers granted. Conversely, State agencies may see a significant decrease in expenditures (all funds) if waivers allow them to purchase goods and services at lower market prices. MCE can handle the reporting requirements using existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that the Department of General Services (DGS) adopt regulations to implement the new waiver process. Additionally, the Secretary of General Services serves as a member of the Pricing and Selection Committee for Preferred Providers.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency oversees Maryland Correctional Enterprises (MCE), which is the primary preferred provider impacted by the new waiver provisions. The Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services also serves on the Pricing and Selection Committee for Preferred Providers.
