The bill repeals purchase limits for individuals visiting Class 1 distilleries and Class 5 breweries, which are significant heritage tourism destinations. This change directly impacts the agency's mission to stimulate the economy through travel and local business promotion.

OAH provides an impartial forum for residents to challenge decisions made by state agencies. Disputes regarding the denial or revocation of the new direct-to-consumer delivery permits would be adjudicated by Administrative Law Judges at this agency.

The bill is projected to increase state general fund revenues through permit fees ($200 initially and for renewals). DBM is responsible for estimating state revenues and overseeing the allocation of these public funds.

Commerce is the state's primary economic development agency. By expanding direct delivery options for breweries, wineries, and distilleries, the bill supports the growth and expansion of these private-sector businesses.

The OAG acts as the legal advisor to state agencies like the ATCC and the Comptroller. It would provide counsel on the implementation of the new direct delivery regulations and represent the state in any related legal challenges.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Agricultural & Resource-Based Industry Development Corp.
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MARBIDCO supports Maryland’s agricultural and resource-based industries, which include wineries and farm-based breweries. The expansion of direct-to-consumer delivery options improves the economic viability of these rural producers.

Many of the breweries and wineries affected by this bill are located in rural counties. RMC advocates for economic sustainability in these areas, and the new delivery rights support the growth of rural small businesses.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Many local breweries, wineries, and distilleries are small businesses. This agency provides advocacy and support for these entrepreneurs, who will benefit from the increased sales opportunities provided by direct delivery permits.

The bill requires an evaluation of a standard digital age verification system. DoIT is responsible for the state's strategic IT policy and cybersecurity standards, which would be relevant to implementing such a digital verification platform.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Tobacco Retail Modernization Act of 2024 makes several changes to the sale and enforcement of tobacco and electronic smoking devices. It requires retailers to keep these products behind counters, increases retail license fees to $300, and mandates that the Maryland Department of Health conduct at least one unannounced compliance inspection of every licensed retailer annually. The bill also removes exceptions that previously allowed 18-to-20-year-old active-duty military members to purchase tobacco products, effectively raising the minimum purchase age to 21 for all individuals.
qa_results.responsible_party: Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission and the Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Retailers of cigarettes, tobacco products, and electronic smoking devices; vape shop vendors; active-duty military members under age 21; and consumers of tobacco and nicotine products.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund revenues and expenditures increase by approximately $1.2 million in FY 2025 and $1.6 million annually thereafter due to the increase in license fees, which will fund enforcement grants to local health departments. General fund revenues may increase by $32,000 annually from higher fines, while general fund expenditures increase by $44,800 in FY 2025 for Judiciary computer programming. Local revenues for Montgomery County and local health departments will increase via fee distributions and state grants for enforcement.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Health is the primary implementing agency responsible for conducting annual unannounced inspections, managing enforcement grants to local health departments, and leading the collaborative report mandated by the bill.

The bill has a notable fiscal impact of approximately $44,761 on the Judiciary for IT programming. Court clerks are responsible for distributing license fees and communicating license suspension and revocation orders to the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission.

The agency is explicitly required to collaborate on a formal report analyzing the proximity of tobacco retailers to schools and the prevalence and health impacts of tobacco and electronic smoking device use among youth.

The Comptroller is named as a collaborating agency for the mandated reporting requirements and is responsible for monitoring the fiscal health and tax revenue impacts related to changes in tobacco and electronic smoking device sales.

DBM oversees the fiscal allocation of special funds and the creation of new state personnel positions (such as the administrative officer in the Department of Health) required to implement the bill's enforcement provisions.
As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the various departments involved in implementing the bill and signed the legislation into law.
The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the state agencies implementing the new regulatory and enforcement framework for tobacco and electronic smoking devices.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill involves criminal justice strategies and the coordination of enforcement efforts with local law enforcement agencies to reduce the sale of tobacco products to minors.

As the primary statewide law enforcement agency, the State Police are involved in the development and execution of strategies to enforce criminal laws regarding the distribution of tobacco products to individuals under 21.
The OLA will likely be responsible for future fiscal compliance audits of the new special fund revenues and expenditures managed by the Department of Health under this act.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill directs the Maryland Department of Information Technology to evaluate the feasibility of using artificial intelligence to develop a statewide virtual 3-1-1 portal to provide nonemergency government information and services to Maryland residents. If the department determines that creating such a portal is feasible, it is required to prioritize its development.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Information Technology
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents seeking nonemergency information and the Maryland Department of Information Technology.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Department of Information Technology (DoIT) expects to complete the required evaluation by January 2025 using existing resources. General fund expenditures may increase in the future if a statewide virtual 3-1-1 portal is implemented, but these costs cannot be reliably estimated at this time. The bill has no direct effect on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly tasks the Department of Information Technology with evaluating the feasibility of an AI-driven 3-1-1 portal and prioritizing its creation if determined to be feasible.
As a primary provider of essential social services, DHS is a key stakeholder for the nonemergency information and referrals that the 3-1-1 portal would facilitate.
MDH currently manages public health referrals and the integration of behavioral health (9-8-8) services, which are critical components of the nonemergency information systems mentioned in the bill.
MDEM is a major stakeholder in the development of 3-1-1 systems as they are designed to reduce nonemergency congestion on the 9-1-1 emergency lines managed by the department.
The Innovation Team's mission to test data-driven solutions and modernize government services aligns directly with the bill's goal of leveraging artificial intelligence for public service delivery.
The Governor's Office oversees all state departments and recently issued executive orders establishing the regulatory framework for AI use in state government.
DBM is responsible for the fiscal oversight of state expenditures, including the potential general fund increase required to implement the statewide 3-1-1 portal.
GOPI focuses on modernizing state services and eliminating government waste through data-driven decisions, a role that overlaps with the efficiency goals of an AI-driven 3-1-1 system.
MDOT agencies like SHA and MVA are primary sources of nonemergency inquiries that a 3-1-1 portal would be expected to handle for Maryland residents.
MDOD ensures that new state digital services, such as the proposed AI portal, are accessible and meet the needs of Marylanders with disabilities.
MDOA provides essential services to older adults, a demographic that frequently utilizes nonemergency referral systems like 2-1-1 and 3-1-1 for resource access.
The development of a 3-1-1 portal benefits MSP by redirecting nonemergency police-related inquiries away from emergency response channels.
The OAG provides necessary legal guidance to DoIT regarding data privacy, software contracts, and the ethical implementation of artificial intelligence.
OLA is responsible for auditing the fiscal management and performance effectiveness of new state programs and IT initiatives.
DGS manages state real estate and procurement; they would likely be involved in the contracting process for any AI technology or infrastructure required for the portal.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the authorized use of grants from the Safe Schools Fund to include school security employees who are not school resource officers. It also alters the grant distribution formula, changing it from a basis of the number of schools to the number of students enrolled in each school system. Furthermore, it requires the Maryland Center for School Safety, the State Department of Education, and the Interagency Commission on School Construction to jointly review the state of physical security in schools and existing safety guidelines every two years.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Center for School Safety, the State Department of Education, and the Interagency Commission on School Construction
qa_results.stakeholders: Public school students, staff, local school systems, and school security employees
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on total state revenues or expenditures as it primarily expands the authorized use of existing funds. Local school systems and law enforcement agencies will see no overall change in funding levels, although the shift to an enrollment-based allocation formula may redistribute grant amounts among various local jurisdictions.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Center is a primary implementing agency for the bill, tasked with jointly reviewing the state of physical security in schools and providing guidance for school security design to maximize safety.

MSDE is explicitly required to jointly review physical school security and provide guidance. Additionally, the Maryland Center for School Safety operates within MSDE, and the bill impacts local school system funding and personnel.
The IAC is explicitly named as a joint participant in reviewing school physical security and providing guidance, and its facility assessment process is coordinated with safety evaluations.
The bill authorizes the Governor to include significantly increased appropriations in the annual budget bill for the Safe Schools Fund and the Governor oversees the School Safety Subcabinet.
DBM is responsible for state budget formulation and will oversee the management of the increased grant funding authorized by the bill for fiscal years 2026 and 2027.

The Secretary of State Police is a member of the School Safety Subcabinet, and the Maryland Coordination and Analysis Center (MCAC), which provides input for the required security reviews, is staffed by State Police.
GOHS facilitates the Maryland Coordination and Analysis Center (MCAC), whose MVIEW program is specifically cited in the bill as providing input for the joint review of school physical security.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The School Safety Subcabinet, an executive body of cabinet members, is responsible for administering the Safe Schools Fund and establishing grant procedures impacted by this bill.
The Attorney General is a statutory member of the School Safety Subcabinet, which administers the grants and programs addressed in the bill.
The Secretary of Health is a statutory member of the School Safety Subcabinet, which manages the Safe Schools Fund and oversees the relevant safety regulations.

The Secretary of Disabilities is a statutory member of the School Safety Subcabinet, and school emergency plans reviewed by the subcabinet include specific accommodations for students with disabilities.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases funding for Maryland's emergency medical system by raising the annual motor vehicle registration surcharge from $17 to $40. It redirects these funds to the Maryland Emergency Medical System Operations Fund, the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center, and the Maryland Trauma Physician Services Fund. Additionally, it increases maximum fines for certain driving-while-impaired offenses, allocating at least 20% of those collections to trauma services, and mandates an annual $16.5 million appropriation for local fire and rescue services via the Senator William H. Amoss Fund starting in fiscal year 2026.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Health Care Commission, Health Services Cost Review Commission, Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems, and the Motor Vehicle Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland motor vehicle owners, trauma centers, trauma physicians and health care practitioners, the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center, and local fire, rescue, and ambulance departments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund revenues increase by $104.8 million annually starting in FY 2025 due to the registration surcharge increase. These revenues are distributed to the Maryland Emergency Medical System Operations Fund (MEMSOF), the Shock Trauma Center, and the Maryland Trauma Physician Services Fund (MTPSF). Special fund expenditures increase by $3.4 million in FY 2025 and $4.9 million annually thereafter to cover credit card processing fees, pediatric trauma grants, and a mandated $1.5 million increase in Amoss Fund appropriations. Local governments receive increased fire and rescue funding through the Amoss Fund.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor is required to sign the legislation and must include mandated appropriations for the Senator William H. Amoss Fund in the annual budget starting in fiscal 2026.
The Comptroller is responsible for administering the Maryland Emergency Medical System Operations Fund (MEMSOF) and managing the accounting for the redistributed surcharge revenues.
The State Treasurer serves as the principal custodian of the state funds being redistributed and sits on the Board of Public Works which oversees related fiscal integrity.
The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to the multiple state commissions and departments implementing the new reimbursement methodologies and fund regulations.
DBM is responsible for formulating the state budget and must manage the mandated annual appropriation of $16.5 million for the Amoss Fund and other shifts in special fund spending.
The Department receives transfers from the Trauma Physician Services Fund to cover Medicaid expenditures and oversees the commissions administering the fund.
MDOT is the parent agency of the MVA and will experience a fiscal impact on the Transportation Trust Fund due to increased credit card processing fees for the higher surcharges.
MDEM administers the Senator William H. Amoss Fire, Rescue, and Ambulance Fund, which receives a significant mandated funding increase under the bill.
The State Police Aviation Division is a primary beneficiary of the Maryland Emergency Medical System Operations Fund (MEMSOF), which receives expanded funding from the surcharge increase.
The Judiciary collects the fines for impaired driving, which are increased by the bill, and requires system programming updates to implement the new fee structures.
MHCC is the primary agency responsible for administering the Maryland Trauma Physician Services Fund and establishing its reimbursement methodologies.
HSCRC jointly administers the Trauma Fund and is responsible for reporting hospital trauma costs and managing the state's hospital rate-setting system affected by this bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MIEMSS coordinates the statewide emergency medical system, sets the criteria for trauma centers, and is a major beneficiary of MEMSOF funding.
The MVA is directly responsible for collecting the increased $40 motor vehicle registration surcharge and distributing it according to the new statutory formulas.
The R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center and the Maryland Fire and Rescue Institute, which are part of or affiliated with the System, are major recipients of the expanded funding.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Workgroup on Home Detention Monitoring to study and provide recommendations concerning the costs and availability of pretrial home detention monitoring systems, whether provided publicly or privately. The workgroup must report its findings to the General Assembly annually.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Pretrial defendants, private home detention monitoring agencies, local detention centers, the Judiciary, state's attorneys, and the Maryland Public Defender.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures for staffing and member reimbursements are expected to be minimal and absorbable within existing resources. State revenues are not affected. Local government finances are not expected to be materially affected.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill designates the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services as a member of the Workgroup and mandates that the Department provide staff for the Workgroup's operations.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill explicitly establishes a new Workgroup on Home Detention Monitoring to study policy, costs, and availability of monitoring systems and provide recommendations.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Public Defender of Maryland, or their designee, is a statutory member of the newly created Workgroup.

The bill requires a representative of the Judiciary to be appointed by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Maryland to serve on the Workgroup; the AOC provides administrative support for such appointments and judicial participation.
The Governor is responsible for appointing several key members of the Workgroup, including representatives from detention centers, law enforcement associations, and private monitoring agencies.
This office will be responsible for recruiting and vetting the candidates the Governor must appoint to the Workgroup as specified in the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits incarcerated individuals who are serving a sentence for first-degree rape from earning diminution credits to reduce their term of confinement for crimes committed on or after October 1, 2024.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals convicted of first-degree rape, the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, and local correctional facilities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures are expected to increase in the future as individuals serve longer sentences, although there is no material effect in the near term (within the first five years). Local government finances are not anticipated to be materially affected because offenders for violent crimes are typically not sentenced to local facilities. No impact on state revenues is expected.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS is the primary implementing agency. It manages the State's adult correctional facilities and is responsible for calculating diminution credits and terms of confinement for incarcerated individuals. The bill directly impacts their operational processes and long-term costs.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP serves as the state's central hub for public safety policy and advises the Governor on criminal justice strategies. This bill represents a significant change in public safety policy regarding the sentencing and release of violent offenders.

DBM oversees the state's budget and general fund expenditures. The fiscal note indicates that this bill will lead to a potentially significant increase in long-term general fund expenditures for incarceration.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The OPD represents indigent individuals facing criminal charges. This bill fundamentally changes the sentencing consequences for clients charged with first-degree rape, affecting legal strategy and the advice provided by public defenders.
The OAG acts as the legal advisor to the state and manages criminal appeals. They are involved in the legal interpretation and defense of state laws related to sentencing and correctional services.
The Governor's Office oversees all state departments, including DPSCS, and is responsible for the overall execution of public safety laws and the state budget.
The AOC manages the administrative and technological infrastructure of the Maryland Judiciary, where the convictions and sentences for first-degree rape occur.
The OLA conducts fiscal compliance and performance audits of executive agencies, including DPSCS. They monitor the efficiency and legal compliance of state spending on incarceration.

MSP is the primary agency investigating major crimes like first-degree rape. While the bill impacts the post-sentencing phase, it relates to the broader criminal justice framework in which MSP operates.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the State Emergency Medical Services Board, in collaboration with the Maryland Department of Health, to co-locate at least two doses of naloxone with every automated external defibrillator (AED) in public buildings such as transit stations, parks, and schools. It provides civil immunity for building owners and individuals who administer naloxone during a suspected overdose and mandates that the initiative be funded via the Opioid Restitution Fund.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Emergency Medical Services Board and the Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Owners and operators of public buildings, students and staff at secondary and higher education institutions, users of public transit and parks, and individuals at risk of opioid overdose.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Special fund expenditures from the Opioid Restitution Fund increase by at least $74,100 in FY 2025 for personnel. Additional unquantified costs include IT updates and the purchase of naloxone kits ($45 per pack) and storage materials ($25 per site). Local impact is expected to be absorbable within existing resources.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency is primarily responsible for administering the Public Access Automated External Defibrillator Program and is mandated by the bill to lead the development and implementation of the naloxone co-location initiative.
The department is required to collaborate with MIEMSS on the initiative and oversees the Opioid Restitution Fund, which is the bill's designated funding source for these emergency services.
The bill defines 'public building' to include public secondary schools, requiring these facilities to co-locate naloxone with existing AEDs, which impacts MSDE-overseen K-12 school systems.
The bill's definition of 'public building' includes public mass transportation accommodations such as terminals and stations, which are managed by units of this department.
This agency manages Maryland's state parks and public gathering areas, which fall under the bill's definition of 'public buildings' required to participate in the naloxone co-location initiative.
As an operator of numerous public transportation stations and terminals, the MTA is directly impacted by the requirement to maintain co-located naloxone doses at these facilities.
Public higher education facilities are specifically included in the bill's requirements, impacting the campuses and facilities managed by the University System.
As a public higher education institution, the university is subject to the bill's requirement to co-locate naloxone with AEDs in its public campus buildings.
As the state’s public honors college, its facilities are covered under the bill's definition of 'public building' for secondary or higher education.
As a state-operated secondary education facility, the school is required to meet the naloxone co-location standards established by the initiative.
MHEC serves as the coordinating board for the higher education sector, which is significantly impacted by the bill's requirements for public college and university buildings.
DBM is responsible for the fiscal oversight and appropriation of the Opioid Restitution Fund, which is mandated as the funding source for this initiative.
The bill references the Maryland State Police Medical Director regarding protocols for individuals administering medications in response to a drug overdose.
The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies regarding the implementation of the bill and its significant civil immunity provisions for responders and building owners.
The bill amends the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article to establish civil immunity for those providing naloxone, which impacts court proceedings and judicial interpretations of liability.
The MSA manages various gathering and amusement venues that may qualify as 'public buildings' required to co-locate naloxone under the new regulations.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill expands the Maryland Police Officers and Probation Agents Scholarship Program by including Maryland community colleges as eligible institutions. The program provides tuition assistance to students intending to become police officers or probation agents and to current police officers and probation agents pursuing degrees to further their careers.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Prospective police officers and probation agents, current law enforcement and probation personnel seeking higher education, and Maryland community colleges.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill expands eligibility for an existing scholarship program but is not expected to increase State expenditures beyond the current $5,000,000 annual general fund mandate, as the program has been significantly underutilized. The Maryland Higher Education Commission can implement the changes with existing resources. Local community college revenues and expenditures are not expected to be materially affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MHEC is the primary implementing agency for the scholarship program. The bill directly alters the program's eligibility criteria, which MHEC's Office of Student Financial Assistance must administer.
As the coordinating body for higher education, the commission oversees the scholarship program and the institutions (including community colleges) newly eligible under this bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS employs probation agents, who are primary beneficiaries of the scholarship program. Expanding eligible institutions to community colleges directly impacts the educational opportunities for their workforce.

Maryland State Police officers are eligible for this scholarship program. The expansion to community colleges provides more accessible educational pathways for recruitment and career advancement within the agency.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP is the state's central hub for public safety policy and funding. Although specific reporting requirements were amended in the final bill, the scholarship remains a key tool in their broader public safety recruitment strategy.
DBM oversees the state's annual budget, which includes the mandatory $5.0 million appropriation for this scholarship program. They manage the fiscal allocation that supports these changes.

USM institutions were previously the primary 'eligible institutions' for this scholarship. The inclusion of community colleges expands the program's scope and provides alternative pathways for students who might otherwise attend USM schools.
The Natural Resources Police are considered police officers under state law, making their recruits and current officers eligible beneficiaries of the scholarship's expanded eligibility.
MDOT oversees the MDTA Police and Transit Police. These officers are eligible for the scholarship, and expanding eligibility to community colleges facilitates recruitment for these divisions.
The Governor's Office is responsible for signing the legislation into law and oversees the agencies (MHEC, DPSCS, MSP) involved in the program's administration and use.

The MLDS Center tracks student and workforce data. Expanding this scholarship program likely requires tracking the educational and employment outcomes of recipients as they move into public safety careers.
The board works to create pathways to high-demand careers; public safety is a critical workforce sector, and this scholarship supports the pipeline of trained officers and agents.

As a public senior higher education institution, Morgan State is currently an eligible institution for this program. The bill expands the market to community colleges, which could impact student enrollment patterns in criminal justice programs.
St. Mary's is an eligible institution for the scholarship. The expansion to community colleges introduces new institutional partners into the financial aid framework they currently utilize.
The OAG provides legal counsel to MHEC and other state agencies regarding the implementation of legislative changes and the regulation of scholarship programs.
OLA conducts periodic fiscal compliance audits of MHEC and the scholarship funds it administers, including the Police Officers and Probation Agents Scholarship Program.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the notification requirements that hospitals must follow when charging outpatient facility fees. It expands the definition of 'hospital' to include out-of-state facilities that provide outpatient services at locations within Maryland and revises the specific disclosure language that must be provided to patients. Additionally, the bill mandates the Maryland Health Services Cost Review Commission (HSCRC) to study the impact of these fees and convene a workgroup to recommend potential expansions of the notice requirements to all outpatient services.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Health Services Cost Review Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Patients receiving hospital outpatient services, in-state and out-of-state hospitals, physician practices, health insurance carriers, and healthcare payers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures for the Health Services Cost Review Commission (HSCRC) are expected to increase by $75,000 in both FY 2025 and FY 2026, totaling $150,000, to hire consultants for the required studies and reports. Other state entities, including the Maryland Department of Health and the Office of the Attorney General, can fulfill their roles with existing resources. The bill has no impact on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary implementing agency, the HSCRC is responsible for conducting the comprehensive study on outpatient facility fees, convening the mandated workgroup, and submitting reports to the General Assembly. The fiscal note indicates a notable impact of $150,000 for contractual services to fulfill these requirements.

The Maryland Department of Health is explicitly named as a consultant for the required study and workgroup. Additionally, the study must evaluate the impact of facility fees on Medicaid recipients, a program administered by MDH.

The MIA is a designated consultant for the study and workgroup and is tasked with receiving annual lists of hospital-based, rate-regulated outpatient services to assist in its regulatory and consumer protection functions.

The Health Education and Advocacy Unit (HEAU) within the OAG is explicitly named as a consultant for the study and workgroup. The agency is also a recipient of hospital service lists and is responsible for assisting consumers with mediating facility fee complaints.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates the creation of a specialized workgroup comprised of various stakeholders to advise on the expansion of outpatient facility fee notice requirements.

The study includes an analysis of industry practices for approving outpatient locations 'at the hospital,' which overlaps with the MHCC’s regulatory responsibility for health system planning and facility oversight.
DBM is the state’s central fiscal authority; it is relevant because the bill involves special fund expenditures and oversight of the fiscal resources allocated for the HSCRC’s research and reporting.
The Governor’s Office oversees the executive agencies tasked with implementation and signed the legislation into law as part of a policy initiative to address healthcare affordability.
The study must evaluate the impact of hospital facility fees on employers, which aligns with the Department of Commerce's mission to support the economic welfare of Maryland businesses.

The bill explicitly exempts the HSCRC from standard state procurement laws (Division II of the State Finance and Procurement Article) when implementing the study and workgroup components, which is a notable deviation from DGS-managed protocols.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill is an annual corrective measure that addresses technical errors, omissions, and obsolete references within the Annotated Code of Maryland. It reorganizes certain sections and clarifies language to maintain the accuracy and clarity of the state's laws without making substantive policy changes.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Legislative Services
qa_results.stakeholders: The general public, legal professionals, and Maryland State agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no fiscal impact on state or local government operations or finances, as it is strictly technical in nature.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill officially updates numerous statutory references to reflect the renaming of the Court of Appeals to the Supreme Court of Maryland and the title of its members to Justices, which is a primary administrative change for the judiciary.

The bill updates critical terminology throughout the Health - General article, including replacing 'mental retardation' with 'intellectual disability' and formally codifying the name of the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner.
The bill corrects obsolete terminology by renaming the Water Management Administration to the Water and Science Administration across several articles of the Annotated Code.
The bill updates the name of the Alcohol and Tobacco Commission to the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission, reflecting the administrative reorganization of cannabis oversight.
The bill repeals the Rural Broadband Assistance Fund from the Economic Development Article to reflect its previous redesignation under the Department of Housing and Community Development.
The bill corrects cross-references related to the Maryland 529 program, student debt collection, and the registration of family child care providers which are overseen by MSDE.
The bill clarifies the delegation of fiduciary duties by the State Treasurer regarding the Maryland 529 program and updates provisions related to the custody of the 2010 Trust Fund.
The bill makes technical corrections to the Education Article regarding the delegation of fiduciary duties for the state's education savings programs.
The bill updates various cross-references and terminology affecting the Motor Vehicle Administration and the State Highway Administration, including veteran registration fee exemptions.
The bill makes several technical corrections to the Natural Resources Article, specifically regarding the 2010 Trust Fund and the Youghiogheny Scenic and Wild River Local Advisory Board.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill corrects terminology regarding the Board of Review's parole process and updates obsolete references to the Law Enforcement Officers’ Bill of Rights.
The bill updates obsolete references from 'Veterans’ Administration' to 'U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs' in various articles affecting veteran benefits and services.
The bill corrects technical terminology regarding OREC pricing schedules for offshore wind projects within the Public Utilities Article.
The bill updates cross-references in the Labor and Employment Article related to the State minimum wage and the Uninsured Employers’ Fund.
The bill corrects cross-references in the State Finance and Procurement Article regarding the referral of delinquent student accounts at public institutions of higher education.
The bill updates cross-references regarding motor vehicle liability insurance coverage for family child care providers.
The bill removes obsolete sections of the Economic Development Article regarding the Rural Broadband Assistance Fund and corrects stylistic errors in the Authority's membership provisions.
The bill updates the definition of police officers to include the renamed Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission and references the statewide accountability process.
The bill updates terminology regarding 'intellectual disability' within court proceedings that involve the rehabilitation and commitment of youth.
The bill updates terminology regarding 'intellectual disability' in court and criminal procedure articles that impact child welfare and adult protection cases.
The bill updates sections related to the accounting of the 2010 Trust Fund and the certification of costs for state projects.
The bill corrects stylistic errors and internal cross-references within the State Personnel and Pensions Article.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates how fishing reports are sent to the Maryland Department of Natural Resources (DNR). Instead of using specific department forms, reports will now be submitted according to rules set by DNR. The bill also applies these reporting requirements to recreational fishers with certain licenses.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Commercial fishers, fish packers, fish dealers, and recreational anglers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no direct effect on State or local finances. It permits the Department of Natural Resources to transition to electronic reporting systems via regulation and potentially introduce mandatory reporting for recreational fishing. Future costs related to system expansions would be addressed during the regulatory process. Small businesses in the commercial fishing industry may experience a potential impact from improved harvest data management.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary implementing agency, DNR is responsible for managing Maryland's fish resources, issuing commercial and recreational fishing licenses, and enforcing the reporting and auditing requirements modified by this bill.

The bill shifts reporting from physical forms to methods prescribed by regulations, which enables electronic and mobile reporting; DoIT oversees the state's IT infrastructure, cybersecurity, and digital service standards for such platforms.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Council on the Chesapeake Bay
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Also known as the Chesapeake Bay Cabinet, this council coordinates interagency data and policies; accurate fish harvest reporting is vital for monitoring water quality and ecosystem health goals for the Chesapeake Bay.

Maryland is a member of interstate compacts like the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission (ASMFC), which manage shared fish resources; the reporting data standardized by this bill is essential for meeting interstate management obligations.

The Council advocates for the economic sustainability of rural communities, including watermen and seafood dealers in the state's 18 rural counties who are directly impacted by these regulatory reporting changes.

The fiscal note identifies a potentially meaningful effect on small businesses in the commercial fishing industry; Commerce supports these businesses through marketing and economic development initiatives.

The Authority operates the state's wholesale seafood market hub in Jessup; its tenants include the packers and dealers specifically required by the bill to maintain accurate books and submit reports to DNR.

OAH provides impartial hearings for agency decisions; they would handle administrative appeals if DNR takes licensing or enforcement actions against individuals for failure to comply with the new reporting regulations.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor for DNR and will be responsible for reviewing the legality of the new regulations and the implementation of data privacy protections for income information contained in reports.

OLA conducts fiscal and performance audits of executive agencies; they would oversee DNR's compliance with the bill's auditing mandates and ensure that the fish resource data is being handled according to state law.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Many entities in the commercial fishing, packing, and dealing sectors are small businesses; this office monitors state procurement and regulatory impacts on small and diverse enterprises in these industries.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates sustainable land-use and environmental stewardship; the data collected from enhanced fishery reporting supports their goals of protecting the health of the Chesapeake Bay and coastal waters.

MDA promotes the economic viability of the seafood industry through programs like 'Maryland's Best'; while not the primary regulator, they support the marketing of products from the watermen and dealers affected by this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the University System of Maryland to issue up to $30 million in academic facilities bonds to finance and refinance various construction, renovation, and renewal projects across its campuses, specifically allocating $5 million for infrastructure improvements at the University of Maryland, College Park and $25 million for systemwide facilities renewal.
qa_results.responsible_party: University System of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Students, faculty, and staff of the University System of Maryland and its constituent institutions.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill increases State revenues and expenditures from bond proceeds by $30 million in FY 2025. Higher education expenditures are projected to increase by approximately $2.5 million annually beginning in FY 2026 for debt service payments over a 20-year period. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The University System is the primary entity authorized by the bill to issue $30 million in bonds and is responsible for managing the identified campus infrastructure and facilities renewal projects.
As the agency responsible for the state's capital budget and Capital Improvement Program (CIP), DBM oversees the fiscal allocation and oversight of these bonding proceeds.
The Board must approve significant state expenditures and capital improvements, serving as a critical oversight body for the University System's construction projects funded by these bonds.
The Governor's Office directs the state's budget process, including the CIP where these authorizations reside, and is responsible for signing the bonding authority into law.
The Treasurer oversees state debt management and serves on the Board of Public Works to approve the financial commitments and projects authorized by the bill.
MHEC coordinates statewide planning for higher education and ensures the University System's facility expansion aligns with the State Plan for Postsecondary Education.
The Comptroller serves as the state's fiscal watchdog and a member of the Board of Public Works, reviewing the financial implications and contract approvals associated with the bonds.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases funding and support for tax assistance programs for low-income residents in Maryland. It mandates the Comptroller to distribute $500,000 annually from the Unclaimed Property Fund to the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund starting in fiscal year 2025. Additionally, it increases the annual mandated appropriation for the CASH Campaign of Maryland from $500,000 to $800,000 beginning in fiscal year 2026, with a requirement that $150,000 of those funds be used for grants to provide mobile or on-demand tax clinics for seniors, rural communities, and under-resourced populations.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Maryland Comptroller and the Governor
qa_results.stakeholders: Low-income Maryland residents, senior populations, rural communities, New American populations, the University of Maryland School of Law, the University of Baltimore School of Law, and the Maryland Volunteer Lawyers Service.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Starting in FY 2025, general fund revenues decrease by $500,000 annually as unclaimed property funds are redirected to a special fund. Special fund revenues and expenditures increase by $500,000. Beginning in FY 2026, general fund expenditures increase by $300,000 annually to cover the expanded mandated appropriation for the CASH Campaign. Higher education revenues and expenditures for the University of Maryland and University of Baltimore increase by $333,300 annually due to the grants awarded from the special fund.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill designates the Comptroller as the administrator of the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund. The Comptroller is also responsible for distributing funds from the State’s Unclaimed Property Fund to this specific fund as mandated by the legislation.

Two of the three primary beneficiaries of the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund are the University of Maryland School of Law and the University of Baltimore School of Law, both of which are member institutions of the University System of Maryland.

The bill requires the Governor to include specific mandated appropriations in the annual State budget for the CASH Campaign of Maryland and provides the Governor with the authority to include appropriations for the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund.
The bill requires the State Treasurer to hold the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund separately and to invest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money.

As the agency responsible for formulating and overseeing the Governor's annual operating budget, DBM is responsible for implementing the mandated appropriations for tax assistance and the grant funds for low-income Marylanders required by this bill.

The bill amends the Human Services Article of the Maryland Code regarding the CASH Campaign's funding and objectives. The campaign's mission to provide tax preparation and financial services to low-income individuals aligns directly with the social service mission of DHS.

qa_results.bill_summary: This emergency bill expands eligibility for the Douglas J. J. Peters Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship by repealing the specific terminal dates for military service. Under this change, Maryland veterans, active-duty members, and their qualifying family members remain eligible for the scholarship if they served in Afghanistan on or after October 24, 2001, or in Iraq on or after March 19, 2003, regardless of when the U.S. Secretary of Defense declares the conflicts officially ended for service purposes.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission (MHEC)
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland veterans and active-duty military members who served in the Afghanistan or Iraq conflicts, members of the National Guard or reserves activated for these conflicts, and their spouses and children.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill expands eligibility but does not mandate additional state spending. The fiscal 2025 budget includes a $750,000 general fund appropriation for the scholarship program. While expanding eligibility to additional applicants may increase demand—estimated at approximately $47,000 annually for nine additional applicants—the Maryland Higher Education Commission can manage this with existing resources or by utilizing a waiting list. There is no impact on local revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency for statewide higher education policy and financial aid, MHEC (specifically the Office of Student Financial Assistance) is responsible for administering the Douglas J. J. Peters Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship and implementing the eligibility changes mandated by this bill.

The commission is the state's coordinating board for higher education and is directly responsible for administering the scholarship program mentioned in the bill through its Office of Student Financial Assistance.

The department is the primary advocate for Maryland's veterans and is responsible for helping them navigate and secure state benefits, including the education grants and scholarships that this bill expands by repealing the service terminal date.

Members of the Maryland National Guard who were activated as a result of the Afghanistan or Iraq conflicts, as well as their families, are specifically named as eligible beneficiaries of this scholarship.

As the head of the Military Department and commander of the Maryland National Guard, the Adjutant General oversees the personnel who are directly eligible for this scholarship based on their service in the specified conflicts.
The scholarship amount is explicitly capped at 50% of the tuition and fees at the USM institution with the highest annual expenses, and many scholarship recipients enroll in USM institutions.

As a public state university, Morgan State may enroll students who are recipients of the Douglas J. J. Peters Veterans scholarship, and the expansion of eligibility may affect its student financial aid coordination.
As a public state college, Saint Mary's may enroll students who utilize this scholarship, and the agency is responsible for facilitating state financial aid for its students.
DBM oversees the state's annual operating budget, which includes the general fund appropriation for the scholarship fund (noted as $750,000 in the fiscal 2025 budget).

The Governor's Office is responsible for drafting the state's annual budget, which includes the necessary funding for the Douglas J. J. Peters Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a Class B-CAEVC (College Athletic Event Venue Concessionaire) beer, wine, and liquor license in Prince George's County. The license allows authorized concessionaires at the University of Maryland, College Park and Bowie State University campuses to sell alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption at athletic event venues.
qa_results.responsible_party: Prince George’s County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Concessionaires at University of Maryland, College Park and Bowie State University, Prince George’s County Board of License Commissioners, and attendees of college athletic events.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Prince George's County revenues are expected to increase by approximately $10,500 annually starting in fiscal 2025 due to the issuance of three Class B-CAEVC licenses at $3,500 each. There is no material impact on State finances or operations. Local enforcement activities can be handled with existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly authorizes the creation of a new liquor license for concessionaires operating at athletic venues located on the campuses of the University of Maryland, College Park and Bowie State University, which are primary institutions within the University System of Maryland.

As the state's chief financial officer and tax collector, the Comptroller is responsible for overseeing the collection of alcohol-related excise taxes and state sales taxes generated by the new license holders.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to state agencies and universities; it would likely provide legal counsel regarding the implementation of the new license class on state-owned campus property and the resulting concession contracts.
The Governor's Office is responsible for the final signing and enactment of the legislation, and oversees the state departments and universities impacted by the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This joint resolution affirms the Maryland General Assembly's position that the federal Equal Rights Amendment (ERA) has met all requirements for adoption under Article V of the U.S. Constitution. It urges President Joseph R. Biden to publish the ERA as the 28th Amendment, calls on the U.S. Congress to pass a resolution affirming its status, and encourages other states to take similar actions.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Legislative Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents, the President of the United States, the U.S. Congress, and other state legislatures.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The joint resolution does not directly affect State or local finances, nor does it have an impact on small businesses. Expenditures are not impacted as the bill primarily involves administrative communication of the resolution.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's chief executive, the Governor signs joint resolutions and serves as the primary representative of Maryland in formal requests to the President of the United States and federal administration.

The bill explicitly mentions the Attorney General's previous legal advocacy (filing an amicus brief) in support of the ERA. The OAG is the state's lead legal advisor on constitutional amendments and the rule of law.

The agency's primary mission is to enforce anti-discrimination laws and ensure equal opportunity, particularly regarding protections based on sex, which is the core focus of the Equal Rights Amendment.

The Secretary of State maintains the Great Seal, certifies official state documents, and oversees diplomatic and interstate relations, which are relevant to a resolution communicated to other state legislatures.

This office acts as a liaison to diverse constituent groups, including LGBTQIA+ and other communities whose rights and protections are directly addressed by the equal rights advocacy outlined in the resolution.
